About the Original.name: About the Original
About the Original.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.MpHlri7y2k3OpikL caption=false classes="right three"]

The adventure in this set reimagines B2: The Keep on the Borderlands for the current edition of the game. First printed in 1979, the original adventure was designed for the Dungeons & Dragons Basic Set, which introduced new players and Dungeon Masters to the world of D&D—much as this set does.

Design: Gary Gygax

Development: Dave Cook, Harold Johnson, Jon Pickens, Michael Price, Evan Robinson, Lawrence Schick, Stephen D. Sullivan

Editing: Mike Carr, David Cook, Harold Johnson, Jeff R. Leason, Frank Mentzer, Tom Moldvay, Lawrence Schick, Edward G. Sollers, Stephen D. Sullivan, Jean Wells

Art: David S. LaForce, Erol Otus, Jim Roslof

Welcome to Adventure.name: Welcome to Adventure
Welcome to Adventure.text:
Dungeons & Dragons is a cooperative game in which a group plays together to tell fun and exciting fantasy stories facilitated by a player who assumes the role of Dungeon Master, or DM. Imagination and chance determine the fate of the players’ characters and their adventures.

Using This Guide

This guide familiarizes you with the contents of this set and teaches you some of D&D’s fundamental rules, while the Quick-Start Guide helps you assign roles, rapidly create characters, and begin play. You don’t need to memorize every rule in this book, but understanding how it is organized will help you find relevant information when needed.

For explanations of game terms, see the rules glossary at the end of this booklet.

Harnessing Imagination

In D&D, the action takes place in the imaginations of the players, and it’s narrated by everyone together. Here’s a glimpse at what that looks like:

Jared (as Dungeon Master): After your journey through the wilderness, the Caves of Chaos loom ahead. The caves dot towering cliffs. Eerie lights glimmer in some of the cavernous openings, and bestial howls echo around you. What do you do?

Phillip (as the Cleric): I listen carefully to the howls. What do they sound like? And which cave are they coming from?

Sam (as the Fighter): I stand guard by the closest cave’s opening. I don’t want anything to sneak up on us!

Jared: All right, one at a time. Phillip, make a Wisdom check.

Phillip: Does my Perception skill apply?

Jared: Sure!

Phillip (Rolling a D20): Ugh. I rolled a 2 for a total of 7.

Jared: You can’t pinpoint the howls’ source, but you’re pretty sure you’re not hearing the sounds of regular animals.

Sam: Now I’m even more on guard!

Jared: That’s good, because you’re pretty sure you hear something shuffling toward you in the cave’s darkness …

The adventure continues from there, relying on the DM’s descriptions to set the scenes. Later in this guide, an example shows how a battle might unfold. When you’re playing, your group determines how the adventure plays out!

Component Overview.name: Component Overview
Component Overview.text:
Learn how to build characters in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbQuickStart00.JournalEntryPage.8xJ4mVC3cU1juFrj]{Getting Started} section of the Quick Start guide.

Character Sheets

The pre-made Actors included in this Adventure use the standard D&D5E character sheet for Foundry Virtual Tabletop. Here's a breakdown of how you can interact with that sheet.

Parts of a Player's Character Sheet

  1. Class and Level. This is the character’s class and character level.

  2. Ability Modifiers. All creatures—characters and monsters—have six abilities that measure physical and mental characteristics. Each ability has a corresponding modifier.

  3. Saving Throws. A saving throw—also called a save—represents an attempt to avoid or resist a threat. A saving throw is a kind of &Reference[D20 Test].

  4. Skills. A skill is an area of specialization associated with an ability check. Ability checks and skills are described @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.XhwMgWG8yWHDW3kS]{later in this guide}.

  5. Heroic Inspiration. This gem denotes whether or not a character has &Reference[Inspiration]. Click it to add and remove Inspiration from your character.

  6. Initiative. Initiative determines the order of turns during combat. The Combat section (page 13) explains how to roll @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.t0sLMxxhkAqBXNPl]{Initiative}.

  7. Speed. A character’s Speed is the distance they can move on their turn. See @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.SVX0uYx2OeHm9pR3]{Movement and Position} for more information.

  8. Hit Points. Increase or decrease the value here to track a character’s @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.jStPaKVM0gltxO1g]{Hit Points} (see page 15) here. If you take 5 points of damage you can enter "-5" in the field and press enter and Foundry will calculate the change for you. Likewise, you can enter "+5" for healing.

  9. Inventory. This tab contains the physical gear that your character has like weapons, torches, and magic items.

  10. Class Features. This tab contains features that are unique to your Class, Background, Species, etc. These features provide a character’s most exciting capabilities.

  11. Resting. These two buttons allow you to Short (Left) and Long Rest (Right). Any features or items which rely on resting or a new day passing are automatically updated when using these buttons.

  12. Class Tips. The Pre-Made Actors biographies contain tips for playing your class.

  13. Origin. Click here to open the Compendium Browser and choose your Species and Background. You can also drag and drop a Background and Species item here.

Backgrounds

The Backgrounds included in Heroes of the Borderlands are detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBackgrounds0]{Backgrounds} Journal entry with a link to each Background. These Backgrounds can be dragged onto your character sheet or selected using the Compendium Browser.

Parts of a Background Item

  1. Item Name. The name of the Background.
  2. Item Type. The type of the Item.
  3. Advancement. Anything you need to play this Background is listed in the Advancement tab. They are automatically added to your character sheet when you select it.

  4. Description. Each background includes a brief narrative of what your character’s earlier life might have been like. It also gives your character special features not tied to their class or species.

Species

The Species included in Heroes of the Borderlands are detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSpecies00000]{Species} Journal entry with a link to each Species. These Species can be dragged onto your character sheet or selected using the Compendium Browser.

Parts of a Species Item

  1. Item Name. The name of the Species.
  2. Item Type. The type of the Item.

  3. Size. Your character’s species determines the character’s size.

  4. Special Traits. Each species gives a character special traits—unique characteristics based on the species’ physiology or magical nature. These special traits are added to your character sheet automatically and can be found in the Advancement tab.

Equipment

The Equipment included in Heroes of the Borderlands can be found in the Items Compendium Pack and are linked throughout various Journals as needed. They are also detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbEquipment000.JournalEntryPage.kXrRaXJGhQjC14Pr]{Equipment} page. Where an item differs materially from the SRD version of the item a modified version has been included in this module.

Parts of an Item

  1. Item Name. The name of the Item.
  2. Item Subtype. This line denotes what kind of equipment the card represents. The subtypes include things like adventuring gear, armor, tools, weapons, and class items like Spellbooks.

  3. Quantity, Weight, and Value. This area indicates the quantity of this Item, each unit's weight, and the monetary value of the item.

  4. Detail. This tab contains the full details of the weapon including all of its properties, reach, base attack, and damage.

  5. Activities. The Activities tab detail everything you can do with the Item. A simple weapon might only have an Attack activity but more complex magic items might have the ability to cast spells, provoke saves, or more.

  6. Effects. Some items can cause effects like making a creature invisible, forcing them prone, and more. This tab contains any effects that this Item can cause.

  7. To Hit and Damage. This area shows the weapon's to hit bonus, amount, and type of damage it deals when an attacker hits with it.

  8. Description. A description of the Item and how it works. Each weapon has a mastery property defined on its card. To use that property, you must have a feature that lets you use it. If your character can use a given Item's mastery it will be available when using the Item.

Spells

The Spells included in Heroes of the Borderlands can be found in the Character Options Compendium Pack and are linked throughout various Journals as needed. They are also detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSpells000000]{Spells} Journal. Where a spell differs materially from the SRD version of the spell a modified version has been included in this module.

Parts of a Spell Item

  1. Spell Item Name. The name of the Spell.
  2. Spell Metadata. This area details properties of the spell like its level, school, and spellcasting method.

  3. Detail. This tab contains the full details of the weapon including all of its properties, reach, base attack, and damage.

  4. Activities. The Activities tab detail everything you can do with the Spell. A simple Spell might only have an Attack activity but more complex Spells might have the ability to provoke saves and more.

  5. Effects. Some Spells can cause effects like making a creature invisible, forcing them prone, and more. This tab contains any effects that this Spell can cause.

  6. Spell Properties. This area covers how long it takes to cast this Spell, its Range, Target area, whether it requires Verbal, Somatic, or Material components, its duration, and any materials which are necessary to cast it.

  7. Description. Each Spell includes a description of how the Spell works, what/whom it impacts, and what occurs if you cast it at a higher level.

Magic Items

The Magic Items included in Heroes of the Borderlands can be found in the Items Compendium Pack and are linked throughout various Journals as needed. They are also detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbEquipment000.JournalEntryPage.4CF0awJZeBENHnYo]{Magic Items} page. Where an item differs materially from the SRD version of the item a modified version has been included in this module.

NPCs

The NPCs included in Heroes of the Borderlands are detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000]{NPCs} Journal entry with a link to each Actor.

Parts of an NPC/Monster Sheet

  1. Creature Name. The name of the NPC/Monster.
  2. Creature Metadata. This line denotes the creature's size, creature type, and alignment which are explained in the rules glossary.
  3. Challenge Rating. This number summarizes the threat a creature poses. The higher the number, the greater the threat.
  4. Attributes and Saving Throws. This section details the creature’s ability and saving throw modifiers. For more on these terms, see the rules glossary.

  5. Basic Statistics. This section lists the creature’s Armor Class (in the shield to the left), Hit Points (in the green bar), Initiative (top-right). and the creature's portrait (all defined in the rules glossary).

  6. Skills, Senses, Resistances and Immunities. These entries list the creature's skills, if any, along with any special senses, &Reference[Resistance]{Resistances}, and &Reference[Immunity]{Immunities}. Resistances and Immunities are defined in the rules glossary, as is each special sense. If the creature has any other traits, those appear below these sections.

  7. Features/Item. A creature can take one action on its turn. The DM chooses one of these actions or an action detailed in the rules glossary. Some creatures might also have Bonus Actions, Reactions, or both.

  8. More Details. The NPC/Monster sheet has additional tabs for Inventory, Spells, Effects, Biography, and Special Properties. The Inventory contains items like weapons, armor, lanterns, etc. The Spells tab contains any spells that the creature can cast. The Effects tab summarizes any effects which are currently impacting the creature. The Biography tab contains details about a Monster's origins or an NPC's background and any rumors they know. The Special Properties tab contains some special checkboxes to enable unique functionality and fields for adding global bonuses to the creature's abilities.

Monsters

The Monsters included in Heroes of the Borderlands are detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbMonsters0000]{Monsters} Journal entry with a link to each Actor.

Rhythm of Play.name: Rhythm of Play
Rhythm of Play.text:
D&D involves imagination, improvisation, and strategy. A typical game unfolds according to this basic pattern:

1: The DM Describes a Situation. The DM tells the other players where their characters are and what’s around them.

2: Players React to the Situation. A player can do any of the following:

  • Ask the DM questions about the scene, such as for more details about a particular creature or thing their character perceives.
  • Discuss with other players how they feel about the situation.
  • Tell the DM what their character does or says.

3: The DM Narrates What Happens Next. After a player says what their character does, the DM can do one or both of the following:

  • Describe how the situation changes in response to the character’s action.
  • Ask a player to roll a &Reference[D20 Test] to determine the outcome of their character’s action.

This pattern repeats throughout the game.

Dice.name: Dice
Dice.text:
Dice add randomness to the game. They help determine whether characters and monsters are successful at the things they attempt.

Dice Notation

The dice used in D&D are referred to by the letter d followed by the die’s number of sides: d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, and d20. For instance, a d6 is a six-sided die (the cube that many games use). The illustration on this page shows what each die looks like.

When you need to roll dice, the rules tell you how many dice to roll of a certain type, along with any numbers to add or subtract. For example, “3d8 + 5” means you roll three eight-sided dice, add them together, and add 5 to the total.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.W0vyflY3p76pnOKA]

What Are Dice For?

Here are the most common uses of dice in D&D:

The D20. The 20-sided die (d20) is the most important die in the game. It’s central to the core mechanic—called &Reference[D20 Test]{D20 Tests}—the game uses to determine whether creatures succeed or fail at the things they attempt. You roll a d20 when your character tries to do something that the DM decides has a chance of both success and failure; the higher the roll, the more likely it is that the character succeeds.

Damage. The most common use for dice other than the d20 is to determine damage. When you make a successful attack roll (one kind of D20 Test), you roll damage to see how effective the attack is. When you cast a spell, you might also roll damage. Different weapons and spells use different dice for damage. For example, a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.phbwepDagger0000]{Dagger} uses 1d4 and the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplBurningHan]{Burning Hands} spell uses 3d6.

The Six Abilities.name: The Six Abilities
The Six Abilities.text:
All creatures—characters and monsters—have six abilities that measure their physical and mental characteristics, as shown on the Ability Descriptions table.

Ability Descriptions

Ability

Measures …

Strength

Physical might

Dexterity

Agility, reflexes, and balance

Constitution

Health and stamina

Intelligence

Reasoning and memory

Wisdom

Perceptiveness and mental fortitude

Charisma

Confidence, poise, and charm

Ability Modifiers

Each ability has a modifier that you apply whenever you make a &Reference[D20 Test] with that ability. A character’s ability modifiers are listed on the character’s or monster's sheet.

D20 Tests.name: D20 Tests
D20 Tests.text:
When the outcome of an action is uncertain, the game uses a d20 roll to determine success or failure. These rolls are called D20 Tests, and they come in three kinds: ability checks, saving throws, and attack rolls. They all follow these steps:

1: Roll 1d20. You always want to roll high. If the roll has &Reference[Advantage] or &Reference[Disadvantage], you roll two d20s, but you use the number from only one of them—the higher one if you have Advantage or the lower one if you have Disadvantage.

2: Add Modifiers. Add these modifiers to the number rolled on the d20:

  • Relevant Ability Modifier. The following sections explain which ability modifier to use for various &Reference[D20 Test]{D20 Tests}. Characters’ and monsters' ability modifiers are listed on their character sheets.
  • Circumstantial Bonuses and Penalties. A class feature, a card, or another rule might give a bonus or penalty to the die roll.

3: Compare the Total to a Target Number. If the total of the d20 and its modifiers equals or exceeds the target number, the D20 Test succeeds. Otherwise, it fails. The DM determines target numbers and tells the other players whether their rolls succeed. The target number for an ability check or a saving throw is called a Difficulty Class (DC). The target number for an attack roll is called an Armor Class (AC), which appears on their character sheets.

Ability Checks.name: Ability Checks
Ability Checks.text: An ability check represents a creature using talent and training to try to overcome a challenge. The DM and the rules often call for an ability check when a creature attempts something other than an attack.

Saving Throws.name: Saving Throws
Saving Throws.text:
A saving throw—also called a save—represents an attempt to evade or resist a spell, a trap, or another threat. You don’t normally choose to make a save; you must make one because your character (if you’re a player) or a monster (if you’re the DM) is at risk. A save’s result is detailed in the effect that caused it.

Ability Modifier

A saving throw is named for the ability modifier it uses: a Constitution saving throw, a Wisdom saving throw, and so on. A rule or the DM tells you which ability modifier to use.

Difficulty Class

The DC for a saving throw is determined by the effect that causes it or by the DM. For example, if a spell forces you to make a save, the DC is specified on the Spell. Monster abilities that call for saves specify the DC on the feature in the monster's character sheet.

Attack Rolls.name: Attack Rolls
Attack Rolls.text:
An attack roll determines whether an attack hits a target. An attack roll hits if the roll equals or exceeds the target’s Armor Class. Attack rolls usually occur in battle, described in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.xfCOOUmTtzTIKIUe]{Combat} section, but the DM might also ask for an attack roll in other situations, such as an archery competition.

Ability Modifier

The Attack Roll Abilities table shows which ability modifier to use for different types of attack rolls.

Attack Roll Abilities

Ability

Attack Type

Strength

Melee attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike

Dexterity

Ranged attack with a weapon

Varies

Spell attack

The ability modifier used for a spell attack depends on the spellcaster’s spellcasting ability, as specified on the character’s sheet. See @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.gJFi9mc3JPxmJYpy]{Spellcasting} for more information.

Armor Class

A creature’s Armor Class (AC) represents how well the creature avoids being wounded in combat. A character’s and monster's AC is listed on their character sheet.

Calculating AC. All creatures start with the same base AC calculation:

  • Base AC = 10 + the creature’s Dexterity modifier

A creature’s AC can then be modified by armor, magic items, spells, and more.

Only One Base AC. Some spells and class features give characters a different way to calculate their AC. A character with multiple features that give different ways to calculate AC must choose which one to use; only one base calculation can be in effect for a creature.

Rolling 20 or 1

If you roll a 20 on the d20 (called a “natural 20”) for an attack roll, the attack hits regardless of any modifiers or the target’s AC. This is called a @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.TDMRKIHPdK6Fds0m]{Critical Hit}.

If you roll a 1 on the d20 (a “natural 1”) for an attack roll, the attack misses regardless of any modifiers or the target’s AC.

Advantage/Disadvantage.name: Advantage/Disadvantage
Advantage/Disadvantage.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.jqgIg316l93kQDAa classes="right three"]

Sometimes a &Reference[D20 Test] is modified by &Reference[Advantage] or &Reference[Disadvantage]. Advantage reflects positive circumstances surrounding a d20 roll, while Disadvantage reflects negative circumstances.

You usually acquire Advantage or Disadvantage through the use of special abilities and actions.

Roll Two D20s

When a roll has either Advantage or Disadvantage, roll a second d20 when you make the roll. Use the higher of the two rolls if you have Advantage, and use the lower roll if you have Disadvantage. For example, if you have Disadvantage and roll an 18 and a 3, use the 3. If you instead have Advantage and roll those numbers, use the 18.

They Don’t Stack

If multiple situations give a roll Advantage, you still roll only two d20s. Similarly, if multiple situations give a roll Disadvantage, you roll only two d20s.

If circumstances cause a roll to have both Advantage and Disadvantage, the roll has neither of them, and you roll one d20. This is true even if multiple circumstances impose Disadvantage and only one grants Advantage or vice versa. In such a situation, you have neither Advantage nor Disadvantage.

Interactions with Rerolls

When you have Advantage or Disadvantage and something in the game lets you reroll or replace the d20, you can reroll or replace only one die, not both. You choose which one. For example, if a Halfling has Advantage or Disadvantage on an ability check and rolls a 1 and a 13, the Halfling could use their Lucky trait to reroll the 1.

Actions.name: Actions
Actions.text:
When a creature does something other than moving or communicating, it typically takes an action. You can take only one action at a time.

The Actions table lists the game’s main actions, which are defined in the rules glossary.

Actions

Action

Summary

Attack

Attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike.

Dash

For the rest of the turn, give yourself extra movement equal to your Speed.

Disengage

Your movement doesn’t provoke Opportunity Attacks for the rest of the turn.

Dodge

Until the start of your next turn, attack rolls against you have Disadvantage, and you make Dexterity saving throws with Advantage. You lose this benefit if you have the Incapacitated condition or if your Speed is 0.

Help

Help another creature’s ability check or attack roll, or administer first aid.

Hide

Make a Dexterity (Stealth) check.

Influence

Make a Charisma (Deception, Intimidation, Performance, or Persuasion) or Wisdom (Animal Handling) check to alter a creature’s attitude.

Magic

Cast a spell, use a magic item, or use a magical feature.

Ready

Prepare to take an action in response to a trigger you define.

Search

Make a Wisdom (Insight, Medicine, Perception, or Survival) check.

Study

Make an Intelligence (Arcana, History, Investigation, Nature, or Religion) check.

Utilize

Use a nonmagical object.

A character can also do things not covered by these actions. Many class features and other abilities provide additional action options, and you can improvise other actions. When you describe an action not detailed elsewhere in the rules, the DM tells you whether that action is possible and what kind of &Reference[D20 Test] you need to make, if any.

Bonus Actions

Various class features, spells, and other abilities let you take an additional action on your turn called a Bonus Action. The Cunning Action feature, for example, allows a level 2 Rogue to take a Bonus Action. You can take a Bonus Action only when a special ability, a spell, or another feature of the game states that you can do something as a Bonus Action. You otherwise don’t have a Bonus Action to take.

You can take only one Bonus Action on your turn, so you must choose which Bonus Action to use if you have more than one available.

You choose when to take a Bonus Action during your turn unless that action’s timing is specified.

Reactions

Certain special abilities, spells, and situations allow you to take a special action called a Reaction. A Reaction is an instant response to a trigger of some kind, which can occur on your turn or on someone else’s. The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.1BoqRgrcz1QPVNKR]{Opportunity Attack} is the most common type of &Reference[Reaction].

When you take a Reaction, you can’t take another one until the start of your next turn. If the reaction interrupts another creature’s turn, that creature can continue its turn right after the Reaction.

A Reaction takes place immediately after its trigger unless the Reaction’s description says otherwise.

Social Interaction.name: Social Interaction
Social Interaction.text:
During adventures, the characters meet different people and face some monsters that would rather talk than fight. In those situations, it’s time for social interaction, which takes many forms. For example, a character might try to convince a burglar to confess or try to flatter a guard. The DM assumes the roles of any nonplayer characters who are participating.

An NPC’s attitude toward a character is &Reference[Friendly], &Reference[Indifferent], or &Reference[Hostile], as defined in the rules glossary. Friendly NPCs are predisposed to help, and Hostile ones are inclined to hinder.

Social interactions progress in two ways: through roleplaying and ability checks.

Roleplaying.name: Roleplaying
Roleplaying.text:
When you roleplay a character, you determine how the character thinks, acts, and talks. Roleplaying is part of the whole game, but it comes to the fore during social interactions.

The DM uses an NPC’s personality and a character’s actions and attitudes to determine how an NPC reacts. When interacting with an NPC, pay attention to the DM’s portrayal of the NPC. You might be able to learn an NPC’s goals and then use that information to influence the NPC.

If you offer NPCs something they want or play on their sympathies or fears, you can form friendships, ward off violence, or learn key information. If you insult an NPC, you might cause them to turn on you.

undefined.name: Duration
undefined.text:
A spell’s duration is the length of time the spell persists after it is cast. A duration typically takes one of the following forms:

Concentration. If a duration requires Concentration, see &Reference[Concentration] in the rules glossary.

Instantaneous. An instantaneous duration means the spell’s magic appears and then disappears.

Time Span. A duration that provides a time span specifies how long the spell lasts in rounds, minutes, hours, or the like. For example, if a Duration entry says “1 minute,” the spell ends after 1 minute. While a time-span spell that you cast is ongoing, you can dismiss it (no action required) if you don’t have the &Reference[Incapacitated apply=false] condition.

Exploration.name: Exploration
Exploration.text:
Exploration involves delving into places that are dangerous and full of mystery. The rules in this section detail some of the ways adventurers interact with the environment in such places.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.YJLdyHZONameB2qb caption=false]

Vision and Light.name: Vision and Light
Vision and Light.text:
Some adventuring tasks—such as noticing danger, hitting an enemy, and targeting certain spells—are affected by sight, so effects that obscure vision can hinder you, as explained below.

Obscured Areas

An area might be Lightly or Heavily Obscured.

Lightly Obscured. In a Lightly Obscured area—such as an area with Dim Light, patchy fog, or moderate foliage—you have Disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

Heavily Obscured. A Heavily Obscured area—such as an area of Darkness, heavy fog, or dense foliage—is opaque. You have the &Reference[Blinded apply=false] condition when trying to see something there.

Light

The presence or absence of light determines the category of illumination in an area, as defined below.

Bright Light. Bright Light lets most creatures see normally. Even gloomy days provide Bright Light, as do torches, lanterns, fires, and other sources of illumination within a specific radius.

Dim Light. Dim Light, also called shadows, creates a Lightly Obscured area. An area of Dim Light is usually a boundary between Bright Light and surrounding Darkness. The soft light of twilight and dawn also counts as Dim Light. A full moon might bathe the land in Dim Light.

Darkness. Darkness creates a Heavily Obscured area. Characters face Darkness outdoors at night (even most moonlit nights), within the confines of an unlit dungeon, or in an area of magical Darkness.

Special Senses

Some creatures have special senses that help them perceive things in certain situations. The rules glossary defines the following special senses: &Reference[Blindsight], &Reference[Darkvision], &Reference[Tremorsense], and &Reference[Truesight].

Hiding.name: Hiding
Hiding.text:
Adventurers and monsters often hide, whether to spy on one another, sneak past a guardian, or set an ambush. The DM decides when circumstances are appropriate for hiding. When you try to hide, you take the &Reference[Hide] action.

Finding Hidden Objects

When your character searches for hidden things, such as a secret door or a trap, the DM typically asks you to make a Wisdom (Perception) check, provided you describe the character searching in the hidden object’s vicinity. On a success, you find the object, other important details, or both.

If you describe your character searching nowhere near a hidden object, a Wisdom (Perception) check won’t reveal the object, no matter the check’s total.

Combat.name: Combat
Combat.text: Adventurers encounter many dangerous monsters and nefarious villains. In those moments, combat often breaks out.

The Order of Combat.name: The Order of Combat
The Order of Combat.text:
A typical combat encounter is a clash between two sides: a flurry of weapon swings, feints, parries, footwork, and spellcasting. The game organizes combat into a cycle of rounds and turns. A round represents about 6 seconds in the game world.

Combat Step by Step

Combat unfolds in these steps:

1: Establish Positions. The DM determines where all the characters and monsters are located. Given the adventurers’ stated positions in the location, the DM figures out where the adversaries are—how far away and in what direction.

2: Roll Initiative. Everyone involved in the combat encounter rolls Initiative, determining the order of combatants’ turns.

3: Add Combatants to the Combat Tracker. The DM writes down each combatant’s name next to their Initiative count.

4: Take Turns. Each participant in the battle takes a turn in initiative order. When everyone involved in the combat has had a turn, the round ends. Repeat this step until the fighting stops.

Playing on a Grid

Follow these rules when playing on a gridded map.

Squares. Each square represents 5 feet.

Speed. Rather than moving foot by foot, move square by square on the grid, using your Speed in 5-foot segments. You can translate your Speed into squares by dividing it by 5. For example, a Speed of 30 feet translates into 6 squares.

Entering a Square. To enter a square, you must have enough movement left to pay for entering. It costs 1 square of movement to enter an unoccupied space that’s adjacent to your space (orthogonally or diagonally adjacent). A square of &Reference[Difficult Terrain] costs 2 squares to enter. Other effects might make a square cost even more.

Corners. Diagonal movement can’t cross the corner of a wall, a large tree, or another terrain feature that fills its space.

Ranges. To determine the range on a grid between two things—whether creatures or objects—count squares from a square adjacent to one of them and stop counting in the space of the other one. Count by the shortest route.

Initiative.name: Initiative
Initiative.text:
Initiative determines the order of turns during combat. When combat starts, every participant rolls Initiative; they make a Dexterity check that determines their place in the Initiative order.

The monsters in this module have Initiative modifiers on their sheets.

Initiative Order. A combatant’s check total is called their Initiative count, or Initiative for short. The DM ranks the combatants from highest to lowest Initiative on the Combat Tracker (this happens automatically when using Foundry's combat tracker). This is the order in which they act during each round. The Initiative order remains the same from round to round.

For a group of identical monsters, each member of the group acts on the same Initiative count, and the DM decides the order in which the individuals take their turns during that count.

Ties. If a tie occurs, the DM decides the order among tied monsters, and the other players decide the order among tied characters. The DM decides the order if the tie is between a monster and a character.

Your Turn.name: Your Turn
Your Turn.text:
On your turn, you can move a distance up to your &Reference[Speed] and take one action. You decide whether to move first or take your action first.

The main actions you can take are listed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.OLpDZ0dVH5nUjjee]{Actions} section. A character’s and a creature’s character sheets also list action options. The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.SVX0uYx2OeHm9pR3]{Movement and Position} section gives the rules for movement.

Communicating. You can communicate however you are able—through brief utterances and gestures—as you take your turn. Doing so uses neither your action nor your move.

Interacting with Things. You can interact with one object or feature of the environment for free, during either your move or your action. For example, you could open a door during your move as you stride toward a foe.

If you want to interact with a second object, you need to take the &Reference[Utilize] action. Some magic items and other special objects always require an action to use, as stated in their descriptions.

Doing Nothing on Your Turn. You can forgo moving, taking an action, or doing anything at all on your turn. If you can’t decide what to do, consider taking the &Reference[Dodge] action.

Ending Combat.name: Ending Combat
Ending Combat.text: Combat ends when one side or the other is defeated, which can mean the creatures are killed or knocked out or have surrendered or fled. Combat can also end when both sides agree to end it.

Movement and Position.name: Movement and Position
Movement and Position.text:
On your turn, you can move a distance equal to your &Reference[Speed] or less. Or you can decide not to move.

Your movement can include climbing, crawling, jumping, and swimming (each explained in the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule]{rules glossary}). These different modes of movement can be combined with your regular movement, or they can constitute your entire move.

However you’re moving with your Speed, you deduct the distance of each part of your move from it until it is used up or until you are done moving, whichever comes first.

Difficult Terrain.name: Difficult Terrain
Difficult Terrain.text:
Combatants are often slowed by &Reference[Difficult Terrain]. Furniture, rubble, undergrowth, steep stairs, snow, and shallow bogs are examples of Difficult Terrain.

Every foot of movement in Difficult Terrain costs 1 extra foot, even if multiple things in a space count as Difficult Terrain.

Breaking Up Your Move.name: Breaking Up Your Move
Breaking Up Your Move.text: You can break up your move, using some of its movement before and after any action, &Reference[Bonus Action], or &Reference[Reaction] you take on the same turn. For example, if you have a &Reference[Speed] of 30 feet, you could go 10 feet, take an action, and then go 20 feet.

Creature Size.name: Creature Size
Creature Size.text:
A creature belongs to a size category: Tiny, Small, Medium, Large, Huge, or Gargantuan. Your character’s size is specified on your Species sheet, and a monster’s size is specified on its sheet.

A creature’s size affects certain rules as well as the size of the creature’s token in this set (Medium and smaller creatures use the same token size).

Moving Around Other Creatures.name: Moving Around Other Creatures
Moving Around Other Creatures.text:
During your move, you can pass through the space of an ally, a creature that has the &Reference[Incapacitated] condition, a Tiny creature, or a creature that is two sizes larger or smaller than you.

Another creature’s space is &Reference[Difficult Terrain] for you unless that creature is Tiny or your ally.

You can’t willingly end a move in a space occupied by another creature. If you somehow end a turn in a space with another creature, you have the &Reference[Prone apply=false] condition unless you are Tiny or are of a larger size than the other creature.

Dropping Prone.name: Dropping Prone
Dropping Prone.text: On your turn, you can give yourself the &Reference[Prone apply=false] condition without using an action or any of your &Reference[Speed], but only if your Speed isn’t 0.

Making an Attack.name: Making an Attack
Making an Attack.text:
When you take the &Reference[Attack] action, you make an attack. Some other actions, &Reference[Bonus Action]{Bonus Actions}, and &Reference[Reaction]{Reactions} also let you make an attack. An attack has the following structure:

1: Choose a Target. Pick a target within your attack’s range.

2: Determine Modifiers. The DM determines whether the target has &Reference[Cover] and whether you have &Reference[Advantage] or &Reference[Disadvantage] against the target. In addition, spells, special abilities, and other effects can apply penalties or bonuses to your attack roll.

3: Resolve the Attack. Make the attack roll, as detailed earlier in the guide. On a hit, you roll damage unless the particular attack has rules that specify otherwise. Some attacks cause special effects in addition to or instead of damage.

Unseen Attackers and Targets

When you make an attack roll against a target you can’t see, you have Disadvantage on the roll. This is true whether you’re guessing the target’s location or targeting a creature you can hear but not see. If the target isn’t in the location you targeted, you miss.

When a creature can’t see you, you have Advantage on attack rolls against it.

If you’re hidden when you make an attack roll, you reveal your location when the attack hits or misses.

Ranged Attacks.name: Ranged Attacks
Ranged Attacks.text: When you make a ranged attack, you fire a bow or otherwise send projectiles to strike a target. Many spells also involve making a ranged attack.

Range.name: Range
Range.text:
You can make ranged attacks only against targets within a specified range. If a ranged attack, such as one made with a spell, has a single range, you can’t attack a target beyond this range.

Some ranged attacks, such as those made with a bow, have two ranges. The smaller number is the normal range, and the larger number is the long range. Your attack roll has &Reference[Disadvantage] when your target is beyond normal range, and you can’t attack a target beyond long range.

Ranged Attacks in Close Combat.name: Ranged Attacks in Close Combat
Ranged Attacks in Close Combat.text: Aiming a ranged attack is more difficult when a foe is next to you. When you make a ranged attack roll with a weapon, a spell, or some other means, you have &Reference[Disadvantage] on the roll if you are within 5 feet of an enemy who can see you and doesn’t have the &Reference[Incapacitated apply=false] condition.

Melee Attacks.name: Melee Attacks
Melee Attacks.text: A melee attack allows you to attack a target within your reach. A melee attack typically uses a handheld weapon or an Unarmed Strike. Many monsters make melee attacks with claws, teeth, or other body parts. A few spells also involve melee attacks.

Reach.name: Reach
Reach.text: A creature has a 5-foot reach and can thus attack targets within 5 feet when making a melee attack. Certain creatures have melee attacks with a reach greater than 5 feet, as noted on their sheets or features.

Opportunity Attacks.name: Opportunity Attacks
Opportunity Attacks.text:
Combatants watch for enemies to drop their guard. If you move heedlessly past your foes, you put yourself in danger by provoking an Opportunity Attack.

Avoiding Opportunity Attacks. You can avoid provoking an Opportunity Attack by taking the &Reference[Disengage] action. You also don’t provoke an Opportunity Attack when you teleport or when you are moved without using your movement, action, &Reference[Bonus Action], or &Reference[Reaction]. For example, you don’t provoke an Opportunity Attack if an explosion hurls you out of a foe’s reach or if you fall past an enemy.

Making an Opportunity Attack. You can make an Opportunity Attack when a creature that you can see leaves your reach. To make the attack, take a Reaction to make one melee attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike against that creature. The attack occurs right before it leaves your reach.

Damage and Healing.name: Damage and Healing
Damage and Healing.text: Injury and death are frequent threats in D&D, as detailed in the following rules.

Hit Points.name: Hit Points
Hit Points.text:
Hit Points represent durability and the will to live. Creatures with more Hit Points are more difficult to kill. Your Hit Point maximum is the number of Hit Points you have when uninjured. Your current Hit Points can be any number from that maximum down to 0, which is the lowest Hit Points can go.

Whenever you take damage, subtract it from your Hit Points. Hit Point loss has no effect on your capabilities until you reach 0 Hit Points.

Damage Rolls.name: Damage Rolls
Damage Rolls.text:
Each weapon, spell, and damaging monster ability specifies the damage it deals. You roll the damage dice, add any modifiers, and deal the damage to your target. If there’s a penalty to the damage, it’s possible to deal 0 damage but not negative damage.

When attacking with a weapon, you add your ability modifier—the same modifier used for the attack roll—to the damage roll. A spell tells you which dice to roll for damage and whether to add any modifiers. A weapon’s item sheet details its damage dice, as does a spell’s sheet if the spell deals damage.

Critical Hits.name: Critical Hits
Critical Hits.text: When you score a Critical Hit, you deal extra damage. Roll the attack’s damage dice twice, add them together, and add any relevant modifiers as normal. For example, if you score a Critical Hit with a Dagger, roll 2d4 for the damage rather than 1d4, and add your relevant ability modifier. If the attack involves other damage dice, such as from the Rogue’s Sneak Attack feature, you also roll those dice twice.

Saving Throws and Damage.name: Saving Throws and Damage
Saving Throws and Damage.text: Damage dealt via saving throws uses these rules.

Damage Against Multiple Targets.name: Damage Against Multiple Targets
Damage Against Multiple Targets.text: When you create a damaging effect that forces two or more targets to make saving throws against it at the same time, roll the damage once for all the targets. For example, when the Wizard casts Burning Hands, the spell’s damage is rolled once for all creatures caught in the blast.

Half Damage.name: Half Damage
Half Damage.text: Many saving throw effects deal half damage (round down) to a target when the target succeeds on the saving throw. The halved damage is equal to half the damage that would be dealt on a failed save.

Damage Types.name: Damage Types
Damage Types.text: Each instance of damage has a type, like Fire or Slashing. Damage types are listed in the rules glossary and have no rules of their own, but other rules, such as Resistance, rely on damage types.

Resistance and Vulnerability.name: Resistance and Vulnerability
Resistance and Vulnerability.text:
Some creatures and objects have Resistance or Vulnerability to certain types of damage. If you have Resistance to a damage type, damage of that type is halved against you (round down). If you have Vulnerability to a damage type, damage of that type is doubled against you. For example, if you have Resistance to Fire damage, such damage is halved against you, and if you have Vulnerability to Necrotic damage, such damage is doubled against you.

Modifiers to damage are applied in the following order: (1) adjustments such as bonuses, penalties, or multipliers; (2) Resistance; and (3) Vulnerability.

Immunity.name: Immunity
Immunity.text: Some creatures and objects have Immunity to certain damage types and conditions (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.Kwq3zMkqzCKcE5GL]{Conditions}). Immunity to a damage type means you don’t take damage of that type, and Immunity to a condition means you aren’t affected by it.

Healing.name: Healing
Healing.text:
Hit Points can be restored by magic, such as the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplCureWounds]{Cure Wounds} spell or a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.phbagPotionofHea]{Potion of Healing}, or by a &Reference[Short Rest]{Short} or &Reference[Long Rest].

When a creature receives healing, add the restored Hit Points to its current Hit Points. A creature’s Hit Points can’t exceed its Hit Point maximum; any Hit Points regained in excess of the maximum are lost. For example, if a character has 4 Hit Points, receives 8 Hit Points of healing, and has a Hit Point maximum of 10, the character regains 6 Hit Points, not 8.

A dead creature can’t be healed. When a character dies, the other characters might find a way to revive them, or the player can make a new character.

Dropping to 0 Hit Points.name: Dropping to 0 Hit Points
Dropping to 0 Hit Points.text:
When a creature drops to 0 Hit Points, it either dies outright or falls unconscious, as explained below.

Knocking Out a Creature

When you would reduce a creature to 0 Hit Points with a melee attack, you can instead reduce the creature to 1 Hit Point and give it the &Reference[Unconscious apply=false] condition. It then starts a &Reference[Short Rest], at the end of which that condition ends on it. The condition ends early if the creature regains any Hit Points or if someone takes an action to administer first aid to it, making a successful [[/skill 10 med]] check.

Instant Death.name: Instant Death
Instant Death.text:
A monster dies the instant it drops to 0 Hit Points.

When damage reduces a character to 0 Hit Points and damage remains, the character dies if the remainder equals or exceeds their Hit Point maximum. For example, if a character with a Hit Point maximum of 12 has 6 Hit Points and takes 18 damage, they are reduced to 0 Hit Points, but 12 damage remains. The character then dies, since 12 equals their Hit Point maximum.

Falling Unconscious.name: Falling Unconscious
Falling Unconscious.text: If you reach 0 Hit Points and don’t die instantly, you have the &Reference[Unconscious apply=false] condition until you regain any Hit Points, and you now face making @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.OqAvqz2u4UZsPOHJ]{Death Saving Throws}.

Death Saving Throws.name: Death Saving Throws
Death Saving Throws.text:
Whenever you start your turn with 0 Hit Points, you must make a Death Saving Throw to determine whether you creep closer to death or hang on to life. Unlike other saving throws, this one isn’t tied to an ability modifier. You’re in the hands of fate now.

Three Successes/Failures. Roll 1d20. If the roll is 10+, you succeed. Otherwise, you fail. A success or failure has no effect by itself. On your third success, you become Stable (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000.JournalEntryPage.3dorsCxJ1QHeyFiX]{Stabilizing a Character} below). On your third failure, you die.

The successes and failures needn’t be consecutive; keep track of both on the Combat Tracker until you collect three of a kind. Zero the number of both when you regain any Hit Points or become Stable.

Death Saving Throws

When you roll a Death Saving Throw it is automatically tracked on your character sheet.

Rolling a 1 or 20. When you roll a 1 on the d20 for a Death Saving Throw, you suffer two failures. If you roll a 20 on the d20, you regain 1 Hit Point.

Damage at 0 Hit Points. If you take any damage while you have 0 Hit Points, you suffer a Death Saving Throw f ailure. If the damage is from a Critical Hit, you suffer two failures instead. If the damage equals or exceeds your Hit Point maximum, you die.v

Stabilizing a Character.name: Stabilizing a Character
Stabilizing a Character.text:
You can take the &Reference[Help] action to try to stabilize a character with 0 Hit Points, which requires a successful [[/skill 10 med]] check.

A Stable creature doesn’t make Death Saving Throws even though it has 0 Hit Points, but it still has the &Reference[Unconscious apply=false] condition. If the creature takes damage, it stops being Stable and starts making Death Saving Throws again. A Stable creature that isn’t healed regains 1 Hit Point after [[/r 1d4]] hours.

Resting

Adventurers can’t spend every hour adventuring. They need rest. Any creature can take hour-long &Reference[Short Rest]{Short Rests} in the midst of a day and an 8-hour &Reference[Long Rest] to end it. Regaining Hit Points is one of the main benefits of a rest.

Conditions.name: Conditions
Conditions.text: Many effects impose a condition, a temporary state that alters a creature’s capabilities. Conditions—such as &Reference[Blinded apply=false], &Reference[Charmed apply=false], &Reference[Frightened apply=false], and &Reference[Prone apply=false]—are defined in the rules glossary. The definition specifies what happens to its recipient while affected by it.

Duration.name: Duration
Duration.text: A condition lasts either for a duration specified by the effect that imposed the condition or until the condition is countered (the &Reference[Prone apply=false] condition is countered by standing up, for example).

No Stacking.name: No Stacking
No Stacking.text: If multiple effects impose the same condition on you, each instance of the condition has its own duration, but the condition’s effects don’t get worse. Either you have a condition or you don’t. The &Reference[Exhaustion apply=false] condition is an exception to that rule.

Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
Spellcasting.text: This section provides the rules for casting spells. See @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSpells000000]{Spells} for descriptions of spells.

Casting Spells.name: Casting Spells
Casting Spells.text: Each spell description contains the details needed to cast the spell. The following sections explain each part of a Spell.

Spell Level.name: Spell Level
Spell Level.text: Every spell has a level, such as 0, 1, or 2. A spell’s level is an indicator of how powerful it is. Cantrips—simple spells that can be cast almost by rote—are level 0. The rules for each spellcasting class say when its members gain access to spells of certain levels.

Spell Slots.name: Spell Slots
Spell Slots.text:
Spellcasting is taxing, so a spellcaster can cast only a limited number of level 1+ spells before resting. Spell slots are the main way a spellcaster’s magical potential is represented. Each spellcasting class gives its members a limited number of spell slots of certain spell levels. For example, a level 3 Wizard has four level 1 spell slots and two level 2 slots.

In this module, you track spell slots using Spell Slots. When you cast a spell, you expend a slot of that spell’s level or higher, effectively “filling” a slot with the spell. Imagine a spell slot is a groove of a certain size—small for a level 1 slot, larger for a spell of higher level. A level 1 spell fits into a slot of any size, but a level 2 spell fits only in a slot that’s at least level 2. So when a level 3 Wizard casts Magic Missile, a level 1 spell, that Wizard spends one of four level 1 slots and has three remaining.

Finishing a &Reference[Long Rest] restores expended spell slots.

Casting Time.name: Casting Time
Casting Time.text: Most spells require the &Reference[Magic] action to cast, but some spells require a &Reference[Bonus Action], a &Reference[Reaction], or 1 minute or more. A spell’s Casting Time entry specifies which of those is required.

One Spell with a Spell Slot per Turn.name: One Spell with a Spell Slot per Turn
One Spell with a Spell Slot per Turn.text: On a turn, you can expend only one spell slot to cast a spell. This rule means you can’t, for example, cast a spell with a spell slot using the &Reference[Magic] action and another one using a &Reference[Bonus Action] on the same turn.

Reaction and Bonus Action Triggers.name: Reaction and Bonus Action Triggers
Reaction and Bonus Action Triggers.text: A spell that has a casting time of a &Reference[Reaction] is cast in response to a trigger that is defined in the spell’s Casting Time entry. Some spells that have a casting time of a &Reference[Bonus Action] are also cast in response to a trigger defined in the spell.

Longer Casting Times.name: Longer Casting Times
Longer Casting Times.text: Certain spells require more time to cast: minutes or even hours. While you cast a spell with a casting time of 1 minute or more, you must take the &Reference[Magic] action on each of your turns, and you must maintain &Reference[Concentration] while you do so. If your Concentration is broken, the spell fails, but you don’t expend a spell slot. To cast the spell again, you must start over.

Effects.name: Effects
Effects.text: The effects of a spell are detailed after its duration entry. Those details present exactly what the spell does, which ignores mundane physical laws. Whatever the effects, they typically deal with targets, saving throws, attack rolls, or all three, each of which is detailed below.

Targets.name: Targets
Targets.text:
A typical spell requires the caster to pick one or more targets to be affected by the spell’s magic. A spell’s description says whether the spell targets creatures, objects, or something else.

A Clear Path to the Target. To target something with a spell, a caster must have a clear path to it, so it can’t be behind &Reference[Total Cover].

Targeting Yourself. If a spell targets a creature of your choice, you can choose yourself unless the creature must be &Reference[Hostile] or a creature other than you.

Areas of Effect. Some spells, such as Thunderwave, cover an area called an &Reference[area of effect]. The area determines what the spell targets. The description of a spell specifies whether it has an area of effect, which is typically one of these shapes: Cone, Cube, Emanation, Line, or Sphere.

Awareness of Being Targeted. Unless a spell has a perceptible effect, a creature doesn’t know it was targeted by the spell. An effect like lightning is obvious, but a more subtle effect, such as an attempt to read thoughts, goes unnoticed unless a spell’s description says otherwise.

Invalid Targets. If you cast a spell on someone or something that can’t be affected by it, nothing happens to that target, but if you used a spell slot to cast the spell, the slot is still expended.

Saving Throws and Attack Rolls.name: Saving Throws and Attack Rolls
Saving Throws and Attack Rolls.text:
Many spells specify that a target makes a saving throw to avoid some or all of a spell’s effects. The spell specifies the ability that the target uses for the save and what happens on a success or failure. Some spells require the caster to make an attack roll to determine whether the spell hits a target.

A caster’s spell save DC and spell attack modifier are both listed on the character’s sheet.

Combining Spell Effects.name: Combining Spell Effects
Combining Spell Effects.text: The effects of different spells add together while their durations overlap. In contrast, the effects of the same spell cast multiple times don’t combine. Instead, the most potent effect—such as the highest bonus—from those castings applies while their durations overlap. The most recent effect applies if the castings are equally potent and their durations overlap. For example, if two creatures cast Bless on the same target, that target gains the spell’s benefit only once; the target doesn’t receive two bonus dice.

Combat and Damage Example.name: Combat and Damage Example
Combat and Damage Example.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.CfgEAjcUz9CK0RRj caption=false]

In this scene, threats force a group of adventurers into battle. The following example demonstrates the turn-based flow of combat.

In the Caves of Chaos, the characters enter combat!

Jared (as DM): This shadow-filled cave is quiet as the grave, and a chill wind blows around you.

Sam (as the Fighter): I try to see what’s ahead.

Jared Peering deeper into the cave, you can see bones littering the floor. The silence is broken suddenly by the rattle of bones as the skeletons lurch to their feet all around you and prepare to attack! 1

Sam: Ack! How many skeletons?

Jared: Ten in all, and they're hostile. Roll initiative! 2

Sam: Ten skeletons? Yikes! I got a 16.

Maeve (as the Wizard) I got 8.

Phillip (as the Cleric): An incredible 2 for Gareth.

Amy (as the Rogue): I got a 19!

Jared:The Rogue is quick to react—but not as quick as the skeletons! They got a 20. The first four attack the person in the lead: the Fighter. 3

Sam: Oh, boy.

Jared: Their attack roll totals are 8, 16, 18, and 20.

Sam: The 8 and 16 miss my AC, but the others hit.

Jared: Two of them stick you with their broken blades, dealing a total of 9 Piercing damage. 4

Sam: Is that the best you can do?

Phillip: Never say that to the DM.

Jared: Now two of them attack the Rogue. The first roll is a natural 1: a miss. The second roll is 16.

Amy: That hits.

Jared: You take 4 Piercing damage, and one of them attacks the Wizard with a roll of 14.

Maeve: Hits. No, wait! I cast Shield, so that misses. 5

Jared: The skeleton’s blade bounces off your shield of magical force. Then two of them attack the Cleric. One misses with a 5, but the other one lands a solid blow with a 21, dealing 7 piercing damage.

Phillip: That got my attention!

Jared: That’s nine attacks. There’s one more skeleton at the end of the hall. It moves up and waits for an opening. Now it’s the Rogue’s turn.

Amy: I attack one close to me. Does a 24 hit?

Jared: A solid hit!

Amy: And it’s next to one of my allies, right?

Jared: Yes.

Sam: So with my Sneak Attack, that’s 22 damage! 6

Jared: Your blade slides into an empty eye socket, and the skeleton clatters to the ground, now inanimate and harmless.

Amy: Then I use Cunning Action to Disengage as a Bonus Action and move 20 feet out of the melee. 6

Jared: Very good. Sam?

Sam: I drop my sword and pull out my warhammer. Time to break some bones! My first attack is a 21 to hit for 7 Bludgeoning damage. 7

Starting Combat. While describing the skeletons animating, the DM gets ready to start combat by mentally figuring out where everyone is, referring to the map of the area and the party’s established marching order. 1

Rolling Initiative. The next step in combat is for everyone involved to roll Initiative. 2

Taking Turns. Now each participant in the battle takes a turn in Initiative order. The skeletons go first because they got the highest Initiative: 20. 3

Attack Rolls. When a creature attacks, whether swinging a sword or firing an arrow from a bow, its player makes an attack roll. If the total is equal to or higher than the target’s Armor Class (AC), the attack hits. 4

Spells and Reactions. The Wizard casts the Shield spell. It’s a special property of this spell that it can be cast even when it’s not the caster’s turn, using her &Reference[Reaction]. 5

Special Abilities. The Rogue’s Sneak Attack lets her deal extra damage to the skeletons, and her Cunning Action lets her Disengage as a &Reference[Bonus Action]. These are examples of class features that let characters bend the rules. 6

Vulnerability. An attack that deals Bludgeoning damage is deadly to skeletons. The Fighter knows this from past experience, which is why he drops his sword and switches to a Bludgeoning weapon. He rolls only 7 damage, but the DM knows the skeleton actually takes 14 damage. 7

Difficulty Class.name: Difficulty Class
Difficulty Class.text:
The DC of an ability check represents the task’s difficulty. The more difficult the task, the higher its DC. The rules provide DCs for certain checks, but the DM ultimately sets them. The Typical Difficulty Classes table presents a range of possible DCs for ability checks. If the DC for a check is unspecified, use the table to determine an appropriate DC.

Skills.name: Skills
Skills.text:
A skill is an area of specialization associated with an ability check. Sometimes the DM might ask for an ability check using a specific skill or a choice of skills—for example, “Make a Wisdom (Insight) check” or “Make a Charisma (Deception or Persuasion) check.” At other times, a player might ask the DM if a particular skill applies to a check. In either case, creatures often have modifiers for certain skills that are higher than the ability modifier associated with that skill.

For example, if a character tries to climb a cliff, the DM might ask for a Strength (Athletics) check. The character makes a Strength check, but they apply the Athletics modifier listed on their character sheet rather than the Strength modifier. The modifier might be the same, or it might be higher.

A monster’s skill modifiers appear on its character sheet. If a monster doesn’t have a skill modifier listed, it uses its relevant ability modifier instead.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Dungeons & Dragons is a cooperative game in which players create exciting fantasy stories guided by a Dungeon Master, or DM. Imagination and chance determine the fate of the players’ characters.

This guide is designed to familiarize you with the contents of this module and help you quickly choose roles, make characters, and start playing. The three adventure journals gradually teach you rules as you play, while the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000]{Play Guide} contains the fundamentals of the game and a glossary of rules terms, making it an invaluable reference during play.

Rules Glossary

If you come across a game term you don't know, see the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule]{rules glossary} or hover over linked terms to get a quick explanation of the rules like: &Reference[difficult terrain].

An Ongoing Game.name: An Ongoing Game
An Ongoing Game.text: Each time you gather to play D&D, you’re playing a single game session. These sessions connect to form adventures like the one in this module. Between sessions all of your data is stored in Foundry VTT. The next time you play, the story picks up where you left off.

Choose Your Role.name: Choose Your Role
Choose Your Role.text:
To play D&D with this module, you need two to four people to play as characters and one person to be the Dungeon Master, or DM.

Playing a Character

If you want to be one of the protagonists in your group’s adventures, consider playing a character. Here’s what these players do:

Make a Character. Your character is your alter ego in the fantasy world of the game. Choose from four iconic options—the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.classes24.Item.phbclcCleric0000]{Cleric}, the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.classes24.Item.phbftrFighter000]{Fighter}, the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.classes24.Item.phbrgeRogue00000]{Rogue}, or the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.classes24.Item.phbwzdWizard0000]{Wizard}.

Team Up. Your character joins the other players’ characters to form an adventuring party. These adventurers are allies who face challenges and fantastical situations together. Each character has distinctive capabilities that complement those of the other characters.

Venture Forth. Your character’s group explores locations and events presented by the DM. You can respond to them however you can imagine, guided by the rules in this set. Although the DM controls all the monsters you encounter, the DM isn’t your adversary. The DM guides your party’s journey as your characters become more powerful.

Being the Dungeon Master

If you want to be the mastermind of the game, consider being the DM. Here’s what DMs do:

Run the Adventure. You run the adventure in this module.

Guide the Story. You narrate much of the action during play, describing locations and creatures that the adventurers face with read-aloud text. The players decide what their characters do as they navigate hazards and choose what to explore. Then you use a combination of imagination and the game’s rules to determine the results of the adventurers’ decisions.

Adjudicate the Rules. You oversee how the group uses the game’s rules, making sure the rules serve the group’s fun. Tutorials in the adventure booklets teach you some of those rules, but you’ll want to read the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbPlayGuide000]{Play Guide} to better understand them.

Swapping Roles

Playing a character and being the Dungeon Master aren’t permanent roles. This module makes trading places easy.

Whenever you begin play or whenever the Player Characters decide to leave one of the adventure’s three settings—the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos}, the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn]{Keep on the Borderlands}, or the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbWilderness00]{Wilderness}—determine who will be the DM for the upcoming section.

If your group consists of four or fewer players, the previous DM can either make a new character of a level equal to the other characters or play as the new DM’s now-available character. For groups of five, the previous DM always inherits the available character.

Getting Started.name: Getting Started
Getting Started.text:
Once you’ve chosen the DM, follow the instructions below to begin play.

If You’re a Character

Follow these steps to create your character:

1: Choose your Class. Pick one of the four level 1 pre-made Actors as your character’s Class: @UUID[Actor.hotbCleric000000]{Cleric (Level 1)}, @UUID[Actor.hotbFighterL1000]{Fighter (Level 1)}, @UUID[Actor.hotbRogueL100000]{Rogue (Level 1)}, @UUID[Actor.hotbWizardL10000]{Wizard (Level 1)} or create a new Actor and choose your Class from the options in the SRD.

Give Players Ownership of Their Character

When your player picks the Class they would like to play:

  1. Head to the  Actors tab, open the Heroes of the Borderlands folder, then the Pre-Made Actors folder.

  2. Right click on their choice and select Duplicate.

  3. Right click on the duplicated Actor and select  Configure Ownership.

  4. Grant their user account ownership of the Actor. They will then be able to see their character in the Actors tab and make changes to it.

  5. (Optional) Move their Actor to another folder. They will be able to rename their character.

2: Choose your Origin. Pick your @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBackgrounds0]{Background} and @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSpecies00000]{Species} . Together, these form your character’s Origin. Select a Player Character Token that corresponds with your chosen Species.

Choosing Your Origin

  1. Press the Add Species button on the main tab of the character sheet.

  2. In the left-hand side of the Compendium Browser filter to just the Heroes of the Borderlands option, choose from the standard SRD, or any other modules you have installed.

  3. Select your choice by checking the box to the right and pressing Select.

  4. Repeat for the Add Background button.

Choosing Your Portrait

  1. Put your sheet into Edit mode by pressing the toggle in the top-left of the sheet.

  2. Click on the Mystery Man icon under your character's name to choose a portrait.

  3. Navigate to your portrait image or upload one to Foundry. You can find a number of portrait options by going to modules/dnd-heroes-borderlands/assets/portraits.

  4. Put your sheet back into Play mode by pressing the toggle in the top-left of the sheet.

Choose Your Token

  1. Click on the kebab menu (three vertical dots) in the top-right corner of the sheet and select  Prototype Token.

  2. Change to the  Appearance tab.

  3. Click on the   button and navigate to your token image or upload one to Foundry. You can find a number of token options by going to modules/dnd-heroes-borderlands/assets/tokens.

  4. Press the  Update Token button at the bottom of the window.

3: Gather Character Components. Some Backgrounds and Species also list additional game components required for play.

Character Components

Each pre-made Actor's attributes, equipment, spells, etc. have already been added to their sheet. The Species and Backgrounds you choose automatically add the necessary content to their sheet when they are chosen.

4: Hit Points. Your Hit Point maximum is automatically configured and appears underneath your portrait.

5: Name Your Character. Choose a name for your character. The name can be whatever you like. When you’re ready, introduce your character to the other players and your DM.

Setting Your Character Name

  1. Put your sheet into Edit mode by pressing the toggle in the top-left of the sheet.

  2. Enter your character's name in the top-left of your character sheet.

  3. Click on the kebab menu (three vertical dots) in the top-right corner of the sheet and select  Prototype Token.

  4. Change the Token Name to match your character's name.

  5. Press the  Update Token button at the bottom of the window.

  6. Put your sheet back into Play mode by pressing the toggle in the top-left of the sheet.

If You’re the Dungeon Master

Follow these steps if you’re the DM:

1: Flip through the Play Guide. Familiarize yourself with the Play Guide and its organization. You don’t need to memorize every rule before you play, but you should understand the rhythm of play and where to find relevant information when needed.

2: Choose an Adventure Setting. Pick one of the three adventures and read its two-page introduction. If this is your first time playing D&D, the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbWilderness00]{Wilderness} Journal is a good place to start, followed by the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn]{Keep on the Borderlands}. Each Journal contains a tutorial location with sidebars that help you run the adventure.

3: Gather Adventure Components. The “What You Need to Play” sections throughout the adventure booklet link you directly to the Scenes, Actors, and Journals you need to play.

Finally, place the dice where everyone can reach them. Now you’re ready to play D&D!

The Adventure.name: The Adventure
The Adventure.text:
The adventure in this module is for two to four characters of levels 1–3. The adventure has no overarching plot. While there are conflicts and secrets to uncover, the story that emerges is the one your group experiences.

The adventure is divided into three self-contained booklets, each of which features a different area. You don’t need to read one booklet to understand the others, and you can play and revisit them in any order. The adventure areas are as follows:

The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos} tempt adventurers with riches and glory, obtainable by any who dare brave these monster-filled caverns.

The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn]{Keep on the Borderlands} is a fortified settlement where the party can rest, purchase goods and services, and interact with locals.

The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbWilderness00]{Wilderness} lies beyond the ken of law. Friends, foes, and surprises await explorers who traverse these untamed wilds.

Over the course of the adventure, the characters might visit these areas more than once. They don’t have to complete all the encounters in an adventure journal before exploring a different corner of the Borderlands.

Keep It Secret

Secrets and reveals are important DM tools. If you read any of the DM-only material and still want to experience the adventure as a player, you can—just don’t let this knowledge influence your character’s actions or behavior. More importantly, don’t spoil any surprises for your fellow players!
