Andrella.name: Andrella
Andrella.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.IIhDzyyt69579Inp caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbAndrella0000]{Andrella}

Human Captain of the Guard

This captain is strong, stern, and just.

Perfect Posture. Andrella is as strict with her posture as she is with the law.

Role Model. Many of the keep’s young people admire Andrella and enjoy her goodhearted mentorship.

Rumors

“A dastardly bandit, Pral, accosts travelers along the trail. Apparently he’s quite handsome; I’m sure he’ll look even better behind bars.” (True)

“The castellan tells me monsters are drawn to the Caves of Chaos in droves. I wonder why.” (True)

Bartho.name: Bartho
Bartho.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.77W5x4kFgTpDB0CZ caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbBartho000000]{Bartho}

Human Gate Guard

This gullible recruit spends more time dreaming than patrolling.

Distractable. Bartho is easily distracted from his post because he’d rather be doing anything else.

Sleepy. Bartho likes to catch a few winks during the night shift.

Rumors

“If you can’t afford a bed at the inn, Cornflower will let you sleep in the barn. The hay’s real comfy.” (True)

“Minotaurs aren’t real. They’re just a myth told to scare little children from wandering into caves.” (False)

Cornflower.name: Cornflower
Cornflower.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.vJoRnCEcsA3SRrHM caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbCornflower00]{Cornflower}

Halfling Barn Hand

This spunky stable hand isn’t afraid to get her hands dirty.

Animal Lover. Cornflower’s best friends are all barn animals.

Idiomatic. Cornflower likes to use animal idioms, such as “busy bee,” “chicken out,” and “hold your horses.”

Rumors

“Did you know animals have all sorts of special glands? Giant fire beetles are like big glowing cave lanterns! Isn’t nature amazing?” (True)

“Careful if you go trekking into the wilderness. The tamaracks are overrun with giant spiders.” (True)

Dwern.name: Dwern
Dwern.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.vpaiuOwQyN52gXQo caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbDwern0000000]{Dwern}

Dwarf Scribe

This gruff scribe prefers the company of books over people.

Bookworm. Dwern has read more books than anyone else in the keep.

Curmudgeonly. Dwern is ill-tempered toward younger people—which, to him, are most people.

Rumors

“The guild house’s library boasts a modest but impressive collection of books on history and magic.” (True)

“There’s an ancient statue somewhere in the forests north of the keep. It was once the site of strange rituals. Some say it still is.” (True)

Elandra.name: Elandra
Elandra.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.XiQhoH6verFXNJRZ caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbElandra00000]{Elandra}

Elf Adviser

Elandra provides guidance to the castellan and citizens of the keep.

Cautious. When presented with a choice, Elandra typically prefers the option with the least amount of risk.

Complainer. Nothing is ever good enough for Elandra.

Rumors

“Every night, the tavern hosts a rowdy little drinking game with prizes. It’s not for me.” (True)

“Kalista, the keep’s blacksmith, doesn’t sell weapons to adventurers. If you want to know why, ask her.” (True)

Fazzir.name: Fazzir
Fazzir.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.AgXkGN9VdcYEkobx caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbFazzir000000]{Fazzir}

Human Priest

This spiritual leader offers counsel and healing to all who seek the temple.

Altruistic. Fazzir puts the needs of others before his own.

Trusting. Fazzir always assumes the best of people.

Rumors

“The keep’s former priest, Ivlis, left a large collection of books on all matter of subjects—even occult rituals.” (True)

“Anyone entering the inner bailey is bound to cross paths with Shannik, sergeant of the guard. I think he’s a little too hard on new recruits.” (True)

Gala.name: Gala
Gala.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.zyXJgTD6m1aoSF7i caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbGala00000000]{Gala}

Human Gate Guard

Though she’s memorized all the keep’s laws, this guard still has much to learn.

By the Books. Gala clings to the keep’s laws—and often recites them aloud—whenever she must make a decision.

Naive. Gala believes that life is fair, people mostly tell the truth, and good always prevails.

Rumors

“I’ve heard the captain of the guard, @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.a1gOVKXrvzfgImZ9]{Andrella}, plans to retire soon.” (False)

“The keep’s coat of arms honors its cavalry, thirty riders strong. I hope to become one.” (True)

Haldryck.name: Haldryck
Haldryck.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.iIi1lD49eeYn6WtG caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbHaldryck0000]{Haldryck}

Dwarf Innkeeper

Jovial and accommodating, Haldryck is a fast friend to anyone who visits his inn.

Epicurean. Good food and drink are the keys to Haldryck’s heart.

Overseller. Haldryck advertises his inn’s basic necessities—like clean sheets and doors with locks—as luxury amenities.

Rumors

“The food at the tavern is the best in the Borderlands!” (Doubtful)

“My inn is the only place visitors to the keep can stay overnight.” (False)

Kalista.name: Kalista
Kalista.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.S0pe3tkg2MUke8xd caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbKalista00000]{Kalista}

Dwarf Blacksmith

The keep’s taciturn, hardworking smith prefers to let her hammer do the talking.

Standoffish. Kalista is curt toward people she doesn’t know, especially adventurers.

Stern. Kalista never cracks a smile.

Rumors

“Every now and then, adventurers return from the Caves of Chaos with magic weapons, but most of the time they don’t come back at all.” (True)

“Mind your equipment around oozes. Their touch can corrode even the sturdiest of metals.” (True)

Lenk.name: Lenk
Lenk.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.QVHdjpOzl8sZEOGp caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbLenk00000000]{Lenk}

Human Jeweler

This elderly jeweler can identify and appraise any gemstone.

Faultfinder. Lenk has a knack for spotting flaws, be they in things or people.

Pessimistic. Lenk always sees the worst part of any situation.

Rumors

“Your money isn’t safe at the bank. I hear a burglar broke in recently and stole every last coin.” (Partially true; the burglar was unsuccessful)

“Some stones hide things. The next time you’re in an ancient dungeon or old cave, inspect the walls closely. You just might find a secret door.” (True)

Mallyn.name: Mallyn
Mallyn.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.c1u6Pa3pifl8fayf caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbMallyn000000]{Mallyn}

Human Traveler

This young wayfarer’s heart is filled with wanderlust.

Easy Come, Easy Go. Mallyn doesn’t get attached to possessions or acquaintances.

Inquisitive. Mallyn eagerly asks strangers lots of questions.

Rumors

“Don’t wander into the fens unless you’re looking for trouble. The lizardfolk there don’t like visitors.” (True)

“My uncle Umbrusk runs the tavern in the keep. He hears all kinds of gossip in the taproom.” (True)

Oleira.name: Oleira
Oleira.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.6aNQoD30dHMuthfC caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbOleira000000]{Oleira}

Human Shopkeeper

This merchant and mother of two deals in wares ranging from common trade goods to curious bric-a-brac.

Fastidious. Oleira can’t stand dusty wares. Every item must be spotless.

Parental. Oleira sometimes treats her customers like she does her children.

Rumors

“A hermit, Xanthe, was cast out of the keep for practicing evil magic. I hear she was in a cult. Think of the children!” (False)

“The keep’s two outer gate guards, Bartho and Gala, are both so green. I’m not sure which of them I trust less to protect us.” (True)

Quink.name: Quink
Quink.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.sor3xRKJIyCjEZyQ caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbQuink0000000]{Quink}

Halfling Baker

Quink is a miserly moneylender.

Frugal. Quink never budges on matters of money.

Garrulous. Conversations with Quink last twice as long as they should.

Rumors

“Good supplies are a sound investment. Ruckus at the provisioner’s shop can outfit you with quality gear.” (True)

“I’ve heard dragons are a bit like bankers—we obsess over every coin. If you ever encounter a dragon, don’t touch its hoard unless you want to meet its wrath.” (True)

Ruckus.name: Ruckus
Ruckus.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.8hTSwoa4PtqEn7Xg caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbRuckus000000]{Ruckus}

Halfling Shopkeeper

The owner of the provisioner’s shop is small but has a big personality.

Loud. Ruckus compensates for his short stature by shouting up to taller customers.

Everything Has a Place. Despite the mess in his shop, Ruckus always knows exactly where to find just what he’s looking for.

Rumors

“I hear goblins throw wild parties.” (Oh Yeah!)

“@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.0SpEYRLrHK7pKQ87]{Lenk} the jeweler gives a fair price for gems and precious stones. He lives in the private apartments.” (True)

Shannik.name: Shannik
Shannik.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.YMh7zqh58U9zdCmW caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbShannik00000]{Shannik}

Human Sergeant of the Guard

Captain Andrella’s second in command brooks no evildoers.

Brusque. When Shannik can substitute a reply with a grunt, he does so.

Shortsighted. Shannik’s plans and actions fail to account for long-term repercussions.

Rumors

“An adventurer is only as good as their gear. Oleira at the trader’s shop is a friend of mine. She can sell you armor and weapons.” (True)

“A real soldier can sleep off any injury. After a battle, I usually rent a bed at the inn. I always sleep better there.” (True)

Toryn.name: Toryn
Toryn.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.bGP7P5R5Cs6YHsu9 caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbToryn0000000]{Toryn}

Human Guild Master

This guild master helps fellow artisans get a good deal for their wares and services.

Judgmental. Toryn looks down on artisans who refuse to join the guild.

Witty. Toryn says smart things and always has the last word.

Rumors

“Castellan Winvarle is the ultimate authority in the keep.” (True)

“The Borderlands are home to all sorts of trades: musicians, mercenaries, treasure-seekers, spies even monsters can have a profession. My advice? Pay them what they ask.” (True)

Umbrusk.name: Umbrusk
Umbrusk.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.27ztRbQzwT0svaFm caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbUmbrusk00000]{Umbrusk}

Human Barkeep

Umbrusk serves up drinks, food, and gossip at the keep’s tavern.

Eavesdropper. Umbrusk listens to his patrons’ conversations.

Good Memory. Umbrusk never forgets a face or name.

Rumors

“A traveler named Mallyn walks the trails outside the keep. If you meet her, say hello for me! She’s my niece.” (True)

“Whenever I order a cake, it gets seized by goblins, roadside bandits—you name it. I guess everybody likes dessert.” (True)

Winvarle.name: Winvarle
Winvarle.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.nwtfm4IpPaW1XZlq caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbWinvarle0000]{Winvarle}

Human Castellan

The keep’s noble commander leads his soldiers whenever the keep comes under attack.

Idealistic. Winvarle’s ideals are rooted in lofty notions of righteousness.

Oblivious. While he excels at battle strategy, Winvarle scarcely knows the inner workings of his own keep.

Rumors

“The Cult of Chaos is an affront to all that is good.” (True)

“Anyone can pledge to defend the keep. Talk to Andrella in the inner gatehouse if you’d like to join the keep’s defenders.” (True)

Xanthe.name: Xanthe
Xanthe.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.DL74QYd8WgX21TVz caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbXanthe000000]{Xanthe}

Elf Hermit

One of the Borderlands’ oldest and wisest residents was banished from the keep for crimes she didn’t commit.

Bad Reputation. Xanthe was wrongfully exiled for using occult magic.

Distrustful. Xanthe doesn’t trust strangers.

Rumors

“A spy named Jacko prowls the fens. Be wary if you meet him. He’ll do anything for coin—even kill.” (True)

“The temple’s head priest is a demon worshiper.” (Partially true; Xanthe is referring to Ivlis, the former priest)

Yvette.name: Yvette
Yvette.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.rmKQidDVmrBmSckW caption=false classes="right three"]

@UUID[Actor.hotbYvette000000]{Yvette}

Human Bank Guard

This corrupt guard exploits her station for selfish ends.

Bitter. Yvette thinks the world owes her.

Grifter. Yvette is always hunting for new ways to get rich quick.

Rumors

“There’s an alms box at the temple that usually contains a few gold pieces. I hear Fazzir doesn’t even lock it.” (True)

“If you find yourself face to face with an owlbear, just play dead. It will quickly get bored and move on.” (False)

Combat.name: Combat
Combat.text:
On your turn in combat, you can move up to your Speed and take one action.

Move up to Your Speed. You can move a distance equal to your Speed or less, or you can decide not to move. You can break up your move, using some of it before or after any action, Bonus Action, or Reaction. Your movement can include climbing, crawling, and jumping (each is explained in the Play Guide).

Take One Action. The main actions you can take are on the other side of this card. Many class features and other abilities provide additional action options you can take instead. If you can’t decide what to do, consider taking the Dodge action.

You might also do any of the following:

Communicate. You can communicate with brief utterances or gestures as you take your turn. Extended communication requires an action; the Influence action is the main way you try to influence a monster.

Interact with Things. You can interact with one object or feature of the environment, such as opening a door, for free during either your move or action. Some magic items and other special objects require an action to use.

Take One Bonus Action. Various class features, spells, and other abilities let you take an additional action on your turn called a Bonus Action. You otherwise don’t have a Bonus Action to take.

Actions.name: Actions
Actions.text:
When you do something other than moving or communicating, you typically take an action. These are D&D’s main actions (defined in the Play Guide):

Attack. Attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike.

Dash. For the rest of your turn, give yourself extra movement equal to your Speed.

Disengage. Your movement doesn’t provoke Opportunity Attacks for the rest of the turn.

Dodge. Until the start of your next turn, attack rolls against you have Disadvantage, and you make Dexterity saving throws with Advantage. You lose this benefit if you have the Incapacitated condition or if your Speed is 0.

Help. Help another creature’s ability check or attack roll.

Hide. Make a Dexterity (Stealth) check.

Influence. Make a Charisma (Deception, Intimidation, Persuasion, or Performance) or Wisdom (Animal Handling) check to alter a creature’s attitude.

Magic. Cast a spell, use a magic item, or use a magical feature.

Ready. Prepare to take an action in response to a trigger you define.

Search. Make a Wisdom (Insight, Medicine, Perception, or Survival) check.

Study. Make an Intelligence (Arcana, History, Investigation, Nature, or Religion) check.

Utilize. Use a nonmagical object.

Getting Started.name: Getting Started
Getting Started.text:
WHAT YOU NEED TO PLAY

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.58Rby9tGVEPdTIDG]{Caves of Chaos}

Beyond the Keep on the Borderlands hide the Caves of Chaos, a network of monster-infested caves where by a wicked cult lurks. Danger awaits foolhardy adventurers who enter the caves—but so do treasure and glory.

DM Secret! This book is for the Dungeon Master’s eyes only. Unless text appears in a read-aloud box (like the one below), don’t read it to the players.

Getting Started

Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos} Scene for the players to see. This player-focused map doesn’t reveal the caves’ contents or names, only the cave mouths and their respective elevations.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

You pass through a dense forest of gnarled trees with grasping roots, the woods twisting as if to ward you off. Undeterred, you emerge from the tangled thicket into a stark ravine. Its rocky walls rise steeply one hundred feet or so above. Several dark cave mouths pockmark the walls at varying heights. The air is stale and quiet.

Among the rocks and dead wood that litter the ravine’s floor are the bones of animals and explorers, picked clean by scavengers. Vultures leer at you hungrily from barren branches.
Where do you want to go?

The Caves of Chaos table summarizes the caves in the order they appear within this adventure. Each cave provides approximately 60–90 minutes of gameplay. The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.58Rby9tGVEPdTIDG]{DM version of the map} includes the suggested minimum level for each cave; for example, the characters should be level 2 or higher before entering @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa]{cave F}.

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAKoboldLair0]{Cave A} functions as a tutorial with helpful sidebars. If this is your first time as the DM, encourage the players to start there. Otherwise, have them choose a cave shown on the map.

Once the player characters choose a cave, open that caves journal entry.

Exploring the Caves.name: Exploring the Caves
Exploring the Caves.text:
As the characters explore a cave, the players move their Player Character Tokens through its areas, as depicted on the cave’s Scene.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.58Rby9tGVEPdTIDG caption=false]

Cave Descriptions

Each description of a cave has these sections:

Getting Started. This section provides setup instructions for the DM and introduces the cave with thematic read-aloud text.

Features. Important features about the cave, such as its lighting, appear here.

Locations. This section details the cave’s areas and its contents, including any monsters.

DM’s Map of the Cave. This shrunk-down map displays the locations of monsters, traps, and treasure within the cave.

Rhythm of Play

When the characters enter an area for the first time, do the following:

Step 1: Describe the Area. Describe what the characters perceive in the area. Focus on what they see, hear, or smell.

Step 2: Manage Tokens. As the characters explore the Scene most creatures will be automatically revealed. Some are hidden until a specific event is triggered and as the DM you can choose to add or remove creatures as you see fit to make the game harder or easier.

Step 3: Ask the Players, “What Do You Do?” Players tell you what their characters do or say.

Step 4: Narrate the Results. The player characters reap the consequences of their actions as outlined in the text. This might involve one or more &Reference[D20 Test]{D20 Test} to determine the outcome. It could also lead to combat (see below).

Step 5: Repeat. When the player characters reach another area of the cave, repeat this procedure.

Combat

Though it’s possible to avoid combat with many of the caves’ occupants, the characters eventually will clash with creatures that can’t be reasoned with. The text states when a monster might start combat. When a fight breaks out, see the “@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbCombat0000000]{Combat}” section in the Play Guide.

Resting

Threats abound within the caves. The characters can take only &Reference[Short Rest]{Short Rests} within them. To take a &Reference[Long Rest], they must first exit any cave they’re in. For more on resting, see the Play Guide.

Leaving the Caves

The characters can leave the Caves of Chaos any time they choose, provided they aren’t inside a cave or engaged in combat. If they return to a cave later, it is as they left it.

Character Advancement

In this adventure booklet, the characters can gain levels by completing caves. To complete a cave, the characters must explore every area within it.

The characters gain levels by achieving the following milestones:

Completing Two Caves. After the characters fully explore two caves, they advance to level 2.

Completing Three More Caves. After the characters fully explore a total of five caves, they advance to level 3.

Each of these level advancements occurs only once. If the characters are already level 3, they don’t gain levels by exploring the caves.

A: Kobold Lair.name: A: Kobold Lair
A: Kobold Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.RNQochyYiuQD5fSE caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveAKoboldL]{Cave A}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.RNQochyYiuQD5fSE]{Cave A: Kobold Lair}

1

A band of kobolds recently stole a dragon egg and brought it to these caves to eat. But when the egg hatched and a screeching dragon wyrmling emerged, the kobolds quickly realized they bit off more than they could chew.2

The kobolds tried to appease the fussy wyrmling with treasure, but they can’t agree on what to do next. Should they return the wyrmling to its nest, or should they raise it themselves?

You can add monsters, such as @UUID[Actor.mmGiantFireBeetl]{Giant Fire Beetles}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can reduce the number of @UUID[Actor.mmKoboldWarrior0]{Kobold Warriors} to make it easier and shorter.3

Getting Started

Lay out this cave’s poster map for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

A tunnel made of hard-packed earth leads into darkness. The cave echoes with high-pitched bickering overtopped by a loud, bestial squeal.4

The sounds come from the quarreling kobolds in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAKoboldLair0.JournalEntryPage.8g7EokmF8gdA8p9d]{area A4} and the crying wyrmling in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAKoboldLair0.JournalEntryPage.9Gpzfiz11Qa6l8Kp]{area A5}.

Kobold Lair Features

5

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 10 feet high.

Environment. The cave has rough stone walls and a dirt floor. The floor is littered with gnawed animal bones and junk collected by the kobolds.

Lighting. The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on Darkvision or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Kobold Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to map A. The map also shows you where to place tokens.

DM Tips. This tutorial is designed for first-time Dungeon Masters. Sidebars like this one explain how to use the text and give examples of how an adventure in this cave might play out.

What You Need to Play. Review the items listed here before you begin play.

1

Summary. The beginning of each cave presents its central conflict, as well as optional ways to increase or decrease the difficulty. If the characters are level 1, don’t increase the difficulty.

2

Bold Terms. When a game component’s name appears in Bold type, that’s a visual cue to say, “Hey, DM, this is going to be important soon.”

3

Boxed Text. Text that appears in a box like the one to the left is meant to be read aloud or paraphrased for the players when their characters first arrive at a location or under a specific circumstance, as described in the text.

4

Features. This section presents special features about the location. Some of these exist to help you set the mood—you might describe the crunch of animal bones under the characters’ feet—while others detail important rules, such as secret doors and how to find them.

5

Exploration and Movement. Exploration is open-ended; the players don’t take turns moving around the dungeon the way they do in combat. As they explore, direct the players to freely move their Player Character Tokens on the Scene, but stop them when they reach the entrance (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAKoboldLair0.JournalEntryPage.uV5xsLYRhZU8LN2S]{area A1}).

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
Pit Trap

When a character detects or triggers the trap, run the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.macros.Macro.hotbCaveAPitTile]{Toggle Pit Tile} Macro to reveal its location. Rules for detecting and escaping the trap are as follows:

Detecting the Trap. The pit is poorly camouflaged. A character who examines the trapped area easily discovers the pit. Once detected, the pit can be safely avoided by sidling along its perimeter.

Escaping the Pit. The pit’s walls have cracks big enough to serve as handholds, allowing trapped creatures to climb out easily.

A character falling into the pit alerts the kobold in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAKoboldLair0.JournalEntryPage.r6fsgGYwftbuOl3X]{area A2}, who approaches the pit and crows, “Got ’em!” The encounter in that area then occurs here.

A twenty-foot-long tunnel leads into the cave.

This tunnel contains a hidden pit trap

Pit Trap. This 10-foot-deep pit is covered by a large, dirty cloth. When a character steps on the cloth, it gives way, dumping the character into the pit, at which point the pit is no longer hidden. A creature that falls into the pit takes [[/damage 1d6 bludgeoning]] damage.

Rhythm of Play. Here’s an example of how the pit trap in area A1 might play out:

1: Describe the Scene. Read the boxed text aloud.

2: Place Tokens. All Monster Tokens and hidden Tiles are already placed. You only need to place the Player Character Tokens.

3: Ask the Players, “What Do You Do?” You might ask how the player characters enter the cave. If they charge brashly ahead, the character in the lead falls into the pit. However, if a player says their character looks carefully, they spot the trap.

4: Narrate the Results. Once the pit’s presence becomes known, use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.macros.Macro.hotbCaveAPitTile]{Toggle Pit Tile} Macro to reveal the trap and describe the pit and the narrow ledge around it.

Once the players know the pit is there, ask them how their characters bypass it. If they come up with a creative solution not described in the text, err on the side of leniency and fun. Whenever you think a rule might be necessary, see the Play Guide.

Repeat this process for the other areas in this cave, modifying it based on their contents.

Guard Nook.name: Guard Nook
Guard Nook.text:
A small, bipedal reptile stands guard in this nook.

A @UUID[Actor.mmKoboldWarrior0]{Kobold Warrior} keeps watch in this nook. The guard is initially Indifferent toward intruders, but it’s also naive. Rather than alerting the other kobolds when it spots the characters, it marches toward them and asks what they want.6/7

As an Influence action, a character can try to appease the kobold and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 10 deception]]. The character tricks the kobold with an outlandish lie.8

[[/skill 10 performance]]. The character amuses the kobold with a jaunty tune.8

[[/skill 10 persuasion]]. The character convinces the kobold the party means it no harm.8

On a successful check, the character improves the kobold’s attitude to Friendly, and the kobold grants them entry, warning them cryptically about the “many-legs” to the west (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAKoboldLair0.JournalEntryPage.sWmgnxPrrcjDZFUt]{area A3}). On a failed check, the kobold becomes Hostile and flees toward area A4, yelping a call to arms.

Monsters. Whenever a Monster appears in the text, show the character art to the players. The Kobold Warrior artwork helps players (and you) visualize this guard and other kobolds throughout this cave.

6

Attitudes. Every creature has a starting attitude toward the characters: Friendly, Hostile, or Indifferent (see the Play Guide). Regardless, creatures defend themselves in combat.

7

Ability Checks. When the outcome of an action is uncertain, the game uses a d20 roll to determine success or failure. This is called a &Reference[D20 Test]. An ability check is one type of D20 Test. Here’s how to run the ability check in area A2:

1: Describe the Scene. Paint a mental picture of the kobold either by describing its words and actions or by actively roleplaying it—giving it a voice like an actor in a role.

2: Ask the Players, “What Do You Do?” If the players aren’t sure what to do, suggest ways they could respond to the kobold, like trying to deceive or persuade it.

3: Narrate the Results. The Difficulty Class (DC) for each listed ability check is 10. If the total of the d20 and its modifiers equals or exceeds 10, the check succeeds. On a 9 or lower, it fails. In either case, the area’s description tells you what happens.

Example. A Rogue tries to deceive the kobold with a Charisma (Deception) check. The player rolls a d20 and adds their character’s Deception modifier (+4) for a total of 14. The check succeeds—the kobold believes the lie!

8

Centipedes’ Den.name: Centipedes’ Den
Centipedes’ Den.text:
This cave contains heaps of waste. Two giant centipedes skitter about, picking at the refuse.

Two @UUID[Actor.mmGiantCentipede]{Giant Centipedes} scavenge this cave. The centipedes are Hostile toward all other creatures and fight anyone who enters their den.

The kobolds are afraid of the centipedes—a fact they report to any who mention the beasts. If the characters slay the centipedes and show proof to a kobold, this deed earns the kobold’s respect, improving its attitude toward them to Friendly.

9

Combat. Though the characters can avoid combat elsewhere, the centipedes in area A3 fight them on sight. Here’s how that might play out:

1: Describe the Scene. Read the boxed text aloud. Then say, “Roll Initiative!” to signal the start of combat. When you've initiated combat you can roll once for both centipedes, which act on the same turn.

2: Players React. In combat, the characters and the centipedes act on their turns.

Use Foundry's Combat Tracker and the “Combat” section in the Play Guide to run this encounter.

9

Common Area.name: Common Area
Common Area.text:
This common area contains straw beds and a pile of junk. Five small, bipedal reptiles pace about the cave, arguing loudly.

Five @UUID[Actor.mmKoboldWarrior0]{Kobold Warriors} are trying to decide whether to keep the wyrmling or return it to its nest. They cease bickering when they notice the characters. The kobolds’ initial attitude is Indifferent. If they learn the characters eliminated the guard in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAKoboldLair0.JournalEntryPage.r6fsgGYwftbuOl3X]{area A2}, these kobolds are Hostile.

Treasure. Stashed in the junk pile are [[/award 25GP]] and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Items Table} to determine the item.10

Treasure. Treasure entries like this describe loot in an area. Usually, treasure consists of Gold Pieces (GP), magic items, or both.

Whenever a player character finds gold, give that player Gold Pieces equal to the listed value (you can use the Award buttons throughout the journal entries to give gold to the party, an individual player, or each person in the Party). For magic items, draw a result from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} and give the item to the player.

Share the Wealth. Encourage players to split treasure among the characters as evenly as possible. This is especially important for magic items, which are seldom awarded.

Spending Gold Pieces. Opportunities to spend gold in the Caves of Chaos are rare, but the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn]{Keep on the Borderlands} contains plenty of goods and services available for purchase.

10

Larder.name: Larder
Larder.text:
The stone door to this room is ajar. A persistent, ear-splitting cry emanates within. When the characters enter, read the following text aloud:

This chamber contains barrels and sacks of dried and salted meats, grains, and vegetables. A dragon wyrmling with copper scales sits on a scant pile of coins and eggshell fragments in the corner of the room, shrieking endlessly.
Two small, bipedal reptiles with worried expressions deposit handfuls of coins and junk at the creature’s feet.

Two @UUID[Actor.mmKoboldWarrior0]{Kobold Warriors} attempt to comfort the crying @UUID[Actor.mmCopperDragonWy]{Copper Dragon Wyrmling} by adding treasure to its meager hoard. It isn’t going well. The kobolds and the wyrmling are Indifferent toward all other creatures.

Soothing the Wyrmling. The wyrmling knows the kobolds aren’t its parents, but it doesn’t know where its nest is. The wyrmling doesn’t yet have a name, which only compounds its misery.

As an Influence action, a character can try to calm the wyrmling and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 10 deception]]. The character mollifies the wyrmling with a promise they don’t intend to keep.

[[/skill 10 persuasion]]. The character assures the wyrmling they’re here to help.

[[/skill 10 performance]]. The character soothes the wyrmling with a gentle lullaby.

A character who offers the wyrmling at least 10 GP has Advantage on this check. On a successful check, the wyrmling stops wailing, and its attitude improves to Friendly, as do the attitudes of all kobolds in the cave. The wyrmling then asks the characters whether it should stay with the kobolds or return home. The kobolds honor the wyrmling’s choice, which corresponds with the characters’ recommendation.11

On a failed check, or if the characters try to steal from its meager hoard, the wyrmling fights. The cowardly kobolds abstain from battle. If the wyrmling defeats all the characters, they wake up 1 hour later outside the cave with 1 Hit Point each.

Treasure. The wyrmling’s hoard consists of [[/award 25GP]] and one magic item; draw a result from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Items Table} to determine the item.

Advantage/Disadvantage. Sometimes a &Reference[D20 Test] is modified by special situations called &Reference[Advantage] and &Reference[Disadvantage], which reflect positive and negative circumstances, respectively. See the Play Guide for more on Advantage and Disadvantage.

In area A5, if a character gives the dragon wyrmling at least 10 GP, that character has Advantage on an ability check to influence it.

Roll Two D20s. When a roll has either Advantage or Disadvantage, roll a second d20 when you make the roll. Use the higher of the two rolls if you have Advantage, and use the lower roll if you have Disadvantage.

Example. A Cleric gives the wyrmling 10 GP and then hums a tune to soothe it. The Cleric takes the Influence action and makes a Charisma (Performance) check with Advantage. The player rolls two d20s: 15 and 6. The player uses the higher roll and adds the Cleric’s Performance modifier (+2) for a total of 17, which exceeds the DC of 10, and the check succeeds. If the check had been made with Disadvantage instead, the total of 8 would’ve failed.

11

Saving Throws. The wyrmling’s Acid Breath action (see the wyrmling’s @UUID[Actor.mmCopperDragonWy]{Actor}) prompts another type of D20 Test: a &Reference[saving throw]. Saving throws—also called saves—are named for the ability modifiers they use; in this case, characters use Dexterity to dodge an exhalation of acid. If a character is targeted by this effect, the player rolls a d20 and adds the character’s Dexterity save modifier. A save’s result is detailed in the effect that caused it.

B: Mephit Lair.name: B: Mephit Lair
B: Mephit Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.gpusJpvBSkMjolX8 caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveBMephitL]

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.gpusJpvBSkMjolX8]

Sturdy fortifications and clean water make this abandoned subterranean outpost an appealing den for thieves and monsters. Before the prior inhabitants left, they stored some enticing treasure here, guarded by a monstrous shape-shifter called a mimic. Since then, a trio of impish elementals and kuo-toa fanatics have made the cave their home.

You can add monsters, such as @UUID[Actor.mmGiantCentipede]{Giant Centipedes}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can remove the @UUID[Actor.hotbKuotoaMaraud]{Kuo-Toa Marauders} or one of the @UUID[Actor.mmSteamMephit000]{Steam Mephits} to make it easier and shorter.

Getting Started

Activate the Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on the Scene.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

Walls of mortared stone and cracked flagstone tiles form the interior of this cave, creating the impression of a subterranean fortress. Water trickles steadily somewhere in the cave.

Water from the broken fountain in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.Ov6rLTpT1I6vu6JG]{area B7} floods a chamber to the south (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.1gVzkdw70xvq8O3A]{area B5}). The dribbling fountain can be heard throughout the cave.

Mephit Lair Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 10 feet high.

Door. The door to @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.TFVSE7DjBYp9AYZC]{area B8} is made from reinforced wood; it’s closed but unlocked.

Environment. The cave’s walls are made of smooth, mortared stones with patches of unworked rock.

Lighting. The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on Darkvision to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Mephit Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
An arrow slit interrupts the wall at this junction.

The arrow slit is linked to @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.M8gdGNT0Ma8LZ7cq]{area B2}. If the characters enter the cave carrying a source of Bright Light or talking loudly, the slit begins to vent harmless steam as the @UUID[Actor.mmSteamMephit000]{Steam Mephit} in that area approaches the opening and observes them. The slit provides the mephit with &Reference[Three-Quarters Cover].

Balistraria.name: Balistraria
Balistraria.text:
Steam fills this stone alcove, which looks out to the cave’s entrance through a thin vertical slit.

Defenders can watch the cave entrance from this alcove. A @UUID[Actor.mmSteamMephit000]{Steam Mephit} flits about the area. It ostensibly watches for intruders coming from @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.tbCCwuchNuLfZCeO]{area B1}, but it is bored and barely fulfilling its duties. The mephit is Indifferent but defends itself in combat.

If the mephit sees the characters enter the cave, it peers at them through the arrow slit and whistles like a teakettle to entice them to approach. If a character comes within 5 feet of the slit, the mephit exhales a 15-foot Cone of harmless steam and snickers at the character’s reaction.

If the characters approach from the other side of the alcove, the mephit feigns innocence. It then tries to lure them to the old barrack (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.ceCRWk3fWsS2rxhK]{area B6}) to be ambushed by the kuo-toa that lurk there.

Prison Cells.name: Prison Cells
Prison Cells.text: Four cold cells line one wall of this chamber. Floor-to-ceiling iron bars partition the cells, which are unlocked and devoid of valuables. Two of the cells contain unidentifiable skeletal remains draped in moth-eaten rags.

Old Armory.name: Old Armory
Old Armory.text: Cobwebbed weapon racks and rusty suits of armor lie scattered about this armory. None of the items is salvageable.

Flooded Room.name: Flooded Room
Flooded Room.text:
Water trickles into this spacious chamber from the north, forming a shallow pool. A small, winged creature made of hissing steam zips above the water in pursuit of a tiny croaking frog.

Warm spring water streams into this room from @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.Ov6rLTpT1I6vu6JG]{area B7}, forming a 1-foot-deep pool here. The pool is &Reference[Difficult Terrain].

A @UUID[Actor.mmSteamMephit000]{Steam Mephit} toys with a panicked frog in the water. The mephit is initially Indifferent toward the characters and remains that way unless they try to spoil its fun, which provokes the hot-tempered elemental to start combat. If a fight breaks out, the mephits in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.M8gdGNT0Ma8LZ7cq]{areas B2} and @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.Ov6rLTpT1I6vu6JG]{B7} quickly join the fray.

Old Barrack.name: Old Barrack
Old Barrack.text:
Ruined cots are heaped near the corners of this chamber, which features a natural ceiling. Two slimy humanoids with fishlike heads use spears to carve strange symbols on the cave walls.

Two @UUID[Actor.hotbKuotoaMaraud]{Kuo-Toa Marauders} scrawl rupestrian gibberish on the walls of this run-down barrack. The Hostile kuo-toa fight the characters on sight, hoping to capture them alive and hold them in the prison cells (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.0VRgqqRq5aQ6tD5R]{area B3}). The room is otherwise empty.

Broken Fountain.name: Broken Fountain
Broken Fountain.text:
A badly broken stone fountain burbles in an alcove at the upper end of this sloped hallway.

Warm water bubbles from an underground spring into this ruined fountain. It flows south and pools in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.1gVzkdw70xvq8O3A]{area B5}.

Unless it was drawn elsewhere, a @UUID[Actor.mmSteamMephit000]{Steam Mephit} lurks near the fountain, quietly mesmerized by the fountain’s burbling. The mephit behaves similarly to the one in area B5, starting combat with the characters if disturbed. If a fight breaks out, the mephits in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.M8gdGNT0Ma8LZ7cq]{areas B2} and @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBMephitLair0.JournalEntryPage.1gVzkdw70xvq8O3A]{B5} join the fray.

Vault.name: Vault
Vault.text:
Dust coats this plundered vault, which is mostly empty. Two chests rest along the east wall.

One of the chests is fake—a hungry @UUID[Actor.mmMimic000000000]{Mimic} has altered its shape to resemble the mundane container beside it. The Mimic's Token is hidden and can be revealed when combat starts. The mimic ambushes any creature that comes within 5 feet of it. It fights to the death.

Treasure. The real treasure chest contains [[/award 150GP]] and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

C: Nothic Lair.name: C: Nothic Lair
C: Nothic Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.sCXmQnDoutnGPoEN caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveCNothicL]{Cave C}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.sCXmQnDoutnGPoEN]{Cave C}

An evil wizard used these caverns to conduct foul experiments. The last of these destroyed the wizard’s memory and transformed her into a cyclopic monster called a nothic. By studying arcane secrets, the nothic hopes to regain its memories and attain enough power to rule the Caves of Chaos.

Recently, a carrion crawler slithered into the cave and interrupted the nothic’s research. Unwilling to confront the creature directly, the nothic is now trapped in its laboratory as it concocts a solution.

You can add monsters, such as @UUID[Actor.mmStirge00000000]{Stirges}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can remove the @UUID[Actor.mmAnimatedFlying]{Animated Flying Sword} to make it easier and shorter.

Getting Started

Lay out this cave’s poster map for the other players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area Shown on the Scene.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

The entrance to this cave is flanked by carved stone blocks etched with strange geometric patterns. You hear sounds of something scuttling across the stone inside the cave.

The sounds come from the carrion crawler in the hallway (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCNothicLair0.JournalEntryPage.poQL6RK5KEF8fxum]{area C4}).

Nothic Lair Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 10 feet high.

Doors. Doors throughout the cave are made of reinforced wood with iron hinges.

Environment. The cave has mostly smooth stone walls with patches of unworked stone. The smooth stone walls are carved with geometric patterns and indecipherable runes.

Lighting. The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on Darkvision or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Nothic Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
The symbols etched into the entrance extend into the cave.

A character who examines the symbols and succeeds on a [[/skill arc 13]] check recognizes them as arcane runes designed to ward the cave against magical scrutiny. The runes are unfinished, so they have no effect.

Ritual Chamber.name: Ritual Chamber
Ritual Chamber.text:
Half-melted black candles surround a circle of arcane symbols scribed on the floor in white chalk. Scorch marks mar the floor inside the circle.

A character who examines the circle and succeeds on a [[/skill arc 13]] check determines it was the site of an arcane ritual that went horribly wrong.

Library.name: Library
Library.text:
Moldy leather-bound books line stone shelves carved into the walls of this underground library. A tome with an iron-plated cover lies open on a table near the north wall.

The nothic occasionally performs research here.

Books. The books in this room cover topics related to alchemy, geometry, and metallurgy. They are hard to parse, and none of them are valuable to the characters.

Iron Tome. The open tome describes the Chaos Bell, a wicked bell said to attract monsters from near and far. The book claims the bell’s toll can even wake the dead. According to the book, the bell can be destroyed only by submerging it in a @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion2Woods.JournalEntryPage.XQht3e1JSq6F1ePK]{sacred spring} hidden in the forests of the Borderlands.

Hallway.name: Hallway
Hallway.text:
A massive, tentacled grub with dozens of legs creeps along the ceiling of this long hallway.

A @UUID[Actor.mmCarrionCrawler]{Carrion Crawler} clings to the hall’s ceiling. It is Hostile toward all other creatures and fights them on sight.

Wizard’s Laboratory.name: Wizard’s Laboratory
Wizard’s Laboratory.text:
Esoteric apparatuses and strange reagents line worktables and shelves in this laboratory. A cyclopic creature paces about the room before a chalkboard. A floating sword guards the creature.

A @UUID[Actor.mmNothic00000000]{Nothic} broods over the invader in the hallway (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCNothicLair0.JournalEntryPage.poQL6RK5KEF8fxum]{area C4}). Protecting the nothic is an @UUID[Actor.mmAnimatedFlying]{Animated Flying Sword} that obeys the nothic’s commands. Both are initially Indifferent toward the characters.

Chalkboard. Scrawled on the chalkboard are a map of this cave and indecipherable formulas.

Eye for an Eye. The nothic wants to research in peace, which it can’t do as long as the carrion crawler threatens its lair. If the characters don’t fight the nothic, it asks them for help.

If the characters slay the carrion crawler, the nothic offers the party the treasure in the cell (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCNothicLair0.JournalEntryPage.0rD5h0M9SquTqrOU]{area C6}). If asked about the dead dwarf there, the nothic takes credit for thwarting the meddlesome thief.

Key. On a table is a key to the storage room (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCNothicLair0.JournalEntryPage.yaKgMl1zOE4GvIEw]{area C7}). To swipe the key without the nothic noticing, a character must succeed on a [[/skill slt 14]] check. On a failed check, the nothic and its sword start combat.

Cell.name: Cell
Cell.text:
Iron bars divide this chamber, forming a cell to the south. Flies buzz around a corpse sprawled on the floor of the cell.

The cell is unlocked. Inside lies the rotting corpse of a dwarf explorer who came to the Caves of Chaos in search of riches but perished ten days ago. A character who examines the corpse and succeeds on a [[/skill med 10]] check deduces that the dwarf died from Necrotic damage.

Treasure. The dead explorer’s belongings include [[/award 60GP]] and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

Storage Room.name: Storage Room
Storage Room.text:
The door to this room is locked. The key can be found in the laboratory (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCNothicLair0.JournalEntryPage.Zvg6eI4hvfHzQUKO]{area C5}). As a Utilize action, a character can pick the lock with a successful [[/skill slt 15 tool=thief]] or force open the door with a successful [[/skill 15 ath]] check.

Treasure. An unlocked chest against the east wall contains [[/award 100GP]] and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

D: Goblin Lair.name: D: Goblin Lair
D: Goblin Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.NgLLrB4AYzrKQyab caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveDGoblinL]{Cave D}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.NgLLrB4AYzrKQyab]{Cave D}

A violent band of goblin warriors lives in this cave. It’s the goblin boss’s birthday, and she demands a celebration! Engrossed in the revelry, the goblins ignore their recent captive: a dwarf named @UUID[Actor.hotbVinx00000000]{Vinx}.

You can add monsters to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult. The goblins might have invited @UUID[Actor.mmHobgoblinWarri]{Hobgoblin Warriors} from the adjacent cave (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa]{cave F}) as party guests or bodyguards. To make the scenario easier and shorter, reduce the number of @UUID[Actor.mmGoblinWarrior0]{Goblin Warriors}.

Getting Started

Activate this cave’s Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0]{map D} if the characters approach from outside the cave, in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0.JournalEntryPage.bHx3nAxEm37lZT78]{area D5} if they enter through the secret door in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbEOgreLair000.JournalEntryPage.ACFAkWYOX0k8RMh3]{cave E}, or in the hallway west of @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0.JournalEntryPage.UWtJtfAl7ORQc9Iz]{area D4} if they arrive from @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa]{cave F}.

Read or paraphrase the following to begin:

Torches illuminate this stinking cave. A horrendous racket of discordant voices echoes within. The voices appear to be singing—quite badly.

The “music” emanates from the boss’s room (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0.JournalEntryPage.UWtJtfAl7ORQc9Iz]{area D4}), where off-key goblins commemorate their leader in song. The singing continues for 1 minute, then ends with a din of celebratory yips.

Goblin Lair Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 10 feet high.

Surroundings. The cave has walls of rough-hewn stone and a dirt floor. It stinks of old food and soiled clothes, which are strewn about the cave.

Doors and Secret Door. Doors in the cave are made of rough wood. The secret door in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0.JournalEntryPage.bHx3nAxEm37lZT78]{area D5} blends in with the surrounding wall. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character can make a [[/skill 15 perception]] check to scan that area for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check.

Lighting. Torches in wall sconces throughout the cave fill it with Bright Light.

Goblin Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
The walls here are daubed with crude paintings of grinning goblins with pointy hats. Scrawled above the art are the words, “hoppee birthday!”

The goblins painted the celebratory drawings.

Dead-End Tunnel.name: Dead-End Tunnel
Dead-End Tunnel.text:
This tunnel leads to a dead end with some old barrels. An exasperated dwarf is tied up beside them. “A little help here?” she asks as she squirms.

The captive is @UUID[Actor.hotbVinx00000000]{Vinx}, a dwarf spelunker. Vinx came to this cave in search of a stolen family tapestry, but the goblins captured her. Vinx is Indifferent toward the characters and has the &Reference[Restrained apply=false] condition while bound.

Vinx assures the characters that she’s a capable explorer who can hold her own in a fight, but some quests can’t be completed alone. If they help her recover the tapestry, she promises a hefty reward.

The barrels are mostly filled with crooked spears and old arrows that are unusable.

Freeing Vinx. As an action, a character can untie Vinx or cut her bonds (no check required). If freed, Vinx gratefully accompanies the characters as they explore the cave and fights alongside them until they all reemerge in the valley.

Treasure. Vinx stashed a magic item at the bottom of one of the barrels before she was captured; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item. If freed, Vinx discreetly fishes the item out of the barrel and keeps it on her person until the characters find her family’s tapestry (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0.JournalEntryPage.UWtJtfAl7ORQc9Iz]{area D4}).

Common Room.name: Common Room
Common Room.text:
Heaps of soiled bedding, tables, and stools are scattered around the room. Clumsily wrapped presents with tattered ribbons are piled on one table, along with a half-eaten cake that looks like it was dropped.

These goblin gifts include a bag of assorted teeth, a moist wad of thoughtfully pre-chewed jerky, and a foul-smelling mushroom. The cake appears professionally baked but poorly handled.

Boss’s Room.name: Boss’s Room
Boss’s Room.text:
In this rowdy chamber, a bossy goblin with a party hat and a kazoo sits on a wooden throne with a lopsided cushion. Goblin celebrants with cake-stained faces dance below.

A @UUID[Actor.mmGoblinBoss0000]{Goblin Boss} and four @UUID[Actor.mmGoblinWarrior0]{Goblin Warriors} are here celebrating the boss’s birthday. The goblins are initially Hostile toward the characters.

When the goblins notice the characters, they stop dancing. Read or paraphrase the following text:

The goblin on the throne leaps to her feet and barks, “BREE-YARK! This is my party, and I don’t remember inviting you!”

The goblins brandish their weapons.

“Hoppee Birthday!” As an &Reference[Influence] action, a character can try to defuse the tension and make a [[/skill per 13]] check. A character who offers the boss an impressive birthday present—such as 10 GP, a magic item, or one of the gifts from @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0.JournalEntryPage.47nMrIlk3bxqYDtX]{area D3}—automatically succeeds on this check.

On a successful check, the goblins’ attitudes improve to Indifferent, and the boss invites the characters to join her birthday celebration. On a failed check, the goblins fight the party crashers.

Treasure. Stashed under the throne’s ragged cushion are a fine @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbTapestry0000]{tapestry} sewn with silver and gold threads and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item. The tapestry belongs to Vinx and is worth 90 GP.

If the characters give the tapestry to Vinx, she rewards them with the magic item from @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0.JournalEntryPage.9UHZvWUBhRmb54rH]{area D2}. However, if she learns the characters intend to keep the tapestry, she hotly demands they return the family heirloom and fights them if they refuse.

Webbed Cavern.name: Webbed Cavern
Webbed Cavern.text:
Webs drape the western half of this musky cave. The @UUID[Actor.mmGiantSpider000]{Giant Spider} is hidden because the monster is hiding! It can be revealed when you're ready.

A Giant Spider lurks in a tunnel to the south. The Hostile spider ambushes all non-goblins in its den.

Webs. The webs are &Reference[Difficult Terrain], but they aren’t strong enough to restrain anyone. Each 10-foot-cube of webs has AC 10; HP 5; Vulnerability to Fire damage; and Immunity to Bludgeoning, Piercing, Poison, and Psychic damage.

Difficult Terrain

The webbed area is configured as Difficult Terrain so movement through it will automatically take twice as much movement.

E: Ogre Lair.name: E: Ogre Lair
E: Ogre Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.wnAeOzQY4htRpQcL caption=false classes="right three"]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveEOgreLai]{Cave E}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.wnAeOzQY4htRpQcL]{Cave E}

An ogre mercenary named Oggdug recently formed an alliance with a red dragon wyrmling who aims to rule the Caves of Chaos. The dragon, Cindertooth, serves Oggdug as an attack dog and companion—for now. Cindertooth tolerates Oggdug so long as the ogre supplies him with gold and spoils for his growing hoard. Player characters might hire the ogre for a short time.

You can add monsters to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult. One or more @UUID[Actor.mmGoblinWarrior0]{Goblin Warriors} or @UUID[Actor.mmKoboldWarrior0]{Kobold Warriors} might be here soliciting the ogre’s services. Conversely, you can remove the @UUID[Actor.mmRedDragonWyrml]{Red Dragon Wyrmling} to make the scenario easier and shorter. Cindertooth might be away when the characters first explore this cave.

Getting Started

Activate this cave’s Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on the Scene if the characters approach from outside the cave or in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbEOgreLair000.JournalEntryPage.ACFAkWYOX0k8RMh3]{area E3} if they enter through the secret door in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0]{cave D}.

If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:

This large cave exudes a strong, sour odor. Half-gnawed hunks of meat from sloppily butchered and charred animals litter the area.

The cave’s occupants are responsible for the mess.

Ogre Lair Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 15 feet high.

Environment. The dirt floor of this natural cave is stained with blood from past battles.

Secret Door. The secret door in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbEOgreLair000.JournalEntryPage.ACFAkWYOX0k8RMh3]{area E3} blends in with the surrounding wall. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character can make a [[/skill 15 perception]] check to scan that area for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check. Oggdug knows about the door but doesn’t use it due to its narrowness and the spider den on the other side (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0]{cave D}).

Lighting. During the day, natural light provides &Reference[Dim Light] in the cave. At night, its denizens rely on Darkvision to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Day and Night Modes

If your players arrive at night you can set the Scene's Darkness level to .8 or higher. This can be done automatically by changing to the Light tool and pressing the Transition to Night button. It will automatically disable the lights in the cave for accurate vision.

Ogre Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to map E. The map also shows you where to place tokens.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
Flies buzz around the rotting carcass of some unrecognizable beast outside the cave mouth.

The carcass conceals a hidden snare trap. The trap is depicted in the Scene.

Snare Trap. This trap consists of bent saplings and a loop of gore-encrusted rope. A creature that moves, prods, or otherwise disturbs the meat must succeed on a [[/save 12 dex]] saving throw or be hoisted 5 feet into the air. The hoisted creature has the &Reference[Restrained] condition until it gets free.

Rules for detecting, disabling, and escaping the trap are as follows:

Detect and Disable. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character can examine the carcass and make a [[/skill prc 13]] check, detecting the trap on a successful check. Once detected, the trap can be disabled by a character who takes the &Reference[Utilize] action and succeeds on a [[/skill 13 slt]] check; failing this check triggers the trap.

Escaping the Trap. As an action, a creature &Reference[Restrained apply=false] by the trap can free itself by cutting the rope or by slipping out with a successful [[/skill acr 15]] check.

If the trap is triggered, the noise alerts the ogre in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbEOgreLair000.JournalEntryPage.KryO3ctzLZCfsscx]{area E2}, who stomps out of the cave to investigate. The encounter in that area then occurs here.

Ogre Mercenary’s Den.name: Ogre Mercenary’s Den
Ogre Mercenary’s Den.text:
Thick, lumpy bearskins cover the floor of this cave, but they’re hardly visible beneath the hulking, potbellied giant that lies atop it, picking his teeth with a rusty sword.

Oggdug, an @UUID[Actor.mmOgre0000000000]{Ogre}, reclines on the bearskins. He is initially Hostile toward the characters, but if they approach peacefully, Oggdug assumes they must want to hire him for mercenary work. He tells the characters to cough up some coin or get out, threatening to clobber any who refuse.

A character can shift Oggdug’s attitude from Hostile to Indifferent by hiring him (see the “Hiring the Ogre” section below) or taking the &Reference[Influence] action to make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill dec 10]]. The character dupes the ogre with a clever ruse or outlandish lie.

[[/skill 10 prf]]. The character amuses the ogre with a small performance, such as a dance or magic trick.

[[/skill 10 per]]. The character convinces the ogre the party means him no harm.

On a failed check, or if a character tries to undercut Oggdug’s price, the ogre starts combat, grumbling that the characters are “puny cheapskates.” If the ogre drops to half his Hit Points or fewer, he calls to Cindertooth in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbEOgreLair000.JournalEntryPage.ACFAkWYOX0k8RMh3]{area E3} for aid.

Hiring the Ogre. Oggdug is accustomed to other denizens of the Caves of Chaos hiring him for mercenary work. His rate is 50 GP per job, but first-time customers get a 50 percent discount (25 GP). Cindertooth gets half of Oggdug’s earnings.

If the party pays the ogre his asking price, he joins them for a single fight in any of the caves except for the two caves he says are off-limits (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave]{cave G} and @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi]{cave K}). After the fight, the ogre returns to this cave unless the characters pay him for another bout. The second time the characters hire the ogre and every time afterward, his rate is 50 GP per job.

“Oggdug Sad.” If a character asks Oggdug about either of the off-limits caves, the ogre sighs mournfully and tells them his tragic story. Oggdug once shared this cave with his older brother, Zurf, before Zurf was killed by an owlbear near its den (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave]{cave G}). Cultists later animated Zurf’s half-eaten corpse, which now guards the cultists’ lair (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi]{cave K}). Oggdug now shuns both caves.

Treasure. The filthy bearskins conceal a pile of equine bones, a wheel of cheese, a keg of brandy, and a lumpy sack containing [[/award 60GP]]. The ogre warns anyone who goes near the bearskins that he’ll “give ’em a good stomping” if they continue snooping. He makes good on his threat.

Dragon’s Den.name: Dragon’s Den
Dragon’s Den.text:
This spacious cavern contains battered armor, broken weapons, casks of ale and mead, and other supplies. A red-scaled dragon glowers down at the chamber from a rocky perch ten feet above the cave floor.

Cindertooth, a @UUID[Actor.mmRedDragonWyrml]{Red Dragon Wyrmling}, dwells in this cavern. The dragon is Hostile toward creatures other than Oggdug.

When Cindertooth notices the characters, he flies down to scold them for trespassing. He demands each character pay him 10 GP as tribute or face his fiery wrath.

A character can attempt to avoid Cindertooth’s toll by making a [[/skill 13 per]] check. Characters who appeal to the dragon’s ego through flattery have &Reference[Advantage] on this check. On a successful check, or if the character pays Cindertooth, the dragon tells them to leave this cave while they still can. On a failed check, or if the characters don’t heed Cindertooth’s warning, he starts combat.

Fighting Cindertooth. Combat here draws the attention of Oggdug, who stomps into this area and joins the fray. At your discretion, the ogre might fight alongside the characters in hopes of claiming the dragon’s hoard for himself.

Treasure. The provisions and supplies in this room were taken from travelers and adventures who crossed paths with Cindertooth. All the equipment here was ruined beyond repair in battle.

Amid the dragon’s spoils are [[/award 50GP]] and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item. The dragon fights any creature that steals from its hoard.

F: Hobgoblin Lair.name: F: Hobgoblin Lair
F: Hobgoblin Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.apmbROei2q8JLU8k caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveFHobgobl]{Cave F}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.apmbROei2q8JLU8k]{Cave F}

Hobgoblins quartered in this cave recently suffered heavy losses, including their former captain. Only four hobgoblins remain. They’ve fortified their outpost and drafted a voracious ooze to guard it.

You can add monsters, such as allied @UUID[Actor.mmGoblinWarrior0]{Goblin Warriors}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can remove some monsters to make it easier and shorter. One or two Hobgoblin Warriors might be out on a patrol elsewhere.

Getting Started

Activate this cave's Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on the Scene if they characters approach from outside the cave or in the hall east of @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.zvYrW2GM5qXWQEqd]{area F2} if they arrive from @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0]{cave D}. Don’t place any other tokens yet, since the cave’s contents aren’t visible to characters at the outset.

If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:

A stout, ironbound door seals this cave mouth. Bleached skulls line niches outside the entrance. A bloodstained sign on the door reads, “Come in! We’d like to have you for dinner!”

The hobgoblins don’t eat people, but they use the sign’s gruesome implication to scare intruders.

Hobgoblin Lair Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 10 feet high.

Doors. The cave’s doors are made of oak planks bound with iron. They are unlocked.

Environment. The cave is carved from stone. It is scrupulously clean. The hobgoblins keep their areas tidy, and the @UUID[Actor.mmGelatinousCube]{jelly cube} in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.zvYrW2GM5qXWQEqd]{area F2} sweeps up anything in its path.

Lighting. The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on Darkvision or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Hobgoblin Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
An armored goblinoid warrior with red-orange skin and a bow stands behind a rickety barricade of interlocking spears. “Halt!” she commands. “State your business or face the wrath of our battalion—thirty hobgoblins strong.”

A @UUID[Actor.mmHobgoblinWarri]{Hobgoblin Warrior} stands guard behind a pair of @UUID[Actor.hotbSpearBarrica]{spear barricades} (see the sidebar). The sentry is Hostile toward intruders and tries to delay them through interrogation until the @UUID[Actor.mmGelatinousCube]{jelly cube} in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.zvYrW2GM5qXWQEqd]{area F2} arrives here to dispatch them.

The sentry is lying about how many hobgoblins remain. Weakened by their recent loss, the hobgoblins fear marauders and try to present a strong front. A character who doubts the sentry can take the &Reference[Search] action and make a [[/skill ins 13]] check; a successful check discerns the lie.

As an &Reference[Influence] action, a character can try to pacify the sentry and make a [[/skill per 14]] check. A character who saw through her previous lie has Advantage on this check. On a successful check, the sentry’s attitude improves to Indifferent, and she stands down; she warns the characters about the jelly cube’s impending arrival but doesn’t let them past the barricades. On a failed check, the sentry commands the characters to leave at once or be destroyed.

Fighting the Hobgoblins. In combat, the sentry remains behind the barricades. If the characters breach either barricade, the sentry uses her next action to blow a war horn, alerting the other hobgoblins in the cave. She then retreats to the barrack (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.JRarjknLf30B097M]{area F4}), where she and the rest of the hobgoblins make their last stand.

Spear Barricade

A spear barricade is a bristly cube of interlocking spears. Each spear barricade has these rules.

Difficult Terrain. The barricade is &Reference[Difficult Terrain]. A creature that moves through the barricade takes [[/damage 1d6 Piercing]] damage.

Provides Half Cover. A creature behind the barricade has &Reference[Half Cover].

Breaking the Barricade. The barricade has AC 15, HP 4, and Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage. If reduced to 0 Hit Points, the barricade is destroyed.

Cube Route.name: Cube Route
Cube Route.text:
This smooth tunnel forms a rectangular circuit.

A hungry @UUID[Actor.mmGelatinousCube]{Jelly Cube} slowly loops counterclockwise through this part of the cave. It takes about 1 minute for it to complete a lap. The cube occasionally meanders down the eastern tunnel toward @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbDGoblinLair0]{cave D} and back again, but it never crosses the spear barricades (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.NOYUTUfqnsrhAGCP#spear-barricade]{the sidebar}).

The cube is Hostile toward all other creatures and fights them on detection. Clever characters might be able to lure the cube out of the cave through the entrance to @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.NOYUTUfqnsrhAGCP]{area F1}, shutting the door behind them.

Mess Hall.name: Mess Hall
Mess Hall.text: The hobgoblins dine in this mess hall. They erected a pair of @UUID[Actor.hotbSpearBarrica]{spear barricades} (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.NOYUTUfqnsrhAGCP#spear-barricade]{the sidebar}) to keep the @UUID[Actor.mmGelatinousCube]{jelly cube} in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.zvYrW2GM5qXWQEqd]{area F2} out. The room contains nothing of value to the characters.

Barrack.name: Barrack
Barrack.text:
This chamber contains a dozen stiff-looking cots, but only four have seen recent use. A large iron strongbox sits against the east wall. A hobgoblin warrior, sword in hand, stands before it.

The surviving hobgoblins lodge in this once-full barrack. A lone @UUID[Actor.mmHobgoblinWarri]{Hobgoblin Warrior} fiercely defends what few valuables remain. He starts combat with the characters on sight and fights to the death.

If the hobgoblin sentry sounded the alarm in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.NOYUTUfqnsrhAGCP]{area F1}, the two Hobgoblin Warriors from @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbFHobgoblinLa.JournalEntryPage.si7Lk8pghF4LQKfs]{area F5} are also here, ready to intercept the characters.

Treasure. The chest includes stolen goods: @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbFineFurs0000]{fine furs} worth 75 GP, a pouch containing [[/award 20GP]], and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

Training Hall.name: Training Hall
Training Hall.text:
This training hall holds bare weapon racks and four straw-stuffed targets painted with bullseyes.
Two hobgoblin archers fire at the targets.

Unless they were called elsewhere, two @UUID[Actor.mmHobgoblinWarri]{Hobgoblin Warriors} train in this hall, which was stripped of its weapons during a raid. The hobgoblins are Hostile toward intruders and fight them on sight.

G: Shunned Caves.name: G: Shunned Caves
G: Shunned Caves.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.EvuysYbApYktHBlQ caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveGShunned]{Cave G}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.EvuysYbApYktHBlQ]{Cave G}

An owlbear—a frightening cross between a bear and a giant owl—lurks in this cave. Most other denizens of the valley give the cave a wide berth.

This cave is connected to @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi]{cave K}, a hotbed of activity for the Cult of Chaos, whose members venerate powers of disorder and destruction. The cult mainly operates in the adjacent cave, but as its ranks swell, cultists increasingly frequent this one. The owlbear is unaware of the cultists’ presence.

You can add monsters, such as @UUID[Actor.mmZombie00000000]{Zombies}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can reduce the number of @UUID[Actor.mmCultist0000000]{Cultists} or @UUID[Actor.mmGrayOoze000000]{Gray Ooze Globs} to make it easier and shorter.

Getting Started

Activate this cave's Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on the Scene if the characters approach from outside the cave or on the stairs south of @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave.JournalEntryPage.Kb3YWWGkK2yPj0ag]{area G6} if they arrive from cave K.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

The stench of rot and wet stone issues from this natural cave. An unsettling screech and the sound of thick feathers ruffling echo within.

The owlbear is moving restlessly in its den (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave.JournalEntryPage.jy1nrvLD2R8ZaZzB]{area G5}).

Shunned Cave Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 15 feet high.

Door. The stone door to @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave.JournalEntryPage.Kb3YWWGkK2yPj0ag]{area G6} is ajar.

Environment. The eastern half of this cave (areas G1–G5) has naturally formed spaces with wet walls and damp dirt floors. The western half of the cave (areas G6–G7) has walls made of cut stone blocks and floors made of cracked tiles.

Lighting. Unless noted otherwise, the cave is unlit. Its denizens use Darkvision or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Shunned Cave Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text: Gnawed bones litter the ground near the cave mouth, and the stench of blood hangs in the air. The bones belong to the owlbear’s victims, including animals, explorers, and other monsters. The bones bear indentations from the owlbear’s toothed beak.

Shallow Pool.name: Shallow Pool
Shallow Pool.text:
Moisture drips from the ceiling of this damp cave, forming a shallow pool. Something glitters in the murky water.

Both of the @UUID[Actor.mmGrayOoze000000]{Gray Ooze Globs} are hiding so their Tokens are hidden. They can be revealed when you're ready. Two Gray Ooze Globs lurk in the pool, which is 2 feet deep and &Reference[Difficult Terrain]. The Hostile oozes fight any creature that comes within 5 feet of the water.

Treasure. The pool contains a jewel-encrusted goblet (give the players one @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbGem000000000]{Gem}) and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

Tight Passage.name: Tight Passage
Tight Passage.text:
A narrow crack spans the cave wall here. The opening is only big enough for a Medium or smaller creature to fit through. Inside, the mangled corpse of a human explorer slumps against a stalagmite.

The owlbear in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave.JournalEntryPage.jy1nrvLD2R8ZaZzB]{area G5} can’t fit through the crack. If a character seeks refuge here, the owlbear loses interest and returns to its den.

Smelly Refuse.name: Smelly Refuse
Smelly Refuse.text: This cave contains heaps of food scraps, rotting carcasses, and a scattering of halfling-size bird pellets composed of fur and regurgitated bones.

Owlbear Den.name: Owlbear Den
Owlbear Den.text:
A monstrous creature with a thick, shaggy hide and a feathered, owllike head paces aggressively in this den between nests formed from damp leaves and bloodstained branches.

A territorial @UUID[Actor.mmOwlbear0000000]{Owlbear} lairs in this den. The Hostile owlbear fights all other creatures on sight.

Ledge. At the chamber’s south end, a ledge 10 feet above the floor marks the entrance to a tunnel to @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave.JournalEntryPage.Kb3YWWGkK2yPj0ag]{areas G6} and G7. To climb the cave’s slippery walls to reach the ledge, a character must succeed on a [[/skill ath 15]] check. The owlbear doesn’t pursue characters beyond the ledge.

Cult Barrack.name: Cult Barrack
Cult Barrack.text:
These cult quarters contain beds, a table, and several chairs. Tapestries on the walls depict evil creatures and obscene rituals. Four humans in hooded red robes recline on the beds.

Torches in wall sconces fill this room with &Reference[Bright Light]. Four @UUID[Actor.mmCultist0000000]{Cultists} relax in these quarters for the Cult of Chaos. They are nonchalantly discussing the finer points of mayhem, torture, and other cruelties.

The cultists are Hostile toward intruders not garbed in their cult’s attire and eagerly inflict violence on nonbelievers. As an &Reference[Influence] action, a character can try to de-escalate the situation and make one of the following ability checks (with Advantage if the character is dressed like a member of the Cult of Chaos). Consider these examples:

[[/skill dec 13]]. The character deceives the cultists with a lie, such as pretending to be a fellow cultist or an aspiring member.

[[/skill per 13]]. The character convinces the cultists that it is in both parties’ interests not to fight.
