On a successful check, the cultists’ attitudes improve to Indifferent. Otherwise, the cultists fight.

Treasure. Footlockers under four of the beds contain the cultists’ belongings. Each contains [[/award 5GP]], a few worthless personal effects, and a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbCultistsRobe]{cult robe}.

Crypt.name: Crypt
Crypt.text:
Damp stairs descend to this musty crypt. A closed stone sarcophagus sits at the north end.

The @UUID[Actor.mmWight000000000]{Wight Lifedrinker}'s Token is hidden as it resides within the sarcophagus. Reveal it when a character opens the sarcophagus (see below).

A Hostile Wight Lifedrinker rests in the sarcophagus. The monster was once a cult leader who was so wicked in life that when he died, he rose as a cruel undead warrior. As an action, a character can pry open the lid of the sarcophagus, at which point the wight springs forth and fights.

Treasure. The sarcophagus holds one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

H: Bugbear Lair.name: H: Bugbear Lair
H: Bugbear Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.woAXakVZiaeL5qfI caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveHBugbear]{Cave H}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.woAXakVZiaeL5qfI]{Cave H}

This cave recently came under the control of three belligerent bugbears and the goblin stooges they’ve cowed into their service. The bugbears are plotting an assault on the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn]{Keep on the Borderlands}. They dream of destroying the keep and looting its riches.

You can add another @UUID[Actor.mmBugbearWarrior]{Bugbear Warrior} to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can remove one or more of them to make it easier and shorter.

Getting Started

Activate the Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on the Scene if the characters approach from outside the cave or in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbHBugbearLair.JournalEntryPage.ZZAkUjrtUKLRc4LZ]{area H5} if they enter through the secret door in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbIMinotaurLai]{cave I}.

If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:

A tunnel of rough stone is tucked behind several bushes. Within, you hear two deep voices in a heated argument. The conversation is unintelligible at this range.

The voices belong to a pair of bugbears quarreling in the war room (@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbHBugbearLair.JournalEntryPage.kepU4JeP06ZdD5Ka]{area H2}).

Bugbear Lair Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 10 feet high.

Doors and Secret Doors. The doors in this cave are made of sturdy wood planks. The secret door in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbHBugbearLair.JournalEntryPage.ZZAkUjrtUKLRc4LZ]{area H5} blends in with the surrounding wall. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character can make a [[/skill 15 perception]] check to scan that area for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check.

Environment. The walls are made of rough-hewn stone in some places and neat-fitting stone blocks in others. Stone tiles cover the floor.

Lighting. The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on Darkvision to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Bugbear Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text: Just inside the cave, a tunnel branches east and west.

War Room.name: War Room
War Room.text:
The door to this makeshift war room is ajar, allowing the characters to hear two gruff voices bickering inside. When the characters enter or peek inside, read or paraphrase the following text:

This room contains an old table and four upright logs. A poorly drawn map of the Borderlands covers the table. Two tall, furry goblinoids hunch over the map, arguing with each other.

Two @UUID[Actor.mmBugbearWarrior]{Bugbear Warriors} squabble about how best to infiltrate the keep. One asserts that a stealthy approach would be best, while the other insists on a direct assault aided by a local ogre mercenary (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbEOgreLair000.JournalEntryPage.KryO3ctzLZCfsscx]{cave E}). The Hostile bugbears fight the characters on sight and can’t be bargained with.

Stairway.name: Stairway
Stairway.text:
Stairs ascend north. At the top of the stairs is a heavy log the width of the stairway. Two goblins stand guard on a landing halfway up the stairs.

These two @UUID[Actor.mmGoblinWarrior0]{Goblin Warriors} are Hostile toward the characters. When the goblins detect an intruder to the south, roll Initiative.

On the goblins’ turn, they attempt to scramble up the stairs and activate the rolling log trap (detailed below). The goblins then fight the characters.

Rolling Log Trap. This 10-foot-long log rolls down an incline, flattening creatures in its path.

As an action, a creature within 5 feet of the stationary log can push it down the stairs. The log tumbles down the incline in a straight line. Each creature in the log’s path must make a [[/save 13 dex]] saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes [[/damage 2d6 Bludgeoning]] damage and has the &Reference[Prone] condition. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.

Rolling Log Trap

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.macros.Macro.hotbCaveHToggleR]{Toggle Rolling Log} Macro will roll the log down the hallway or return it to the starting position if you run it again.

Trophy Room.name: Trophy Room
Trophy Room.text:
The stuffed heads of deer, wolves, and other beasts are mounted on the walls of this room, as are a few humanoid heads with ghastly expressions. Skulls are piled in the northwest corner.

Among the trophies are a number of empty mounts equal to the characters in the party—a grim omen of what could happen if they’re defeated in this cave.

Treasure. The skulls hide a purse containing [[/award 10GP]].

Hall.name: Hall
Hall.text:
Musty animal furs serve as beds in this stark hall, where a furry brute berates two smaller, squeaky-voiced goblin subordinates.

A @UUID[Actor.mmBugbearWarrior]{Bugbear Warrior}—the self-proclaimed boss of the cave—scolds two @UUID[Actor.mmGoblinWarrior0]{Goblin Warriors} for sleeping on the job. When they notice the characters, the bugbear commands the goblins to fight and joins them in battle. The bugbear is Hostile toward the party, while the goblins are Indifferent.

Swaying the Goblins. These fickle goblins, Gargle and Yams, were recently recruited and don’t like being yelled at.

As an &Reference[Influence] action, a character can try to shake the goblins’ loyalty and make one of the following checks (with Advantage if the party already defeated the bugbear). Consider these examples:

[[/skill 10 dec]]. The character tricks the goblins into believing the party now commands the cave.

[[/skill itm 11]]. The character scares the goblins into fearing for their lives.

[[/skill 10 per]]. The character convinces the goblins the party means them no harm.

On a successful check, the goblins’ attitudes improve to Friendly. In exchange for a bribe of at least 2 GP, the goblins also help the characters defeat any remaining bugbears in the cave and tell the characters about the secret door in this area, though the goblins don’t know what lies on the other side.

Treasure. Scattered among the furs on the floor are [[/award 25GP]] and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

Open the Secret Door

If the players discover and open the secret door use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.macros.Macro.hotbCaveHToggleS]{Toggle Secret Door} Macro which will open the door and reveal the hidden Tile which shows the doorway and the room beyond.

Boss’s Chamber.name: Boss’s Chamber
Boss’s Chamber.text:
A heap of thick animal furs forms a soft bed in this room, where the bugbear boss in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbHBugbearLair.JournalEntryPage.ZZAkUjrtUKLRc4LZ]{area H5} sleeps. Don’t reveal that there is treasure in this area unless a character investigates the furs.

Treasure. Stashed in the furs are [[/award 25GP]] and one magic item; draw a result from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

I: Minotaur Lair.name: I: Minotaur Lair
I: Minotaur Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.nluh5BFwekVUD0OT caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Poster Map: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveIMinotau]{Cave I}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.nluh5BFwekVUD0OT]{Cave I}

A bloodthirsty minotaur rules this cave. A servant of Baphomet—a demon lord who endorses bloodshed and cruelty—the minotaur feasts on adventurers and monsters alike. It stalks its lair, huffing in bestial rage.

The minotaur’s only companions are the vermin that scavenge its grisly leftovers. Deprived of recent visitors to its cave, the minotaur hungers for new playthings to hunt.

You can add monsters to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult. One or more @UUID[Actor.mmBandit00000000]{Bandits} might be here searching for hidden treasure. Conversely, you can reduce the number of @UUID[Actor.mmStirge00000000]{Stirges} to make the scenario easier and shorter.

Getting Started

Activate this cave's Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on the Scene if the characters approach from outside the cave or north of @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbIMinotaurLai.JournalEntryPage.1nh6QnQFGYYrxAfP]{area I3} if they enter through the secret door in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbHBugbearLair]{cave H}.

If the characters approach from outside the cave, read the following boxed text aloud to begin:

The entrance to this cave is a gaping maw of crumbling gray bricks. A low bellow rumbles within, causing dirt to trickle from the roof of the cave mouth.

Minotaur Lair Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 15 feet high.

Environment. The cave walls are made of hard-packed dirt reinforced with crumbling pillars and brickwork. Crushed bones lie scattered about the dirt floor.

Lighting. The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on Darkvision or other means to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Secret Doors. The secret doors in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbIMinotaurLai.JournalEntryPage.1nh6QnQFGYYrxAfP]{areas I3} and @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbIMinotaurLai.JournalEntryPage.slzPY51MwR88hBLL]{I4} blend in with their surroundings. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character in either of those areas can make a [[/skill 15 perception]] check to scan the area for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check.

Minotaur Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
Bones litter the furrowed dirt around the cave mouth.

Pressed into the dirt are the broken bones of the minotaur’s past victims—unlucky goblins, kobolds, and explorers who stumbled on the monster’s lair.

Hoof Tracks. A character who inspects the area and succeeds on a [[/skill 11 sur]] check notices hoof tracks left by a hulking, bipedal creature. The tracks lead west.

Stirge Lair.name: Stirge Lair
Stirge Lair.text:
The floor of this bloodstained cavern is strewn with small animal bones and the shriveled-up carcasses of cave-dwelling bats and rodents. A dim orange glow emanates from the north.

Three @UUID[Actor.mmStirge00000000]{Stirges} hang asleep from the ceiling. These flying pests subsist on a diet of fresh blood. The stirges avoid the minotaur, but they are Hostile toward all other creatures.

Bright Light or any noise louder than a whisper wakes the stirges, which then start combat. The light from the fire beetles in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbIMinotaurLai.JournalEntryPage.1nh6QnQFGYYrxAfP]{area I3} is visible from here but is too dim to awaken the stirges. In combat, the stirges gorge themselves until they’ve drunk the characters dry.

Fire Beetle Sanctuary.name: Fire Beetle Sanctuary
Fire Beetle Sanctuary.text:
Old bricks reinforce the walls of this dirt cave. The cave contains two beetles, each as big as a dog and glowing with warm orange light. The beetles search the dirt floor for grubs.

Two @UUID[Actor.mmGiantFireBeetl]{Giant Fire Beetles} scrape up the dirt in search of tasty morsels. The beetles keep a safe distance from the minotaur and defend themselves if necessary. They are Indifferent toward the characters.

Taming the Beetles. As an &Reference[Influence] action, a character can make a [[/skill 12 ani]] check to tame a fire beetle. A character who waves a light source at the beetle has Advantage on this check. On a successful check, the beetle becomes Friendly toward the character and follows them throughout this cave, warmly illuminating their surroundings. While accompanied in this way, the character has Advantage on checks to notice secret doors. The beetles don’t leave cave I.

Minotaur Maze.name: Minotaur Maze
Minotaur Maze.text:
Thick columns hewn from brick and dirt form tunnels in this labyrinthine cave. A jumble of overlapping hoofprints cover the blood-speckled dirt floor, and scratches mar the walls.

A Hostile @UUID[Actor.mmMinotaurOfBaph]{Minotaur of Baphomet} prowls amid the columns, stamping its hooves in the dirt and sharpening its horns on the walls. The minotaur charges the characters on sight and fights to the death. No amount of pleading, persuasion, or deceit can slake its bloodlust.

Secret Spoils.name: Secret Spoils
Secret Spoils.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.3PYE5hXz0m78dXfR caption=false classes="right three"]

A wooden chest sits on the floor of this chamber.

The chest was placed here by bandits who used this cave as a hideout until the minotaur arrived and slew them all.

Treasure. The chest contains [[/award 120GP]] and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

J: Gnoll Lair.name: J: Gnoll Lair
J: Gnoll Lair.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.2D58ku1tiqRHLfxB caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Poster Map: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveJGnollLa]{Cave J}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.2D58ku1tiqRHLfxB]{Cave J}

Evil gnolls—tall, shaggy fiends with hyenoid heads—have turned this abandoned shrine into their lair. The gnolls heard rumors that treasure is hidden somewhere in this cave, but they’ve been unable to find it due to an illusion placed by a long-dead mage. Vicious and hot-tempered, the gnolls have little patience for those who interrupt their search.

You can add monsters to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult. One or more @UUID[Actor.mmBugbearWarrior]{Bugbear Warriors} might have formed a tenuous alliance with the gnolls. Conversely, you can reduce the number of @UUID[Actor.mmGnollWarrior00]{Gnoll Warriors} to make the scenario easier and shorter.

Getting Started

Activate this cave's Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on the Scene.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

All is quiet outside the yawning mouth of this natural cave, at the back of which you can just make out a pair of featureless stone doors.

Gnoll Lair Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 10 feet high.

Doors. The doors to @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbJGnollLair00.JournalEntryPage.ymqKxjwPulaYdz5c]{area J2} are made of stone.

Environment. Past its entrance, the cave’s natural rock gives way to crumbling stone blocks and flagstone tiles. Its walls are decorated with painted motifs of grinning demons and marching skeletons.

Lighting. The cave is unlit, and its denizens rely on Darkvision to see. Area descriptions assume the characters have a light source or other means of seeing in Darkness.

Gnoll Lair Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
Set into the west wall of this natural cavern is a stone double door that is partly open. Bestial, high-pitched laughter echoes within.

The gnolls rigged the door with a makeshift alarm.

Door Alarm. This simple alarm consists of armor scraps and rusty weapons balanced atop the partly open double door. Moving either door triggers the trap, the rules for which are as follows:

Avoiding the Trap. A Medium or smaller creature can slip through the gap between the doors with a successful [[/skill acr 13]] check; failing this check triggers the trap.

Detect and Disable. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character can examine the door and make a [[/skill 13 prc]] check, detecting the trap on a successful check. Once detected, the trap can be disabled by a character who takes the &Reference[Utilize] action and succeeds on a [[/skill 13 slt]] check; failing this check triggers the trap.

Triggering the Trap. If the door is moved, the scraps clatter to the ground. The noise alerts all the gnolls in the cave, who cackle as they rush to dispatch intruders.

Junk Pile.name: Junk Pile
Junk Pile.text:
The center of this chamber’s floor is piled with loose junk—broken ceremonial implements, rusty candlestick holders, and rotten rags.

The gnolls piled objects here to sift through later.

DM Tip! If you increased this cave’s difficulty, one or more Hostile @UUID[Actor.mmBugbearWarrior]{Bugbear Warriors} might be here rummaging through the junk.

Old Chapel.name: Old Chapel
Old Chapel.text:
This forlorn chapel is unfurnished, though a slightly depressed section of floor near the southeast wall suggests an altar or some other heavy object once rested there.
Two tall warriors with mangy hides and hocked knees move about the chamber slowly, their hyena-like heads sniffing its walls.

Two @UUID[Actor.mmGnollWarrior00]{Gnoll Warriors} scour this chamber for secret doors. The Hostile gnolls lunge at intruders in a frenzy. Combat in this chamber draws the attention of the gnolls in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbJGnollLair00.JournalEntryPage.Rv9xTgMzTcZdjqtm]{area J4}, which quickly join the fray.

If the characters defeat all but one gnoll, the last of them surrenders. As an &Reference[Influence] action, a character can try to cow the gnoll into submission and make a [[/skill 13 itm]] check. On a successful check, the gnoll’s attitude improves to Indifferent, and the gnoll reveals that its pack was searching for “a prize hidden in the mouth of a laughing fiend.” On a failed check, the gnoll flees without divulging any information.

Shrine of the Laughing Devil.name: Shrine of the Laughing Devil
Shrine of the Laughing Devil.text:
A stone dais spans much of the south wall of this eerie shrine. Above the dais, a mosaic of black and red tiles depicts the face of a laughing devil whose forked tongue curls down to the dais.

Unless drawn elsewhere, two @UUID[Actor.mmGnollWarrior00]{Gnoll Warriors} pace about this chamber, frustrated in their fruitless search for treasure. The Hostile gnolls behave similarly to the pair in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbJGnollLair00.JournalEntryPage.KvtG3I6JAa9vyY2g]{area J3}; combat in this chamber draws those gnolls here.

Illusory Wall. The laughing devil face is an illusory wall; it looks real to the eye but has no substance. A creature that touches the illusory wall discovers its true nature and can pass right through it.

As a &Reference[Study] action, a character can make a [[/skill 15 inv]] check to discern the wall’s true nature. On a successful check, the character recognizes the wall is a magical illusion.

Hidden Crypt.name: Hidden Crypt
Hidden Crypt.text:
The devil’s face ripples to reveal a dusty crypt. Ancient bones and rubble litter the tiled floor. An austere sarcophagus stands in each corner, and an ornate chest rests in the center of the room.

Long ago, an evil mage reanimated the corpses of four explorers and commanded them to guard this crypt’s treasure for all eternity. Entombed here are four @UUID[Actor.mmZombie00000000]{Zombies}, one in each sarcophagus. Their Tokens start hidden and can be revealed if the players trigger them.

If the characters touch any of the sarcophagi or the chest, the Hostile zombies push the lids off their containers and start combat, seeking to rend intruders limb from limb.

Treasure. Among the debris is the skeleton of a human thief. The thief’s purse contains [[/award 15GP]] and a large @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbGem000000000]{gemstone}.

The chest is unlocked. It contains one magic item; draw a result from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

K: Shrine of Evil Chaos.name: K: Shrine of Evil Chaos
K: Shrine of Evil Chaos.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.PTR9UHEwrKbUurkj caption=false]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbCaveKShrineO]{Cave K}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.PTR9UHEwrKbUurkj]{Cave K}

The Cult of Chaos performs evil rites in this cave, subtly drawing monsters to inhabit the Caves of Chaos and bring strife to the Borderlands. The current cult leader is @UUID[Actor.hotbIvlis0000000]{Ivlis}, the keep’s former priest. Her cruel assistant, @UUID[Actor.hotbNarthus00000]{Narthus}, is always here, and other cultists dwell close by (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave]{cave G}). Undead guardians defend the shrine and the Chaos Bell—the source of the cult’s foul magic—at the shrine’s heart.

You can add monsters, such as @UUID[Actor.mmCultist0000000]{Cultists}, to the cave to make this scenario longer and more difficult, or you can reduce the number of @UUID[Actor.mmSkeleton000000]{Skeletons} or @UUID[Actor.mmZombie00000000]{Zombies} to make the scenario easier and shorter.

Getting Started

Activate this cave’s Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area shown on the Scene if the party approaches from outside the cave or on the stairs east of @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi.JournalEntryPage.bnd56aGBqKagaUWj]{area K5} if they arrive from @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbGShunnedCave]{cave G}.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

A foul draft issues from this cave. Red strata intertwine with bulging black veins running through the hewn rock. A sinister crimson light dances deep in the cave.

The stench issues from the rotting ogre in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi.JournalEntryPage.nSTCdE5cR3ATBGvv]{area K2}.

Shrine Features

The cave has the following features:

Ceilings. The cave’s ceilings are 20 feet high.

Doors and Secret Doors. Doors throughout this cave are made of heavy stone. The secret doors to @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi.JournalEntryPage.8Bn4Zk2sh5g6fxeI]{area K8} blend in with their surroundings but are obvious from inside area K8. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character can make a [[/skill 15 perception]] check to examine the wall for a secret door, noticing it on a successful check.

Environment. The cave instills a sense of unease in its visitors.

Lighting. Unless otherwise noted, Bright Light from red-flamed wall sconces fills the cave’s areas.

Shrine Locations

The following locations are keyed to the Scene.

Guarded Hallway.name: Guarded Hallway
Guarded Hallway.text:
The stench of death fills this hallway. Flies buzz around a groaning, slack-jawed giant backlit by red-flamed wall sconces.

An @UUID[Actor.mmOgreZombie0000]{Ogre Zombie} conscripted by the cultists to guard their nefarious acts stands watch here, but the undead brute is easily fooled.

The ogre zombie lets members of the Cult of Chaos pass unscathed, but it is Hostile toward entrants not garbed in the cult’s attire and pummels them on sight. The creature is Indifferent toward anyone wearing a cultist’s robe.

Chapel of Evil Chaos.name: Chapel of Evil Chaos
Chapel of Evil Chaos.text:
Four pillars support the domed roof of this empty chapel, where cultists conduct foul ceremonies.

DM Tip! If you increased this cave’s difficulty, two or more Hostile @UUID[Actor.mmCultist0000000]{Cultists} might be in the midst of an unholy ceremony here.

Undead Barrack.name: Undead Barrack
Undead Barrack.text: Four @UUID[Actor.mmZombie00000000]{Zombies} shamble restlessly in this bare chamber. They fight any non-Undead not garbed in the cult’s attire but are Indifferent toward anyone wearing a cultist’s robe.

Altar of Evil Chaos.name: Altar of Evil Chaos
Altar of Evil Chaos.text:
Violet draperies curtain this chamber. Three stone altars stand before a dais topped with five chairs: four rickety seats made of bone flanking a high-backed throne. An ominous, black iron bell hangs from a stand near the middle of the room.
Piles of humanoid bones are arranged neatly near the north wall. A cultist flecks the bones with blood while intoning a demonic chant.

@UUID[Actor.hotbNarthus00000]{Narthus} chants evil litanies in this impious chamber. He is Hostile toward the characters, even if they’re garbed in cult attire; Narthus screens every new cultist and knows his fellow cult members well.

If the characters interrupt the ritual, Narthus decries them as blasphemers and starts combat. On his turn, Narthus tries to ring the Chaos Bell, causing the bones to animate (see the “Chaos Bell” section).

Chaos Bell. Hanging from the stand is the Chaos Bell, a profane relic whose toll can wake the dead.

As a Bonus Action, a creature within 5 feet of the Chaos Bell can ring it, causing the bone piles to knit together and arise as four Hostile Skeletons. The tolling bell also summons the @UUID[Actor.mmZombie00000000]{Zombies} in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi.JournalEntryPage.NhtvelioptLtmSEb]{area K4} to the fray. The skeletons and zombies obey Narthus’s commands.

The Chaos Bell is all but indestructible. To destroy the bell and end its magic, the characters must submerge it in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion2Woods.JournalEntryPage.XQht3e1JSq6F1ePK]{sacred spring}. If a character removes the bell from its stand, give that player the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbChaosBell000]{Chaos Bell}.

Ring the Chaos Bell

Use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.macros.Macro.hotbCaveKRingCha]{Ring Chaos Bell} Macro to ring the Chaos Bell and toggle the bone piles into Skeletons and back to bone piles by running it again.

Visitor’s Chamber.name: Visitor’s Chamber
Visitor’s Chamber.text: This room has comfortable chairs and a low table. Cult leaders interview potential new recruits here.

Cult Leader’s Room.name: Cult Leader’s Room
Cult Leader’s Room.text:
This opulent chamber contains a large bed, desk, and wardrobe. A ghastly demon head is mounted on the wall. Kneeling before the demon is a human woman wearing bloodred robes and a spidery headdress.

@UUID[Actor.hotbIvlis0000000]{Ivlis}, leader of the Cult of Chaos, lives here. Each day, she pays tribute to the severed demon head mounted on the wall, which she talks to when no one’s around. Ivlis is Hostile toward the characters.

If confronted, Ivlis first tries to tempt the party with promises of untold riches and power, claiming all things are possible through the Cult of Chaos. She urges the characters to submit to the cult and become Undead. If they refuse, she fights.

Fighting Ivlis. In combat, the sneering cult leader fights arrogantly and doesn’t hold back. If reduced to 15 Hit Points or fewer, however, she tries to flee the cave through @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi.JournalEntryPage.8Bn4Zk2sh5g6fxeI]{area K8} via the secret door. If Ivlis escapes, she attempts to revive the cult elsewhere.

Treasure. The demon head pivots to reveal a nook with [[/award 100GP]], a large @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbGem000000000]{red garnet} (give the players one Gemstone), and two magic items; draw two results from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the items.

Secret “Treasure”.name: Secret “Treasure”
Secret “Treasure”.text:
This hidden room contains only a black iron chest. When a creature moves within 5 feet of the chest, it springs opens and spills [[/award 300GP]] across the floor.

Treasure. The coins are cheap counterfeits intended to slow greedy pursuers. A cursory examination of the coins reveals them as fakes.

Getting Started.name: Getting Started
Getting Started.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbKeepOnTheBor]{Keep on the Borderlands}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.ShSj34GxQG9CaZr1]{Keep on the Borderlands}

Rising from rugged crags amid a harsh countryside, the Keep on the Borderlands is a bastion of peace amid an otherwise brutal wilderness. The keep’s stalwart defenders protect their community from the forces of chaos that would revel in its fall.

DM Secret! This book is for the Dungeon Master’s eyes only. Unless text appears in a read-aloud box (like the one below), don’t read it to the players.

Getting Started

Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbKeepOnTheBor]{Keep on the Borderlands} Scene for the players to see. This map displays all the locations characters can visit in the keep.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

You ascend a winding road through a forested and mountainous country. Ahead, atop a sheer-walled stone plateau, looms a great and stoic keep. Armed sentries along the outer wall peer down at you, ready to welcome new heroes or repel would-be invaders.

Two armed guards stand at the front gate. They hail you and motion for you to approach.

The player characters start just outside the keep. The first time they arrive at the keep, the characters must proceed to the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.6KnKrSo2at9x4e2o]{outer gatehouse}, which functions as a tutorial with helpful sidebars. You can skip this location for subsequent visits to the keep unless the player characters want to return to it.

After the characters visit the gatehouse or whenever they return to the keep, have the players choose a location shown on the Scene. The Keep Locations table summarizes noteworthy sites within the keep in the order they appear within this journal. Each location provides approximately 30–60 minutes of gameplay, depending on the nature of the characters’ visit.

Once the player characters choose a location, open that location in this journal and review any components in its “What You Need to Play” section.

Keep Locations

Location

Description

1

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.6KnKrSo2at9x4e2o]{Outer Gatehouse}

Guards vet entrants and keep watch at this gate.

2

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.IHwLDH3sR0GVeHJq]{Barn}

Livestock and steeds are stabled and groomed here.

3

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.HFTSFYGVWJfdhFD4]{Private Apartments}

These modest apartments house long-term residents.

4

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.Jlxc5y05alQVoipj]{Smithy}

A blacksmith crafts metalwork goods here.

5

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.wOTSso2JzjUOUICl]{Provisioner’s Shop}

This messy, halfling-owned shop specializes in gear.

6

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.XcV5wht7ZUcsPYFW]{Trader’s Shop}

This trading post sells armor and weapons.

7

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.60Ulwg6LCRQDKkmi]{Bank}

The keep’s citizens store their valuables at this bank.

8

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.maGc5sM03P63UapU]{Traveler’s Inn}

Travelers can rent rooms at this cozy inn.

9

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.LNo9oqU4G6ZH1LGu]{Tavern}

Patrons flock to this rowdy tavern for food and drink.

10

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.ODAPxGUu1IeINDso]{Guild House}

Merchants and artisans assemble in this guildhall.

11

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.BJ9gbFmkqqjejT34]{Temple}

Priests offer guidance and healing in this house of worship.

12

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.kzP9sVObAtUjrh5X]{Inner Gatehouse}

This fortification is the keep’s last line of defense.

13

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.ZwITgv4VXBFvGSq4]{Inner Bailey}

The keep’s guards live and train in this enclosed court.

14

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.SBrXpoLzTOv5GyYJ]{Fortress}

The castellan governs the keep from this stronghold.

Outer Gatehouse.name: Outer Gatehouse
Outer Gatehouse.text:
What You Need to Play

NPCs: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.mWEcu22JQpq1sRy6]{Bartho} and @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.zlhX82NCLDClUIuS]{Gala}

1

This gatehouse is the first stop for those seeking to enter the Keep on the Borderlands. The guards here greet outsiders, watch for potential threats, and permit entrance to citizens and peaceful visitors.

2

When the characters arrive at the outer gatehouse, read the following boxed text aloud:

Two stone towers flank an archway that leads into the keep. A sturdy-looking gatehouse spans the archway and connects the towers. A wooden drawbridge allows passage over a steep ditch surrounding the keep. The bridge is currently drawn shut.

Two guards stand before the raised bridge. As you approach, one of the guards shouts, “Hail! Do you bring peace or trouble?”

3

The guards are Bartho and Gala. The characters must respond to the guards and say whether they mean well or ill. After confirming the characters are well-meaning adventurers, Bartho and Gala call for the drawbridge to be lowered, then welcome the party to the keep.

4

Gatehouse Features

5

The gatehouse has the following features:

Drawbridge. The keep’s first line of defense is a steep ditch, 10 feet wide and 10 feet deep, in front of the fortress. The only sure means to cross the dry moat is the drawbridge at this gatehouse.

Gate. The stone arch behind the drawbridge contains an iron portcullis and large oak doors.

Towers. Stairs inside each square, 30-foot-tall tower connect the ground floor to the roof. Arrow slits in the tower walls and roof battlements help archers defend the keep.

Gatehouse Services

6

The gatehouse offers the following services:

Lower the Drawbridge. The drawbridge usually remains raised night and day. To lower or raise the bridge, wheels in both towers must be turned to release or tighten the drawbridge’s chains. The portcullis operates in a similar manner.

Orientation. The gate guards, Bartho and Gala, can describe and give directions to any location in the keep. They can also tailor recommendations to a traveler’s needs. For example, if a character wants to purchase weapons or armor, the guards point them to the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.XcV5wht7ZUcsPYFW]{trader’s shop}.

What You Need to Play. Review the items listed here before you begin play.

1

Summary. The beginning of each cave presents its central conflict, as well as optional ways to increase or decrease the difficulty. If the characters are level 1, don’t increase the difficulty.

2

Boxed Text. Text that appears in a box like the one to the left is meant to be read aloud or paraphrased for the players when their characters first arrive at a location or under a specific circumstance, as described in the text.

3

Bold Terms. When a game component’s name appears in Bold type, that’s a visual cue to say, “Hey, DM, this is going to be important soon.”

4

Features. This section presents special features about the location. Some of these exist to help you set the mood—you might describe the crunch of animal bones under the characters’ feet—while others detail important rules, such as secret doors and how to find them.

5

Services Each location offers unique services. Shops typically offer goods for sale, which might be associated with a handout in this set, while other locations offer more abstract benefits. An NPC at the location can summarize its services to the characters.

6

Exploration and Movement Exploration is open-ended; the players don’t take turns moving around the keep the way they do in combat. Instead, players simply say where they want their characters to go. None of the locations within the keep has or requires its own map; as DM, you help the players visualize these places through your descriptions.

6

Barn.name: Barn
Barn.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.O8PSXE6FJGO37cOx caption=false classes="right three"]

What You Need to Play

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.5o7LSGGkvVfPn2su]{Cornflower}

This barn shelters the keep’s livestock. It also serves merchants and travelers who need a place to stable their mounts while visiting the keep. Animals housed at the barn receive a box stall or pen, food, and grooming.

When the characters arrive at the barn, read the following boxed text aloud:

Animals snuffle, cluck, oink, and moo inside the stalls of this spacious barn, which smells of leather and manure. A freckled halfling woman uses a pitchfork to unload hay from a nearby wagon into an empty stall. She wipes the sweat from her brow and extends a hearty greeting.

The halfling is Cornflower, the barn hand.

Barn Features

The barn has the following features:

Box Stalls. The barn has roomy stalls for up to six Large mounts.

Livestock Pens. Cows, chickens, pigs, and other barn animals occupy several livestock pens.

Loft. Golden piles of hay are stored in a loft above the animal enclosures.

Trough. Stabled animals drink water from a common trough along the stalls.

Barn Services

The barn offers the following services:

Chores. Once per day, the characters can assist Cornflower with chores around the barn, such as collecting freshly laid eggs, feeding and grooming animals, and milking cows and goats. In exchange for their help, Cornflower pays them [[/award 1GP]] each.

Dairy Products. For 1 GP, Cornflower sells a pail’s worth of milk or a slab of freshly churned goat butter (customer’s choice).

Hit the Hay. Cornflower sympathizes with travelers who can’t afford to stay at the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.maGc5sM03P63UapU]{inn}. She lets them sleep in the loft for free.

Private Apartments.name: Private Apartments
Private Apartments.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.vCuKqVaduP5ioWqD caption=false classes="right three"]

What You Need to Play

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.0SpEYRLrHK7pKQ87]{Lenk}

Residents and long-term visitors rent apartments in this tenement building. The complex’s most notable resident is also its landlord, a crotchety jeweler who invests in gemstones and other valuables.

When the characters arrive at the apartments, read the following boxed text aloud:

A wooden jeweler’s sign hangs over an open door in the front of this two-story building. Inside, an old human man hunches over a table, peering at an emerald through a jeweler’s loupe.

The jeweler, Lenk, puts down his loupe with a sigh and invites the characters in.

Apartments Features

The apartments have the following features:

Apartments. Each two-story apartment is a section of the same large tenement building. The apartments have identical amenities: a stove, a small drawing room, a bedroom, and a storage area.

Rain Barrel. A large barrel near the building holds clean water for washing dishes and clothes.

Apartments Services

The apartments offer the following services:

Buy Gems. Lenk can buy gems the characters find in their adventures. He pays [[/award 100GP]] for every @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbGem000000000]{Gemstone} exchanged at this location; this rate includes Lenk’s appraisal fee.

Rent an Apartment. Characters can rent an apartment for 100 GP per month.

Smithy.name: Smithy
Smithy.text:
What You Need to Play

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.kxuT4yEfpoeozPPF]{Kalista}

The smithy is where the keep’s residents purchase metal goods and have them repaired.

When the characters arrive at the smithy, read the following boxed text aloud:

The stench of hot smoke and the sound of clanging metal fill this smithy. Lit by the orange glow of a forge, a dark-haired dwarf pounds a molten ingot at an anvil behind a low wooden counter. Sparks fly with every strike of her hammer.

The hard-working smith is Kalista.

Smithy Features

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.2qGjO8CzvMvXTkYw caption=false classes="right three"]

The smithy has the following features:

Forge. The large forge behind the counter fills most of the smithy’s lower floor. Water barrels and bellows flank the forge.

Mundane Goods. A few stout posts support the upper floor. They bear hanging tools and everyday metal goods: cast-iron pots, horseshoes, and so on.

Private Rooms. Two doors at the rear of the smithy lead to storerooms containing ingots and spare tools. A third door opens to a washbasin and spiral stairs that ascend to Kalista’s quarters.

Smithy Services

The smithy offers the following service:

Leather Branding. For 1 GP, Kalista can brand anything made of leather, such as Leather Armor or a Spellbook, with the keep’s coat of arms.

Kalista makes armaments but doesn’t sell them. She forges them exclusively for the keep’s armed forces.

Provisioner's Shop.name: Provisioner's Shop
Provisioner's Shop.text:
What You Need to Play

Handout: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.680bSZ0oqo92mhRE]{Provisioner}

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.GVjKHu0oYZJI1r2L]{Ruckus}

This cluttered shop provides supplies for travelers who venture into the wilderness.

When the characters arrive at the shop, read the following boxed text aloud:

Dusty rays of sunlight stream into this general store through small windows near the ceiling. Barrels, bottles, boxes, and other supplies crowd its shelves.

An affable halfling named Ruckus runs this shop.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.TvCzY8En78mSUda5 caption=false classes="right three"]

Shop Features

The shop has the following features:

Brimming with Supplies. Everyday supplies fill the shop’s packed interior. Shelves, crates, chests, and cabinets overflow with clothes, blankets, tools, trinkets, toys, and other miscellaneous junk.

Private Rooms. A side entrance leads to a few low rooms where Ruckus lives.

Storage. A storeroom door toward the back of the shop is roped off and bears a hastily scrawled sign that reads, “WARNING! FIRE GHOST. STAY OUT!” Inside the storeroom, jumbled goods cram floor-to-ceiling shelves.

Shop Services

The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.680bSZ0oqo92mhRE]{Provisioner Handout} lists items available for sale. Give this handout to the players whenever they visit this location. Ruckus might point proudly at some of the illustrations to invite comment about how nice they look.

Trader's Shop.name: Trader's Shop
Trader's Shop.text:
WHAT YOU NEED TO PLAY

Handout: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.0TDCiAYVkTQ00Pj8]{Trader}

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.pY8wVhXUZuEZ6o0Q]{Oleira}

Only bold traders bring goods to the Borderlands.

When the characters arrive at the shop, read the following boxed text aloud:

Awnings extend over weapon racks and armor stands at this trader’s shop. Inside, a tall human woman polishes a suit of armor with an oily rag.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.aIaCQIzmTm3rKkiy caption=false classes="right two"]

The woman is Oleira, the shop’s owner. The trader’s shop is a family business. She runs it with her two teenage sons, Derlo and Ulmar, who dream of being brave knights rather than shopkeepers.

Shop Features

The trader’s shop has the following features:

Indoor Display. The shop interior contains minor luxuries such as salt, spices, cloth, and furniture, which Oleira sells only to citizens of the keep. The goods are clean and well organized.

Outdoor Display. When the shop is open, Oleira displays armor and weapons under the awning.

Warehouse. Behind the shop is a small warehouse, where Oleira receives, sorts, and stores goods.

Shop Services

The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.0TDCiAYVkTQ00Pj8]{Trader Handout} lists items available for sale. Give this handout to the players whenever they visit this location.

Bank.name: Bank
Bank.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.7kX8hvV9vbceq31x caption=false classes="right three"]

What You Need to Play

NPCs: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.yZ2qTw1y25wyxQ4G]{Quink} and @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.wYaQWdYGrjtioFgZ]{Yvette}

The keep’s residents and visitors store their most valuable belongings and savings in the bank.

When the characters arrive at the bank, read the following boxed text aloud:

This one-story bank sports a teller’s window with a drop-down counter. A bespectacled halfling woman in a silk tabard sits behind the glass. Outside, a bored human guard stands watch.

The banker, Quink, relies on the keep’s soldiers for protection. Yvette is stationed here most days to discourage anyone from hassling Quink.

Bank Features

The bank has the following features:

Service Counter. Sturdy hinges connect a wooden drop-down counter to the bank’s window. At night, Quink folds up the counter and closes the window, then secures both with an iron grate.

Vault. A locked, reinforced door connects the bank teller’s office to Quink’s private quarters and a vault. Inside the vault are several strongboxes containing [[/award 250GP]] worth of deposited wealth.

Bank Services

The bank offers the following services:

Take Out a Loan. A character can borrow up to 10 GP from the bank with an interest rate of 1 GP per day. There’s no minimum payment due, but if the loan is left unpaid for long, word of the character’s financial insolvency spreads throughout the keep.

Deposit and Withdraw Money. A character can deposit gold and other valuables at the bank. They can withdraw some or all the deposited savings during regular business hours at no cost.

Traveler's Inn.name: Traveler's Inn
Traveler's Inn.text:
What You Need to Play

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.ZXoHwEtCrVkwhziO]{Haldryck}

This inn caters to weary travelers, merchants, and adventurers. It offers a range of accommodations depending on a customer’s budget.

When the characters arrive at the inn, read the following boxed text aloud:

The smell of soap and lavender fills this warm inn. The front door opens to a lobby staffed by a stout dwarf behind a lacquered wooden counter with a shiny call bell.
“Greetings,” the dwarf says in a deep voice. “Are you looking to book a bed for the night?”

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.nRTpzpILgcBXgmmB caption=false classes="right three"]

The dwarf is Haldryck, the innkeeper.

Inn Features

The inn has the following features:

Common Room. The common sleeping area is a large, open room with a handful of stiff cots and a crackling hearth. Patrons can also lay out their own sleeping mats on the floor for a safe—albeit uncomfortable—night’s sleep.

Private Rooms. Customers with gold to spare can sleep in one of the inn’s six private rooms. Each well-appointed room has four beds. Haldryck boasts that the beds in these rooms are bug free.

Wares. Haldryck rents and sells various bedding items, including wool blankets, woven sleeping mats, and pillows stuffed with goose down.

Inn Services

The inn offers the following services:

Rent a Cot. Cots in the common room are available to rent for 1 GP per night. Roll [[/gmroll 1d4]] for each character who rents a cot. On a 1, the character finds a dead bug on their pillow.

Rent a Room. A private room costs 5 GP per night. Roll [[/gmroll 1d4]] for each character who rents a room. On a 4, the character finds [[/award 1GP]] under their mattress.

Tavern.name: Tavern
Tavern.text:
What You Need to Play

Handout: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.b3EbPYiFE8lxwEfg]{Drunken Dragon}

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.ApP2P4jmmLPc8Qsq]{Umbrusk}

Dubbed the Drunken Dragon, this tavern caters to residents and visitors alike and hosts a nightly drinking game.

When the characters arrive at the tavern, read the following boxed text aloud:

The aroma of cooked mutton, fresh bread, and stiff ale wafts from this bustling tavern’s doors. Inside, retired soldiers, chatty merchants, and weary travelers dot the taproom. A raised stage in one corner is empty.

A human man in an apron greets you from behind the bar. “Welcome to the Drunken Dragon. What can I getcha?” he asks in a smooth voice.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.94w5Cg3fdqsqXG5p caption=false classes="right three"]

The man behind the bar is Umbrusk. After taking the characters’ orders, Umbrusk invites them to play @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.my57NHH8c7rin0tU]{chug champion}.

Tavern Features

The tavern has the following features:

Taproom. The tavern’s taproom holds a sticky bar counter, ten round tables, and forty chairs in varying states of disrepair.

Kitchen. In addition to hired cooks, Umbrusk’s staff includes patrons who couldn’t pay their tabs. They all work in a cramped, greasy kitchen behind a swinging door near the bar.

Stage. There’s no formal vetting process for who can use the stage; the taproom’s rowdy patrons loudly express their enthusiasm—or disdain—for anyone brave enough to perform.

Tavern Services

The tavern offers the following services:

Food and Drink. The tavern sells the items listed on the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.b3EbPYiFE8lxwEfg]{Drunken Dragon Handout}. Give this handout to your players whenever they visit this location.

Buy the House a Round. For 20 GP, a character can buy a drink for everyone in the taproom. For the next 24 hours, that character has Advantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks made in the keep.

Solicit Rumors. Once per day, a character in the tavern can make a [[/skill 10 per]] check to glean a rumor from the bartender or a chatty patron. On a successful check, roll on the Tavern Rumors table to determine the rumor they learn. The rumor’s veracity is noted in parentheses; don’t read that part out loud.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbTavernRumors rollable]

Guild House.name: Guild House
Guild House.text:
What You Need to Play

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.M9OZjEVM7tLRPmal]{Toryn}

This guild house offers membership to merchants and artisans, who enjoy benefits such as workshop space, library access, and armed escorts.

When the characters arrive at the guild house, read the following boxed text aloud:

Well-oiled oak beams crisscross the high ceilings of this stately guild house. Quiet murmurs and the sounds of crafting echo among workshops. A staircase ascends to a modest library.
A human woman in a wheelchair emerges from an adjacent office and politely greets you.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.EEI5M4HeN66cqe4H caption=false classes="right three"]

The greeter is the guildmaster, Toryn.

Guild House Features

The guild house has the following features:

Administration. Toryn oversees the guild from a polished but cluttered oak desk in an office with a private elevator.

Library. The guild holds the largest collection of books and scrolls in the keep.

Workshops. Guild members ply their trades in 10-foot-square sections of a spacious room partitioned by hanging curtains.

Guild House Services

The guild house offers the following services:

Customize Equipment. A character can hire an artisan to customize their equipment, such as emblazoning a Shield with a symbol of their choice or embellishing the binding of a Spellbook. The standard rate is 5 GP per piece of equipment.

Research. The library contains books on history, magic, and the creatures of the Borderlands. For 1 GP, a character can spend 1 hour researching in the library. The next time that characters takes the &Reference[Study] action relating to a subject covered by the library’s books, they have Advantage on the Intelligence check made as part of that action. A character can benefit from this only once per day.

Temple.name: Temple
Temple.text:
What You Need to Play

Handout: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.NbZeI2Ji1ThAjPJP]{Sacred Services}

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.jFFvX4PW8YXOtym9]{Fazzir}

The temple meets the spiritual needs of the keep. The curate, a human man named Fazzir, guides the temple’s daily activities, which include conducting ceremonies, healing injured soldiers, and offering counsel in matters of ethics and morality.

When the characters arrive at the temple, read the following boxed text aloud:

The interior of this tall building has a lofty, majestic air. Rows of benches face an altar at the end of a spacious worship hall. Above the altar is an enormous stained-glass window of a sunrise.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.Gfy9Xt1Oq2U1VIdC caption=false classes="right three"]

Until recently, the temple’s head priest was a human woman named @UUID[Actor.hotbIvlis0000000]{Ivlis}, but she recently departed the keep on a long-anticipated pilgrimage.

DM Secret! Ivlis secretly leads the Cult of Chaos, an evil cult that feeds on destruction and disarray. Her supposed religious journey is a cover for her occult activities, which are detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos}.

Temple Features

The temple has the following features:

Alms Box. A stout pole near the temple’s entrance holds a small box for visitors to leave donations. At any given time, the alms box contains [[/award 1d8GP]]. The box is unlocked. A character who steals from the alms box must succeed on a [[/save 15 wis]] saving throw or have Disadvantage on D20 Tests for the next 24 hours.

Sanctuary. This spiritual center can accommodate dozens of worshipers. Fazzir delivers sermons from the altar each dawn. His simple lessons appeal to a variety of religious traditions.

Underground Accommodations. Fazzir inhabits modest rooms in the temple’s cellar. The cellar also contains two small spare rooms. Fazzir uses these rooms as infirmaries or guest quarters as circumstances demand.

Temple Services

The @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.NbZeI2Ji1ThAjPJP]{Sacred Services Handout} lists available goods and services. Give this handout to the players whenever they visit this location. Fazzir provides the temple’s healing and revival services as detailed in his @UUID[Actor.hotbFazzir000000]{character sheet}.

Good-Faith Discounts

It’s unlikely that the characters will accumulate the gold required to revive a party member. At the DM’s discretion, Fazzir might waive any of the fees on the Sacred Services Handout for those he believes show heroic potential.

Inner Gatehouse.name: Inner Gatehouse
Inner Gatehouse.text:
What You Need to Play

NPC Card:@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.a1gOVKXrvzfgImZ9]{Andrella}

This gatehouse houses on-duty soldiers and separates the civilian areas of the keep from the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.ZwITgv4VXBFvGSq4]{inner bailey}.

When the characters arrive at the inner gatehouse, read the following boxed text aloud:

This gatehouse consists of a broad stone archway framed by a squat building constructed along the keep’s inner wall. Battlements line its flat roof, atop which two guards stand watch.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.w82Qsgt7aCSBM8wk caption=false classes="right three"]

The guards ask the characters about their business, then escort them to Andrella, Captain of the Guard.

Gatehouse Features

The gatehouse has the following features:

Garrison. Twenty-four soldiers, including Captain Andrella, are garrisoned in the gatehouse.

Gate. The gate features a massive oak double door. During invasions, soldiers can bar the doors with a heavy timber beam from the other side.

Murder Holes. Guards atop the gatehouse can thrust spears down at invaders through holes in the ceiling of the archway.

Gatehouse Services

The gatehouse offers the following service:

Requisition Uniforms. Characters who pledge to defend the keep can requisition uniforms from Andrella free of charge. Give those players one @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbBorderlandsT]{Borderlands Tabard} each.

Inner Bailey.name: Inner Bailey
Inner Bailey.text:
What You Need to Play

NPC Card: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.WrAC0MHei6IVRzDZ]{Shannik}

The sheltered inner bailey is where the keep’s defenders live and practice combat drills.

When the characters arrive at the inner bailey, read the following boxed text aloud:

Targets and practice dummies dot this courtyard, which contains a large stable and poles with hanging rings. Cavalry soldiers train atop horseback while guards watch the area from the walls and towers that rise around it.

A mountain of a man in heavy armor tromps up to you. “No lollygagging!” he grouses.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.xL7jkg0uaqR2RTZF caption=false classes="right three"]

The man is the keep’s demanding and curmudgeonly sergeant of the guard, Shannik.

Inner Bailey Features

The inner bailey has the following features:

Cavalry Stable. The bailey contains a stable with thirty horses. These war-trained horses serve as mounts for the keep’s cavalry.

Guard Towers. Four towers rise above the bailey, one in each corner. The smallest, to the southeast, holds up to eight guards. The southwest and northeast towers each hold one dozen guards, as well as food stores and other supplies. The Great Tower to the northwest is 60 feet tall.

Watches. Six soldiers, two atop each tower, watch over the inner bailey at all hours. Use the @UUID[Actor.mmGuard000000000]{Guard} for these soldiers if necessary.

Inner Bailey Services

The inner bailey offers the following service:

Weapon Upgrade. The keep ordered too many crossbows, which untrained recruits can’t wield effectively. Shannik wants to trade the weapons for simpler ones. In exchange for 25 GP and a Shortbow, he can provide a character with a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.phbwepHandCrossb]{Hand Crossbow}.

Fortress.name: Fortress
Fortress.text:
What You Need to Play

Handout: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.gDcWIFbomehF4PrD]{Castellan’s Letter}

NPCs: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.fH9f0I0UUsRy53mU]{Dwern}, @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.znsxDE6HsMitGbE3]{Elandra}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.7FaINJ8FBS2V8pfJ]{Winvarle}

The castellan governs the keep from its fortress, a stone stronghold solidly built to withstand assault. Multiple towers rise above the main building, which is 30 feet tall. The fortress shelters emergency resources, municipal chambers, and the keep’s armed forces. Militaristic banners and upholstered furniture decorate its dignified interior.

When the characters arrive at the keep fortress, read the following boxed text aloud:

Two round towers with pointed roofs flank this tiered stronghold. Archers march along its stone parapets, watching for signs of trouble. Two guards stand outside the fortress’s iron doors; they acknowledge passersby with stern nods.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.16AScibP6pWrh8Wt]

Fortress Features

The fortress has the following features:

Armory. Barding and lances for the keep’s cavalry—thirty troops strong—are stored here, though the equipment is off-limits to the characters.

Barracks. Sparsely furnished quarters throughout the fortress can collectively accommodate up to thirty-six soldiers at once.

Great Hall. A spacious hall in the fortress hosts ceremonies, proclamations, and other receptions.

Private Chambers. Two lavishly decorated rooms are reserved for guests of the keep, while another belongs to the castellan.

Towers. Two peaked towers rise from the fortress.

Undercroft. Beneath the fortress are cellars containing vast provision stores, a cistern, and a dungeon with four stout cells for detainees and prisoners. If Yvette was arrested at @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.60Ulwg6LCRQDKkmi]{the bank}, she is detained in one of the cells.

Fortress Services

The fortress offers the following services:

Defense. In times of crisis, the castellan can muster up to thirty-six trained soldiers from the fortress to defend the keep. The fortress also provides refuge during incursions.

Seat of Government. During the day, the castellan and his two assistants conduct business in the main building, where they hold audience with citizens and visitors of the keep.

Quest: Dangerous Stowaway.name: Quest: Dangerous Stowaway
Quest: Dangerous Stowaway.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbDangerousSto]{Trail}

As the characters browse Oleira’s wares, she offers them each [[/award 1GP]] to unload a wagon while her sons are off watching soldiers train elsewhere in the keep. The delivery is late, so Oleira tells the characters to meet the wagon along the trail.

Unknown to Oleira, the shipment contains a dangerous stowaway. During transit, a nasty ooze slithered onto the wagon and gobbled up its driver. Oozes usually lurk in dark places like caves or dungeons, but they go wherever they can sate their voracious appetites.

Ooze Surprise

If the characters agree, the guards at the outer gate nod at them as they exit the keep and head down the trail. When the characters come across the wagon, read the following boxed text aloud:

You find the wagon standing in the middle of the trail with no driver in sight. Some of the crates in the wagon glisten wetly.

A @UUID[Actor.mmGrayOoze000000]{Gray Ooze Glob} lurks within the abandoned wagon, waiting to ambush the characters. When the characters approach the wagon, the ooze seeps from the supplies with a hideous squelching noise and fights the characters. Roll Initiative!

Preparing for Combat. To run this combat encounter, do the following:

1: Activate the Scene. Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbDangerousSto]{Trail Map} for the players to see.

2: Place Tokens. Have the players place their Player Character Tokens on the map anywhere within 15 feet of the wagon.

3: Reveal the Monster's Token. The Monster Token is hidden at the start. Reveal it to your players and open its character sheet.

Use the Combat Tracker and the “@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbCombat0000000]{Combat}” section of the Play Guide to run this encounter.

Reward

After defeating the ooze, carting the goods is straightforward work. When the characters return to Oleira, she’s shocked to learn of the ooze—she or her sons could’ve been seriously harmed.

To show her gratitude, Oleira exceeds her original offer, paying each character [[/award 5GP]] for their heroism.

Quest: Breaking the Bank.name: Quest: Breaking the Bank
Quest: Breaking the Bank.text:
After detailing the services he offers, Lenk tells the characters he’s exploring a new line of business. Read the following boxed text aloud:

“With reports of bandits along the trail and the occasional thief here in the keep, I plan to sell strongboxes to help citizens and travelers secure their valuables. I’ve received a few samples made by local crafters who hope to partner with me in this new venture, but I won’t stake my reputation on shoddy handiwork.

“I need to determine which of the strongboxes are fit for sale, and you look like a capable lot. Care to test your mettle on some metal?”

If the characters agree, Lenk hands each of them a locked iron strongbox and instructs them to try to pilfer its contents however they please. Each strongbox contains a modest amount of gold. If a character can get into a strongbox, they can keep its contents, though Lenk doesn’t reveal what’s inside.

Cracking the Strongboxes

A character can make one attempt to open a strongbox through any of the following means:

Breaking the Strongbox. Each strongbox is a Tiny object with AC 19, 5 HP, Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage, and Vulnerability to Cold damage. A character who reduces a strongbox to 0 Hit Points with a single attack or spell destroys the strongbox but not its contents.

Picking the Lock (Rogue Only). A Rogue can use Thieves’ Tools to pick the strongbox’s lock, doing so with a successful [[/tool 15 ability=dexterity slt tool=thief]].

Prying Open the Lid. A character can force open a strongbox’s lid with a successful [[/skill 15 ath]] check.

At the DM’s discretion, other methods of opening a strongbox might exist.

Reward

Inside each strongbox is [[/award 5GP]]. If the characters manage to penetrate all the strongboxes, Lenk grouses about the boxes’ poor craftsmanship. If all the strongboxes thwart their attempts, Lenk pays each character [[/award 1GP]] as a consolation and says there are nobler skills to master than thievery.

Quest: Tools of Destruction.name: Quest: Tools of Destruction
Quest: Tools of Destruction.text:
If a character asks to purchase armor or weapons, Kalista explains why she no longer sells those to outsiders. Read the following boxed text aloud:

“I used to sell arms and armor to would-be heroes like you. I had heard reports of foolhardy adventurers falling victim to brigands and monsters. I shrugged those stories off for a time.
“Last winter, the castellan’s forces thwarted an assault on the keep. After the onslaught, I was sickened to learn that many of the attackers’ weapons bore my maker’s mark. By selling to outsiders, I had unwittingly armed our enemies. I vowed then never to forge another weapon for anyone but the keep’s soldiers. I haven’t since.”

The keep’s soldiers occasionally bring confiscated weapons to Kalista for destruction.

Weapon Smelting

Kalista recently received a cartload of battered and rusted weapons seized by the keep’s defenders. She asks the characters to help melt them down.

The disarmament process takes 1 hour. To aid Kalista with it, the characters must succeed on the following ability checks in this order:

[[/skill 13 ath]]. The character piles the weapons in the forge and undertakes the tough labor needed to properly melt them down.

[[/skill 13 slt]]. The character carefully tips a crucible of molten metal into an ingot mold without spillage.

If at least one character succeeds on each check, the party completes the disarmament. The characters can retry failed checks, but if they accumulate three failures, Kalista dismisses them with a sigh, insisting she can handle the rest of the job herself.

If the characters successfully help Kalista destroy the weapons, she pays them each [[/award 5GP]].

Quest: Fire Ghost.name: Quest: Fire Ghost
Quest: Fire Ghost.text:
If the characters don’t bring up the unusual sign on the storeroom door, Ruckus soon mentions it and asks for their help in resolving the matter. Read the following boxed text aloud:

“I’ve been smelling smoke in the storeroom for the past few days. Yesterday I peeked inside and saw a cloaked figure smoldering like an ember—surely it was a fire ghost! I threw a flagon of ale at it to put out the fire, but I haven’t dared to enter the room since. Someone braver than me should lay the ghost to rest. Maybe you could do it?”

The “Ghost”

The only thing haunting the shopkeeper is his own reckless disorganization. Ruckus recently relocated some inventory to a shelf in his storeroom; the merchandise included a hefty magnifying glass. On sunny days, the light through a high window focuses through the lens on a dusty old cloak, causing it to smolder. It’s a major fire hazard.

Ruckus’s decision to leave the storeroom alone compounds the danger. If the problem isn’t dealt with soon, a conflagration is inevitable.

Investigating the Scene

Characters can get at the truth by investigating the jumbled storeroom, where they discover a singed cloak stained with dried ale.

Gathering Clues. Characters in the storeroom can gather clues by succeeding on one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 13 nat]]. At noon each day, sunlight from the window shines on the cloak.

[[/skill 12 prc]]. High on a shelf near the storeroom window, a magnifying glass protrudes from an open box.

Solving the Case

After inspecting the storeroom, the characters can draw their conclusions. A character who considers the evidence and succeeds on a [[/skill 13 inv]] check correctly deduces the source of the smoke and the risk it poses to Ruckus’s shop. A character who gathered one or both clues has Advantage on this check.

If the characters explain the situation, Ruckus is relieved to hear his shop isn’t haunted and corrects the fire hazard. As thanks, he pays each character [[/award 10GP]] and encourages them to spend it here.

Quest: Bank Job.name: Quest: Bank Job
Quest: Bank Job.text:
At the service counter, Quink asks the characters if they’re adventurers looking for work. If they say yes, she leans in close and speaks to them in hushed tones. Read the following boxed text aloud:

“Yvette here is a lousy guard. There was a break-in recently on her watch, and the burglar got away. I fear the culprit might attempt another break-in, and I’d like you to prevent the heist—quietly. I can pay you a lump sum of twenty gold pieces for your services. What do you say?”

If the characters accept, Quink continues:

“I’d like you to stake out the bank tonight. If you see a burglar trying to enter, intervene and convince the criminal to leave at once. Remember, I’m paying for discretion. If you try to give the thief a trouncing, it will no doubt cause a scene. I want this matter resolved without violence.”

Quink believes the culprit lives in the keep.

Thief in the Night

That night, a masked thief stealthily approaches the bank’s door and attempts to pick its lock. The thief is Indifferent toward and wary of the characters if approached but doesn’t immediately run away.

As an &Reference[Influence] action, a character can dissuade the thief and make one of these ability checks:

[[/skill 15 dec]]. The character tells the thief a lie, like saying the guards are coming.

[[/skill 15 per]]. The character convinces the thief to pursue a different line of work.

[[/skill 15 itm]]. The character threatens the thief, who abandons the heist.

On a successful check, the thief lingers long enough for the characters to recognize Yvette, the bank’s usual guard! On a failed check, she flees before they can get a good look at her.

Reward

Quink pays the characters [[/award 20GP]] for stopping the heist as promised. If they also reveal the thief’s identity, Quink is flabbergasted but adds a [[/award 10GP]] bonus for the characters’ exceptional work. Soon after, two guards arrive and arrest Yvette. After the arrest, Yvette no longer appears at this location.

Quest: Wake Up Call.name: Quest: Wake Up Call
Quest: Wake Up Call.text:
After making introductions, Haldryck tells the characters they look light on their feet and in possession of good manners. He could use their help. Read the following boxed text aloud:

“Three guests sleeping in the common room this evening requested to be woken before sunrise, but I have a morning errand to attend to, so I won’t be able to fulfill my promise to them. I’d like you to wake the early risers in my stead without stirring any of the other guests.

“In exchange, I can offer you a free night’s stay in one of my private rooms. There’s even one with a window! How does that sound?”

If the characters agree, Haldryck thanks them and describes the three guests who requested wake-up calls before returning to his duties.

Waking the Early Risers

When the characters arrive to wake the early risers, twelve people are asleep in the common room. The early risers are scattered about the room, dozing among other guests who don’t wish to be disturbed.

To find and wake an early riser without disturbing the other guests, a character must succeed on a [[/skill 12 ste]] check. On a failed check, the character still wakes the early riser but bumps a grumpy sleeper in the process, rousing them from their slumber. The characters must make this check three times, one for each early riser.

Checking In with Haldryck

For waking the early risers, Haldryck rewards the party [[/award 5GP]], recommending they use it to rent a private room. If the characters completed the task without bothering any other guests, Haldryck gives the characters an additional [[/award 10GP]] for their good work. Otherwise, he mutters about receiving a noise complaint from an unhappy guest.

Quest: Chug Champion.name: Quest: Chug Champion
Quest: Chug Champion.text:
The tavern’s signature game is a nightly contest called chug champion.

Playing the Game

To play chug champion, participants—called “chuggers”—line up at the bar and pay 5 GP each to receive three pints of either heady ale or non-alcoholic cider (their choice). The goal is to drink the pints as quickly as possible over 3 rounds.

Each round, each participating character must succeed on a [[/save 12 con]] saving throw to quaff the pint in one go. On a failed save, the character drinks too slowly and is eliminated along with a handful of other chuggers. Otherwise, they proceed to the next round. A character who succeeds on all three saves wins the game.

If multiple characters succeed on all three saving throws, compare the results of those chuggers’ last saves, rerolling any ties. The character with the highest result places first, the character with the second-highest result places second, and any other characters place third.

Winning the Game

The winner receives [[/award 25GP]]. Second and third-place chuggers win [[/award 15GP]] and [[/award 10GP]], respectively.

Quest: Chaos Unfurls.name: Quest: Chaos Unfurls
Quest: Chaos Unfurls.text:
Once Toryn learns the characters are adventurers, she tries to hire them. Read the following aloud:

“I recently received a shipment of tempestuous magical scrolls. I need them stored in special scroll cases. If you tackle this chore for me, I’ll pay you a total of twenty gold pieces. Be warned: the scrolls have a will of their own.”

If the characters agree, Toryn leads them to a storeroom containing a pile of empty scroll cases and a warded chest that holds the scrolls. She instructs the characters to open the chest when they’re ready, then wishes them good luck and departs hurriedly.

Ensorcelled Scrolls

When the characters open the chest, the scrolls erupt from it in a flurry of whirling parchment and shimmering ink. Roll Initiative. You can use the Combat Tracker to run this encounter.

Each round on Initiative Count 10 (losing Initiative ties), the scrolls fold themselves into weapons and deliver brutal paper cuts. Each character must succeed on a [[/save 10 dex]] saving throw or take [[/damage 1d4 Slashing]] damage. A character reduced to 0 Hit Points by a scroll has the &Reference[Unconscious] condition but is Stable.

There are two scrolls for every player character in the party. As an action, a character can try to stow a scroll in its case by succeeding on one of the following ability checks:

[[/skill 12 slt]]. The character deftly plucks a scroll from the air and puts it into a scroll case.

[[/skill 12 arc]]. The character pacifies a scroll with an arcane gesture, allowing it to be scooped up and peacefully stored.

[[/skill 12 itm]]. The character bullies a scroll, causing it to flee into a case.

Case Closed

If the characters encase all the scrolls, Toryn pays them [[/award 20GP]] as promised. If the scrolls knock out all the characters, Toryn finishes the task before tending to the party. The characters wake up in her office with 1 Hit Point each. When the characters come to, Toryn apologizes sheepishly for putting them in so much danger, then awards them [[/award 10GP]] for their effort.

Quest: Priestly Duties.name: Quest: Priestly Duties
Quest: Priestly Duties.text:
In Ivlis’s absence, Fazzir is having trouble keeping up with the flood of new responsibilities. He asks the characters to help him with two clerical tasks.

Impromptu Blessing

A married couple asked Fazzir to give them a blessing for safe travel for a romantic getaway. Fazzir needs two assistants to perform the ceremony.

To conduct the ceremony properly, two characters must each take the &Reference[Study] action and make a [[/skill 10 rel]] check. On a successful check, the couple departs the temple with cheer. On a failed check, the couple postpones their trip, uneasy about what their journey might bring.

Occult Symbol

Last night, a vandal defaced the temple with a strange symbol. Fazzir doesn’t recognize the symbol. He asks the party to scrub away the graffiti.

A blood-red bell is splattered onto the side of the temple in runny paint. A character who inspects the symbol and succeeds on a DC 13 Intelligence (Arcana) check recognizes the bell as the mark of the Cult of Chaos and an omen of future turmoil. If informed about the symbol’s meaning, Fazzir finds the revelation deeply troubling. The mark washes off easily, but its stain on the priest’s mind lingers.

Reward

After these tasks, Fazzir gives each character [[/award 3GP]] regardless of their performance. He is just grateful for their support.

Quest: Testing the Defenses.name: Quest: Testing the Defenses
Quest: Testing the Defenses.text:
Andrella has an unusual request. Once she learns the characters are adventurers, she dismisses the guards and says the following to the party:

“I want to observe how my soldiers would fare in an invasion scenario. As adventurers, you might be able to simulate such a threat.
“I’d like you to sneak past the guards stationed here after sunset and steal a pennant from the other side of the gate. As part of this exercise, you can’t harm any on-duty soldiers, but I’ll explain the situation if any of you are detained.
“Are you up for the challenge?”

In exchange for their work, Andrella offers the characters a total of 25 GP.

Infiltrating the Guardhouse

During the night, eight soldiers stand watch outside the gatehouse: six on the roof and another two on the ground before the open gate. If necessary, use the @UUID[Actor.mmGuard000000000]{Guard} to represent each soldier.

As an action, a character can try to bypass the soldiers and make one of these ability checks:

[[/skill 15 ste]]. The character slips past the soldiers undetected.

[[/skill 15 ath]]. The character scales the keep’s sheer wall between regular patrols.

[[/skill 15 dec]]. The character fools the soldiers with a disguise or convincing lie.

On a successful check, the character bypasses the soldiers undetected. On a failed check, two soldiers spot the character and take them into custody, but other characters can continue the mission.

Debrief with Andrella

If at least one character reaches the pennant without getting caught, Andrella meets them afterward. She pays the party [[/award 25GP]] as promised. If no characters were spotted, Andrella throws in an extra [[/award 15GP]] and chastises the soldiers they evaded.
