If all the characters are detained before anyone in the party can grab the pennant, Andrella visits the characters in a sparsely furnished detention cell and thanks them for testing her soldiers. She informs the soldiers about the training exercise and smugly pays the characters [[/award 25GP]] on their release.

Quest: Shannik’s Chores.name: Quest: Shannik’s Chores
Quest: Shannik’s Chores.text:
Shannik hires the characters to complete a couple chores around the inner bailey. The characters can refuse his request, but Shannik asks with increasing insistence each time they visit the inner bailey.

Disrupting the Charge

Shannik wants to train two green recruits for the cavalry. He has them ride around the bailey for 10 minutes, spearing the hanging rings with lances.

During the exercise, Shannik asks the characters to disrupt the training by distracting the horses or their riders without causing injury to either. A character can do so by succeeding on one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 13 ani]]. The character guides a horse off course.

[[/skill 13 itm]]. The character tries to startle a horse or its rider.

Catapult Installation

Shannik wants to install a catapult atop the Great Tower to defend against invaders. To do so, the characters must succeed on the following ability checks in this order:

[[/skill 15 ath]]. The character hauls supplies out of the stores in the southwest tower, across the bailey, and up the Great Tower.

[[/skill 13 inv]]. The character correctly assembles the catapult according to its blueprints.

[[/skill 13 prc]]. The character calibrates the catapult by test-firing it at a target outside the keep’s walls.

This task takes 1 hour. If at least one character succeeds on each check, the party completes the task. The characters can retry failed checks, but if they accumulate three failures, Shannik dismisses them, grumbling about their incompetence.

Reward

In exchange for completing a chore, Shannik pays a character [[/award 5GP]]. A character can complete each of Shannik’s chores only once. Thereafter, the sergeant greets the characters with a respectful nod whenever they visit this area.

Quest: Official Errands.name: Quest: Official Errands
Quest: Official Errands.text:
Each official in the fortress spurs the characters to explore a different adventure setting.

Dwern the Scribe

The castellan’s scribe, a dwarf man named @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.fH9f0I0UUsRy53mU]{Dwern}, sits at a tidy desk in an austere office, documenting changes to the keep’s inventory in a heavy ledger.

When the characters visit Dwern, he issues the following quest:

“I’ve commissioned a map of the wilderness beyond the keep. However, the map is sorely lacking in detail, and few are willing to brave the wilds to properly survey them—but you look like you’re made of sterner stuff.

“If you help me finish my map by exploring the surrounding lands, I’ll compensate you fairly.”

If the characters explore three or more wilderness regions (see the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbWilderness00]{Wilderness} journal entry) and report their findings to Dwern, the scribe pays them a handsome reward: a large, glittering @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbGem000000000]{gemstone}, which they can sell to the jeweler for gold (see @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.HFTSFYGVWJfdhFD4]{area 3}).

Elandra the Adviser

The castellan’s trusted adviser, an elf woman named @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.znsxDE6HsMitGbE3]{Elandra}, operates in one of the towers. Carpets and tapestries decorate her chamber.

When the characters visit Elandra, she issues the following quest:

“While Castellan Winvarle protects the keep from outside threats, it’s my duty to preserve the peace within its walls and ensure its citizens are content.

“I’d like you to visit a few businesses within the keep and help their owners with any odd jobs they might have. I recently acquired an item of arcane significance. Assist me in this effort, and the item is yours.”

If the characters complete three quests within the keep and report back to Elandra, she rewards them with one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

Winvarle the Castellan

The keep’s noble castellan, an elf man named @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.7FaINJ8FBS2V8pfJ]{Winvarle}, holds court daily in the great hall. A keen strategist, Winvarle casts his vigilant gaze toward the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos}, where rumors of a sinister cult have surfaced.

When the characters visit Winvarle, he issues the following quest:

“Your arrival is fortuitous. I’ve heard whispers of a nefarious cult—the self-proclaimed Cult of Chaos—that reportedly operates in a cave network to the northeast. I believe the source of the cult’s power resides in one of those caves.

“These lands yearn for heroes. For the good of the Borderlands and the people under my charge, I humbly ask you to investigate these rumors and, if need be, quash this evil before it reaches the keep.”

Winvarle claims this quest is its own reward, but he adds that the Caves of Chaos abound with treasure, hoping to entice any characters who seek only to fill their coffers.

Castellan Winvarle also encourages the characters to meet with his adviser and scribe, who might have other tasks for them to complete.

Heroes’ Return

If the characters return to this location at level 3, having fulfilled all three keep officials’ quests (detailed in the previous sections), they receive a heroes’ welcome. That evening, Castellan Winvarle throws a celebration in the characters’ honor and invites the citizens of the keep to participate in the festivities. At your discretion, any of the NPCs within the keep might be present at the celebration to mingle with the characters and show their appreciation.

At the height of the revelry, the castellan publicly thanks the characters and presents them a writ of congratulations. Give the players the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.gDcWIFbomehF4PrD]{Castellan’s Letter Handout}, which might inspire future adventures involving the Keep on the Borderlands.

Ending the Adventure

Castellan Winvarle’s celebration marks the end of this adventure, but there’s still plenty to explore in this set after that. The characters can continue to adventure in the Keep on the Borderlands, the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos}, and the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbWilderness00]{Wilderness} (detailed in each respective journal) until they’ve experienced all the Borderlands has to offer. You can also use this set to tell stories of your own.

If you wish to advance these characters beyond level 3 and create new adventures for them, you need the core rulebooks: the Player’s Handbook, the Dungeon Master’s Guide, and the Monster Manual.

Quest: Entry Screening.name: Quest: Entry Screening
Quest: Entry Screening.text:
Quest: Entry Screening

7

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.xCF4bkG4KlWEy6hX caption=false classes="two"]

Once the drawbridge is lowered, Bartho and Gala introduce themselves and encourage the characters to lend their services to the keep.

Read the following boxed text aloud:

“The keep has plenty of need for hearty adventurers like you,” Gala says. “If you want to make a name for yourselves in this community and earn the castellan’s respect, you should visit locations within the keep and offer your aid.”

“Residents usually pay for a job well done,” Bartho adds casually.

Before they venture into the Borderlands, the characters can report to the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.SBrXpoLzTOv5GyYJ]{fortress} for more information on how they can further the interests of the castellan and his advisers.

Bartho’s Reward

8

The guards here have orders to help out around the keep between shifts, but Bartho claims he must rest instead to stay sharp when he’s on duty. He pulls the characters aside and asks them to complete quests around the keep for a small reward.

When the characters return to the outer gatehouse after completing at least three quests around the keep, Bartho thanks them and gives each character [[/award 5GP]].

Social Interaction. Player characters can meet many different people throughout the keep. As DM, you assume the roles of these nonplayer characters, whom you can embody through either active or descriptive roleplaying (detailed below). Players also use one or both of these approaches to roleplay their characters.

Regardless of the approach you prefer, use each nonplayer character’s NPC Card to determine how they react to the character’s words and actions.

Active Roleplaying. In active roleplaying, you speak with a character’s voice and might echo their body language, like an actor taking on a role. You still need to describe things that can’t reasonably be acted out.

An active approach to roleplaying Bartho, an inexperienced guard prone to daydreaming, might involve you pretending to yawn mid-sentence or getting distracted by a butterfly. Perhaps he confides with the characters that he’d rather be doing something else.

Descriptive Roleplaying. In descriptive roleplaying, you draw on your mental image of the character, saying what the character does and how they do it.

A descriptive approach to roleplaying Gala, a straitlaced guard who hopes to ascend in rank, might involve you describing her dutiful posture or no-nonsense expression. You might tell the players that she cautions the characters not to cause trouble as they enter the keep.

Quest. Every location in the keep offers a quest: a heroic task or odd job intended for the party. The characters don’t have to complete a quest at a location to benefit from its services. Unless stated otherwise, the characters can decline a quest; they can always return to complete it at a later time. Each quest’s reward is stated at the end of its section.

7

Treasure. Rewards within the keep usually come in the form of Gold Pieces (GP). Whenever a player character finds gold, give that player Gold Pieces equal to the listed value (you can use the Award buttons throughout the journal entries to give gold to the party, an individual player, or each person in the Party).

8

Quest: Billy Goat Wranglin’.name: Quest: Billy Goat Wranglin’
Quest: Billy Goat Wranglin’.text:
After introducing herself and explaining the barn’s services, Cornflower confesses she could use the characters’ help. Read the following text aloud:

“Last night, I accidentally left the goat pen unlocked—and this mornin’, all the goats were gone! I’m sure they’re still within the keep, but I need to tend to the other animals here and make sure no others get loose. Would you track down the missin’ goats and return them to the barn?”

Cornflower offers the characters [[/award 1GP]] for every goat they bring back. The number of missing goats equals the number of player characters.

Finding the Goats

The goats are scattered throughout the keep. Roll [[/gmroll 1d12]] for each missing goat, rerolling duplicates. Keep these results secret (the roll above is automatically configured to be visible only to the DM). Each result corresponds to a numbered location on the @UUID[Scene.hotbKeepOnTheBor]{Keep on the Borderlands} Scene where a goat can be found. For example, on a 5, a goat is outside the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn.JournalEntryPage.wOTSso2JzjUOUICl]{provisioner’s shop}. To find the goat, the characters must go to that location, though they don’t have to venture inside.

A character can narrow their search by making one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 10 sur]]. The character follows hoofprints in the dirt.

[[/skill 10 per]]. The character asks passersby if they’ve seen a loose goat.

On a successful check, the character learns the location of one goat whose whereabouts the party doesn’t already know.

Returning the Goats

When the characters arrive at a goat’s location, they find it grazing outside the structure and can coax it back to the barn. When the characters return a goat to Cornflower, she pays them [[/award 1GP]] as thanks.

Exploring the Keep.name: Exploring the Keep
Exploring the Keep.text:
The player characters can visit any location in the keep, meeting and interacting with the citizens who reside there. Each keep location employs one or more NPCs, typically representing the most important person at a location, such as an establishment’s owner or highest ranking representative.

The map of the keep isn’t to scale, but you can use Player Character Tokens to track the characters’ current whereabouts. If this is your first time as Dungeon Master, ask your players to keep the party together; it’s easier if the player characters visit each location as a group.

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.ShSj34GxQG9CaZr1 caption=false]

Location Descriptions

Each description of a keep location has the following sections:

Features. This section details noteworthy features about the location.

Services. Services offered at the location, such as goods for sale or rooms for rent, appear here. If a player character pays for a good or service, collect Gold Pieces equal to its cost from that player's character sheet. If they buy an item that has an Item included in this adventure, give the player that Item from the Items Compendium Pack. If no cards remain in the box for an item, it’s out of stock.

Quest. This section contains a quest unique to the location. Most take place in the keep, though some encourage the characters to venture beyond its walls. Each quest can be completed only once.

Social Interaction

The keep offers ample opportunities for characters to socialize with its inhabitants. All NPCs in the keep are initially Indifferent toward the characters. For more about NPC attitudes, see the Play Guide.

Combat

Combat is prohibited in the keep. If you need game statistics for an NPC open their character sheet.

At your discretion, characters who antagonize peaceful members of the keep might attract the attention of the soldiers of the keep, of whom there are many (use the @UUID[Actor.mmGuard000000000]{Guard} Actor). Those who refuse to keep the peace might be arrested and detained for a few days, fined up to 50 GP, or ousted from the keep until they can behave.

Resting

Unlike in the other two adventure settings, the keep is a safe place to rest and resupply. The characters can freely take &Reference[Long Rest]{Long Rests} in the keep. For more on resting, see the Play Guide.

Leaving the Keep

The player characters can leave the Keep on the Borderlands whenever they choose. As they accumulate treasure and advance in level, the party might return to spend their hard-earned wealth, rest, or follow up on previously undertaken quests.

Character Advancement

Though there are quests to complete in the Keep on the Borderlands, the characters don’t gain levels in this adventure. Each quest offers its own reward, usually in the form of gold or favors.

Getting Started.name: Getting Started
Getting Started.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.NJXodJNQMWCjYepb caption=false classes="right three"]

What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbWilderness00]{Wilderness}

DM View: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbAtlas0000000.JournalEntryPage.NJXodJNQMWCjYepb]{Wilderness}

The wilds of the Borderlands teem with dangerous animals and ravenous monsters.

DM Secret! This book is for the Dungeon Master’s eyes only. Unless text appears in a read-aloud box (like the one above), don’t read it to the players.

Getting Started

Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbWilderness00]{Wilderness} Scene for the players to see. This player-focused map doesn’t reveal the contents of each wilderness region, only the general geographic features. The Caves of Chaos and the Keep on the Borderlands aren’t labeled on this map so the players don’t confuse them with wilderness regions.

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

Your adventuring party enters the wilderness. Mysteries await you in this untamed land. Where do you want to go?

The Wilderness Regions table summarizes the regions in the order they appear within this booklet. If fully explored, each region provides about 60–90 minutes of gameplay.

Each region is roughly the same difficulty, but the Trail region functions as a tutorial with helpful sidebars. If this is your first time as the DM, encourage the players to start there. Otherwise, have them choose a region shown on the Scene.

Once the player characters choose a region, open that region's journal and review any components in its “What You Need to Play” section.

Wilderness Regions

Region

Description

1

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion1Trail]{Trail}

Friendly travelers and no-good bandits alike use this dirt road.

2

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion2Woods]{Woods}

These majestic forests shelter wily fey and occult secrets.

3

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion3Fens0]{Fens}

Territorial lizardfolk and a spy for hire lurk in this wetland.

4

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion4Tamar]{Tamarack Stand}

Giant spiders plague this vast stand of conifers.

Wilderness Encounters.name: Wilderness Encounters
Wilderness Encounters.text:
The following tables present additional random encounters the characters might face while exploring the wilderness. The tables are divided by wilderness region.

To generate a random encounter in a region, roll on the table for that region or choose an encounter you like. Activate the Scene for that region and place your Player Character Tokens to run combat encounters where necessary.

Fens Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbFens00000000]{Fens}

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbRandomFensEn rollable]

Tamarack Stand Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbTamarackStan]{Tamarack Stand}

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbRandomTamara rollable]

Trail Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbTrail0000000]{Trail}

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbRandomTrailE rollable]

Woods Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbWoods0000000]{Woods}

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbRandomWoodsE rollable]

@Embed[JournalEntry.hotbArtHandouts0.JournalEntryPage.vaA9GtuLUuHSfUag caption=false]

Locations.name: Locations
Locations.text:
@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion1Trail]{Region 1: Trail}

This dirt trail connects the Keep on the Borderlands to the Caves of Chaos and the lands beyond.

Encounters: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion1Trail.JournalEntryPage.ESnQMPj2hE6tQtL4]{Trail Encounters}

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion2Woods]{Region 2: Woods}

North of the keep sprawls a vast forest, home to hardy oaks, meaty mushrooms, and stores of primal magic. Wherever one goes in the woods, mystery and adventure abound.

Encounters: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion2Woods.JournalEntryPage.IkYTgtjZ2gEJpoCK]{Woods Encounters}

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion3Fens0]{Region 3: Fens}

This sodden wetland is home to dangerous wildlife, canny foes, and squelching mud.

Encounters: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion3Fens0.JournalEntryPage.XO0M4SU2czKj5Jmc]{Fens Encounters}

@UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion4Tamar]{Region 4: Tamarack Stand}

This hilly region’s sparse trees have short, bristly needles. Forest fires and giant animals are more common in this stretch of the wilds.

Encounters: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion4Tamar.JournalEntryPage.DNnCx2YUrXU4210d]{Tamarack Stand Encounters}

Exploring the Wilderness.name: Exploring the Wilderness
Exploring the Wilderness.text:
Wilderness encounters occur across large tracts of unmapped backcountry. The text tells you when to use a Scene and tokens; otherwise, you can resolve encounters using words and imagination.

Region Descriptions

Each description of a wilderness region has the following sections:

Features. Important features about the region, such as its lighting, appear here. The text assumes the characters explore the wilderness during the day and camp or return to the keep at night.

Getting Started. This section provides setup instructions for the DM and introduces the region to the characters with thematic read-aloud text.

Encounters. This section presents encounters that might occur in the region. Each encounter’s text details what challenge the characters must overcome.

Combat

Some encounters pit the characters against foes that mean them harm, such as wild animals or greedy bandits. See the “@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbCombat0000000]{Combat}” section in the Play Guide for how to run a combat encounter.

Resting

The dangers of the wilds keep travelers on their toes. The characters can take only &Reference[Short Rest]{Short Rests} while exploring a wilderness region. To take a &Reference[Long Rest], characters must visit the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn]{keep}. For more on resting, see the Play Guide.

Leaving the Wilderness

The characters can leave the wilderness any time they choose, provided they aren’t in combat. If they return to a region later, it’s as they left it.

Character Advancement

In this adventure, the characters can gain a level by exploring different regions. After the characters complete at least one encounter in all four regions, everyone in the party gains 1 level. This advancement occurs only once. If the characters are already level 3, they don’t gain a level for achieving this milestone.

Region 1: Trail.name: Region 1: Trail
Region 1: Trail.text:
This dirt trail connects the Keep on the Borderlands to the Caves of Chaos and the lands beyond.

Trail Features

The trail has the following features:

Lighting. The trail is illuminated with Bright Light.

Terrain. The 10-foot-wide trail is well kept and mostly flat. Spaces off the trail, however, are &Reference[Difficult Terrain].

Getting Started

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

You travel along a well-kept trail east of the Keep on the Borderlands. Gnarled tree roots and big rocks mark the edges of the ten-foot-wide path.

The characters continue down the trail. Along the way, they face one or more encounters (detailed in the following section). The length of the characters’ journey is up to you.

DM Tips This tutorial is designed for first-time Dungeon Masters. Boxes like this one explain how to use the text and give examples of how encounters in this region might play out.

Features. This section presents special features about the region. Use these to enhance your descriptions or handle situations where rules like lighting or terrain are relevant.

The rules glossary in the Play Guide defines any capitalized rules such as Bright Light.

1

Boxed Text. Text that appears in a box like the one to the left is meant to be read aloud or paraphrased for the players when their characters first arrive at a location or under a specific circumstance, as described in the text.

Boxed text is included for the region in general and for each encounter in it. Read the region's boxed text aloud before choosing the encounter, then read the boxed text aloud for that encounter to begin it.

2

Trail Encounters.name: Trail Encounters
Trail Encounters.text:
Each time the characters use the trail, roll once on the Trail Encounters table to determine what the characters encounter. If this is your first time being the DM, run the encounters in the order presented.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbRandTrailEnc caption=false rollable]

3

Random Tables. You can use tables like this one to randomly determine parts of the adventure. In this case, roll 1d4 to randomly determine what the characters encounter on the trail. Alternatively, you can forgo rolling and simply choose an encounter from the table.

3

Theater of the Mind. While the "Bandit Ambush" encounter later in this region uses a Scene, the "Looted Wagon" encounter doesn't use any game components—it happens in your collective imaginations.

Game Trail.name: Game Trail
Game Trail.text:
What You Need to Play

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.ZXoHwEtCrVkwhziO]{Haldryck}

You spot a regal elk on the trail beside a dense thicket. Startled by your approach, the elk lopes into the thorny thicket. “Blast!” cries a husky voice from somewhere in the brambles.

A character can safely navigate the thicket to the source of the noise by succeeding on one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 12 survival]]. The character follows the narrow game trail used by the elk.

[[/skill 12 nature]]. The character knows how to avoid the brambles’ thorns.

On a failed check, a character scrambles through but takes [[/damage 1d4 Piercing]] damage from the thorns.

Hidden Glen. A hidden glen lies on the other side of the game trail. Dozens of elk graze here in peace. Hiding in the bushes is @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.ZXoHwEtCrVkwhziO]{Haldryck}, a Friendly innkeeper who likes to hunt. (Haldryck also appears in @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbSourceKeepOn]{Keep on the Borderlands}.)

Haldryck asks the characters to keep his hunting spot a secret. If they agree, he gives the characters [[/award 5GP]] and encourages them to spend it at his inn when next they visit the keep.

Social Interaction. Player characters can meet many different people throughout the keep. As DM, you assume the roles of these nonplayer characters, whom you can embody through either active or descriptive roleplaying (detailed below). Players also use one or both of these approaches to roleplay their characters.

Active Roleplaying. In active roleplaying, you speak with a character’s voice and might echo their body language, like an actor taking on a role. You still need to describe things that can’t reasonably be acted out.

An active approach to roleplaying Haldryck in the “Game Trail” encounter might involve you pretending to hide behind imaginary foliage and speaking in hushed tones.

Descriptive Roleplaying. In descriptive roleplaying, you draw on your mental image of the character, saying what the character does and how they do it.

In the “Bandit Ambush” encounter, a descriptive approach to roleplaying Pral, a smarmy bandit captain, might involve you describing his flashy smile or confident swagger. You might tell the players that he holds out his hand expectantly for the characters’ gold.

Looted Wagon.name: Looted Wagon
Looted Wagon.text:
Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbLootedWagon0]{Looted Wagon}

A wagon stands on the trail ahead. The driver and horses are nowhere to be seen.

The wagon was looted by bandits, who stole the horses and scared away the driver. Led by a local menace named @UUID[Actor.hotbPral00000000]{Pral}, these bandits frequently accost travelers along the trail (as happens in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbRegion1Trail.JournalEntryPage.2YGkYz1dwJadJEBY]{Bandit Ambush} encounter described later in this adventure).

A character who inspects the wagon can make one of the following ability checks to learn more about it. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 13 investigation]]. The character deduces the wagon was ambushed by bandits.

[[/skill 13 survival]]. The character discovers a striking bootprint left by @UUID[Actor.hotbPral00000000]{Pral}. The heel is mongrammed with the letter P.

[[/skill 13 perception]]. The character finds treasure the bandits missed (see below).

4

Treasure. The wagon holds supplies intended for the keep: animal feed, bales of hay, and sacks of freshly milled flour. Stashed in one of the sacks is a purse that contains [[/award 12GP]].

5

Ability Checks. When the outcome of an action is uncertain, the game uses a d20 roll to determine success or failure. This is called a D20 Test. An ability check is one type of D20 Test. Here’s how to run the ability check in the “Looted Wagon” encounter:

1: Describe the Scene. Read the boxed text to paint a mental picture of the scene.

2: Ask the Players, “What Do You Do?” If the players aren’t sure how to respond, suggest ways they could glean more information, like looking for tracks.

3: Narrate the Results. The Difficulty Class (DC) for each listed ability check is 13. This number represents the difficulty of the task. If the total of the d20 and its modifiers equals or exceeds 13, the check succeeds. On a 12 or lower, it fails. The encounter’s description tells you what happens on a successful check. In this encounter, nothing happens on a failed check, but the character can try again.

Example. The Cleric searches the wagon and makes a Wisdom (Perception) check. The player rolls a d20 and adds their character’s Perception modifier (+5) for a total of 17. The check succeeds, and the Cleric finds the treasure.

4

Treasure. Treasure entries detail loot in an area, such as Gold Pieces (GP). Whenever a player character finds gold, give that player Gold Pieces equal to the listed value. The Award buttons throughout the Journals can be used to award gold to individual players and the party. Encourage players to split their treasure as evenly as possible.

5

Bandit Ambush.name: Bandit Ambush
Bandit Ambush.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbBanditAmbush]{Bandit Ambush}
Creatures: 3 @UUID[Actor.mmBandit00000000]{Bandits} and @UUID[Actor.hotbPral00000000]{Pral}

A handsome man in a green-and-gold tunic and fancy boots saunters out of the bushes. “Hello,” he says casually as he blocks your path. “I’m Pral. Perhaps you’ve heard of me. Who am I kidding? Of course you have!”

Pral draws a sword. “Your money and your equipment, please. This is a robbery.”

Pral leads a local gang of bandits. Three Bandits hide in the nearby bushes. Pral and the bandits are Hostile to the characters.

If the characters don’t relinquish their gold or talk their way out of the situation, Pral gives the signal for the bandits to spring out (see the “Fighting the Bandits” section).

Adjusting the Difficulty. To make the encounter easier, you can reduce the number of Bandits, or you can add another bandit to increase the difficulty.

Avoiding a Fight. As an &Reference[Influence] action, a character can try to defuse the situation and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 13 deception]]. The character lies to Pral to gain safe passage, perhaps by pretending to be a fellow bandit.

[[/skill 13 persuasion]]. The character convinces Pral that violence isn’t necessary.

[[/skill 13 intimidation]]. The character pressures Pral into reconsidering the ambush.

On a successful check, Pral lets the characters pass unharmed. On a failed check, Pral signals the bandits to emerge (see the following section).

Fighting the Bandits. In the case of combat, read the following to begin:

Pral tsks in disapproval. He snaps his fingers, prompting more bandits to spring from the bushes with weapons drawn. In an instant, you’re surrounded—roll Initiative!

Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbBanditAmbush]{Bandit Ambush} Scene for the players to see. Place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area.

8

Pral and his bandits are brigands, not murderers. A character reduced to 0 Hit Points by Pral or his cohorts has the &Reference[Unconscious apply=false] condition but is Stable. If all the characters are defeated by Pral’s band, they wake up 1 hour later on the trail with 1 Hit Point—and 10 fewer Gold Pieces or no Gold Pieces if they have fewer than 10 GP—each, along with a mocking note penned by Pral. At your discretion, Pral might reappear to the characters the next time they explore this region to rob them again.

Treasure. Stashed in the bushes are the recent ill-gotten gains stolen by Pral’s band. If the characters defeat Pral and his band, they find a sack that contains [[/award 20GP]] and one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

9

Advantage/Disadvantage. Sometimes a &Reference[D20 Test] is modified by special situations called &Reference[Advantage] and &Reference[Disadvantage], which reflect positive and negative circumstances, respectively. See the Play Guide for more on Advantage and Disadvantage.

In the “Bandit Ambush” encounter, Pral is Hostile, so characters have Disadvantage on checks to influence him and thus avoid a fight.

Roll Two D20s. When a roll has either Advantage or Disadvantage, roll a second d20 when you make the roll. Use the higher of the two rolls if you have Advantage, and use the lower roll if you have Disadvantage.

Example. A Rogue tries to smooth things over with Pral by pretending to be a bandit. The Rogue makes a Charisma (Deception) check with Disadvantage.

The player rolls two d20s and adds their character’s Deception modifier (+4) to both results to get two totals: 16 and 9. They use the lower roll, which falls short of the DC of 13, so the check fails—Pral and his bandits start combat! If this check had instead been made with Advantage, it would have succeeded.

Encounter Maps. The Scenes for the four wilderness regions are designed to accommodate multiple encounters and they are pre-configured with placed Tokens and Tiles.

You can use these Scenes, along with the Monsters in this module, to create wilderness encounters of your own.

8

Magic Items. Some treasure entries contain magic items, objects imbued with arcane might. Whenever a player character finds a magic item, draw a Magic Item from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} and hand it to the player.

9

Combat. Here’s how a combat encounter with Pral and his bandits ought to play out:

1: Describe the Scene. Read the boxed text aloud. Then say, “Roll Initiative!” to signal the start of combat. Pral gets his own Initiative roll. Roll once separately for the bandits, who all act on the same turn.

2: Place Tokens. Place the Player Character Tokens on the Scene.

3: Players React. In combat, the characters and the bandits act on their turns.

Use the Combat Tracker and the Play Guide to run this encounter.

Talkative Traveler.name: Talkative Traveler
Talkative Traveler.text:
What You Need to Play

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.6Dti695ubwK7p74L]{Mallyn}

A young woman with a massive backpack and an eager smile hikes toward you along the trail. The traveler waves at you excitedly.

“Good day!” she says. “I’m Mallyn. Might you be adventurers? I ask because I’ve been out here looking for adventures of my own—to no avail. After camping out here for days, I still don’t have any tales worth telling. Do you?”

Mallyn, a Friendly wanderer, is looking for tales of derring-do from brave adventurers. She stops to ask the characters to tell stories of their exploits.

6/7

A character can take a minute to tell Mallyn a story and make one of the following ability checks to impress her. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 13 deception]]. The character spins a grand yarn about a harrowing experience that never happened.

[[/skill 13 performance]]. The character vividly recounts a legendary story through song, dramatic reenactment, or interpretive dance.

If at least one character succeeds on the check, Mallyn thanks the party and gives them a pouch she found on the trail. Otherwise, she encourages them to keep adventuring until they have something more interesting to share. Regardless, Mallyn prefers to travel alone and doesn’t accompany the characters on their journey if invited.

Treasure. The pouch Mallyn found contains [[/award 10GP]].

Bold Terms and NPC Cards. When a game component’s name appears in Bold type, that’s a visual cue to say, “Hey, DM, you should get this component is important.”

This bold term corresponds to an NPC. Whenever such a card appears in the text, show the art side of the card to the players. The Mallyn Actor art helps players (and you) visualize this upbeat NPC. Use the information in their biography along with the adventure text to bring Mallyn to life through roleplay.

6

Attitudes. Every creature has a starting attitude toward the characters: Friendly, Hostile, or Indifferent (see the Play Guide). Regardless, creatures defend themselves in combat.

7

Region: 2 Woods.name: Region: 2 Woods
Region: 2 Woods.text:
North of the keep sprawls a vast forest, home to hardy oaks, meaty mushrooms, and stores of primal magic. Wherever one goes in the woods, mystery and adventure abound.

Woods Features

The woods have the following feature:

Lighting. The thick forest canopy filters sunlight from above, resulting in only &Reference[Dim Light].

Getting Started

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

Dappled sunlight trickles through the canopy of this old-growth forest. Felled trees, shrubs, and mushrooms dot the forest floor.

Hermit’s Hut.name: Hermit’s Hut
Hermit’s Hut.text:
What You Need to Play

NPC: @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.JbKIizsMMDQs7wuN]{Xanthe}

After a couple hours of hiking, you happen on a humble hut made from sheets of sturdy bark and blankets of moss. Sweet-smelling smoke wafts from its chimney. The hut’s wooden door is shut.

A hermit named @UUID[Actor.hotbXanthe000000]{Xanthe} lives here. Banished months ago from the keep, Xanthe is initially Hostile toward the characters, who she believes have come to harass her.

A character who tries to convince Xanthe that they bear no ill will can make a [[/skill per 12]] check. A successful check improves Xanthe’s attitude to Indifferent, and the hermit invites the party into her hut, where she shares her story and the rumors in her @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbNpcs00000000.JournalEntryPage.JbKIizsMMDQs7wuN]{journal}. On a failed check, Xanthe slams the door in their faces.

Occult Ritual.name: Occult Ritual
Occult Ritual.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbOccultRitual]{Occult Ritual}

Equipment: 4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbCultistsRobe]{Cultist’s Robes}

Creatures: 4 @UUID[Actor.mmCultist0000000]{Cultists}

Eventually, you come across an eerie statue in a forest clearing. Strange runes are etched into the stone idol. Four human figures in occult robes gather around the statue, chanting ominously.

Four Cultists conduct a ritual around this ancient statue. They belong to the Cult of Chaos, a faction that delights in death and disarray. They are Hostile toward those not garbed in their cult’s attire but don’t immediately notice the characters.

Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbOccultRitual]{Occult Ritual} Scene for the players to see and place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area.

The cultists continue intoning until their ritual is complete or interrupted. If disturbed, they fight.

Adjusting the Difficulty. To make this encounter easier, reduce the number of Cultists. Conversely, you can make this encounter more challenging by adding one or more @UUID[Actor.mmZombie00000000]{Zombies}, which aid the cultists as undead thralls.

Fooling the Cultists. The cultists are Indifferent toward any character wearing a cultist’s robe, which they might have obtained in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos}. If a character approaches in this disguise, the cultists solemnly motion for the character to join the ritual, but they begin combat if the character refuses.

Completing the Ritual. If the characters join the ritual—or observe it without drawing attention—the statue’s runes begin to glow with an eerie red light. After 10 minutes, the sky darkens, and the statue suddenly splits in two with a loud crack. Moments later, a wicked, disembodied laugh echoes throughout the forest. The cultists then disband.

Treasure. The characters can take robes from the defeated cultists. For each robe they take, give the players a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbCultistsRobe]{Cultist’s Robe}.

Sacred Spring.name: Sacred Spring
Sacred Spring.text:
Deep in the heart of the forest, the foliage parts to reveal a tranquil grove where a natural spring burbles. Rays of sunlight create a silvery glow about the crystal-clear pool.

This sacred spring is infused with primal magic.

Healing Water. A character who takes an action to drink from the spring regains [[/heal 5]]{5 Hit Points}. Once a character regains Hit Points from the spring, they can’t do so again until they finish a Long Rest.

Destroying the Chaos Bell. If the party has the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbKShrineOfEvi.JournalEntryPage.bnd56aGBqKagaUWj]{Chaos Bell} from the Shrine of Evil Chaos, a character can submerge the evil artifact in this sacred spring. If this is done at night while the spring is bathed in moonlight, the bell turns to glittering ash.

Woods Encounters.name: Woods Encounters
Woods Encounters.text:
Each time the characters explore this region, roll once on the Woods Encounters table to determine what the characters encounter.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbWoodsEncount rollable]

Sparring Sprites.name: Sparring Sprites
Sparring Sprites.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbSparringSpri]{Sparring Sprites}

Creatures: 4 @UUID[Actor.mmSprite00000000]{Sprite Skirmishers}

Farther into the woods, four diminutive, winged warriors flit between oversized toadstools and mossy logs, firing needlelike arrows from tiny bows. One of them calls out to you.

“Well met, giant travelers! We are training for battle,” he reports. “Care to spar with us?”

Four Sprite Skirmishers spar vigorously in this clearing. The sprites are Indifferent toward the characters but interested in testing their mettle against the party.

Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbSparringSpri]{Sparring Sprites} Scene for the players to see and place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area.

Sparring with the Sprites. If the characters agree to spar with the pugnacious fey, the bout proceeds as a nonlethal combat encounter. The sprites bow gracefully, then ready their weapons. Roll Initiative.

The sprites fight valiantly but with restraint. A player character reduced to 0 Hit Points by a sprite has the &Reference[Unconscious apply=false] condition and is Stable. The sprites expect similar treatment by the characters.

If all the sprites are defeated, they quickly rouse themselves and commend the characters on their tactical prowess. If all the characters are defeated instead, the sprites wait for the characters to wake up—1 hour later and with 1 Hit Point each—to thank them for helping the sprites train.

Treasure. In exchange for the characters’ spirited participation, the sprites reward the party with one magic item; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

Region 3: Fens.name: Region 3: Fens
Region 3: Fens.text:
This sodden wetland is home to dangerous wildlife, canny foes, and squelching mud.

Fens Features

The fens have the following features:

Lighting. The fens are in Bright Light.

Reeds. Tall, slender reeds grow throughout the soggy wetland. Areas with reeds are &Reference[Lightly Obscured] and &Reference[Difficult Terrain].

Standing Water. Shallow, soupy pools of murk pervade the fens. The water is &Reference[Difficult Terrain].

Getting Started

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

Mosquitoes buzz about the stands of cattails and gnarled trees in these squashy, stagnant fens. Croaking frogs, chirping cicadas, and squawking birds create an incessant din.

Fens Encounters.name: Fens Encounters
Fens Encounters.text:
Each time the characters explore this region, roll once on the Fens Encounters table to determine what the characters encounter.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbFensEncounte rollable]

Flock of Stirges.name: Flock of Stirges
Flock of Stirges.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbFlockOfStirg]{Flock of Stirges}
Creatures: 3 @UUID[Actor.mmStirge00000000]{Stirges}

Your journey halts at a narrow creek bed stained with blood. Near the shore, a giant river rat lies dead in the mud. The carcass is shriveled as if drained of its bodily fluids.
Suddenly, a flock of horrid creatures erupts from the reeds. Each has barbed, leathery wings and a long, sharp proboscis. Roll initiative!

Three Stirges descend on the characters. These bloodthirsty creatures can’t be reasoned with; the Hostile stirges fight to the death.

Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbFlockOfStirg]{Flock of Stirges} Scene for the players to see and place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area.

Adjusting the Difficulty. To make this encounter easier, you can reduce the number of Stirges, or you can increase the difficulty by adding one or more @UUID[Actor.mmGnollWarrior00]{Gnoll Warriors} drawn here by the scent of blood.

Sword Ferns.name: Sword Ferns
Sword Ferns.text:
As you trudge through the mud, you tumble into a ravine of razor-sharp ferns. To continue, you must navigate this treacherous gully.

A character who examines the ferns can make a [[/skill 12 nat]] check, identifying the plants as sword ferns—bladelike ferns endemic to jungles and wetlands—on a successful check.

To forge a path through the ferns, each character must succeed on one of the following checks:

[[/skill 15 athletics]]. The character hacks a path through the ferns with a weapon or stick.

[[/skill 15 survival]]. The character finds a safe trail through the ferns used by wild animals.

On a failed check, the character takes [[/damage 1d6 slashing]] damage from the ferns on their way through the gully.

Lizardfolk Swamp.name: Lizardfolk Swamp
Lizardfolk Swamp.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbLizardfolkSw]{Lizardfolk Swamp}
Creatures: 2 @UUID[Actor.hotbLizardfolkWa]{Lizardfolk Wardens}

Deeper into the fens, mounds of mud rise above the fetid water and reeds. You spot a glint of gold amid the mud.

The fen’s territorial lizardfolk denizens use these mounds to conceal their treasure. Two @UUID[Actor.hotbLizardfolkWa]{Lizardfolk Wardens} hide among the reeds, watching over the mounds. The lizardfolk have the &Reference[Invisible apply=false] condition and are Hostile toward the characters.

Activate the @UUID[Scene.hotbLizardfolkSw]{Lizardfolk Swamp} Scene for the players to see and place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area. The Wardens have the Invisible status which must be turned off whenever the players should be able to see them.

After 1 minute, the lizardfolk appear and tersely command the characters to leave at once. If the characters refuse, the lizardfolk fight.

Detecting the Lizardfolk. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character can scan the mud mounds for signs of danger, detecting the lizardfolk with a successful [[/skill prc 15]] check.

Fighting the Lizardfolk. If a character approaches the mound or disturbs the treasure (see below), the lizardfolk leap out and start combat. Characters who failed to detect the lizardfolk before the ambush have Disadvantage on their Initiative rolls. The lizardfolk fight fiercely in defense of their possessions.

Treasure. Hidden in the mounds are [[/award 20GP]] and one @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.items.Item.hotbGem000000000]{gemstone}.

Spy’s Campsite.name: Spy’s Campsite
Spy’s Campsite.text:
What You need to Play

NPC: @UUID[Actor.hotbJacko0000000]{Jacko}

The air is still in this corner of the fens. Just ahead, a curved stand of reeds conceals a secluded campsite with a still-smoldering firepit. The reeds sway and rustle in the muggy breeze.

This campsite belongs to Jacko, a notorious spy for hire. Jacko hides in the surrounding foliage. He is Indifferent toward the characters.

Detecting Jacko. As a &Reference[Search] action, a character can survey the campsite for clues to its inhabitant’s whereabouts and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 15 perception]]. The character spots the glint of Jacko’s blade in the reeds.

[[/skill 15 survival]]. The character spots faint tracks that lead to the spy.

On a successful check, Jacko emerges from the tall reeds and commends the party on finding his hideout. He then offers his services to the party.

Hiring Jacko. Plucky do-gooders aren’t Jacko’s usual clientele, but for 25 GP, he offers to join the characters in a single fight anywhere in the wilderness. If the party contains a Rogue or a character with the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbBackgrounds0.JournalEntryPage.O0c5r8RheNC6YT1v]{Criminal} background, Jacko offers a 5 GP discount. The shady halfling advertises his services as “all inclusive” and “no questions asked” while performing a cutthroat gesture.

If a player character hires Jacko, give that player the Jacko Monster Token. Thereafter, whenever the characters roll Initiative in the wilderness, ask that player if they’d like Jacko to assist them in the fight. If so, Jacko joins the fray alongside the party. After the fight, Jacko returns to this location unless the characters hire him again.

Region 4: Tamarack Stand.name: Region 4: Tamarack Stand
Region 4: Tamarack Stand.text:
This hilly region’s sparse trees have short, bristly needles. Forest fires and giant animals are more common in this stretch of the wilds.

Tamarack Stand Features

The tamarack stand has the following feature:

Lighting. Bright Light illuminates the region.

Getting Started

To begin, read the following boxed text aloud:

Conifers rise from this highland’s soft, peaty soil. Squirrels skitter about the fallen pinecones and pine needles that blanket the ground.

Tamarack Stand Encounters.name: Tamarack Stand Encounters
Tamarack Stand Encounters.text:
Each time the characters explore this region, roll once on the Tamarack Stand Encounters table to determine what the characters encounter.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbTamrackStand rollable]

Flash Fire.name: Flash Fire
Flash Fire.text:
Your expedition stops at the bottom of a steep gorge—a dead end. As you reorient yourselves, smoke begins to fill the air, and a sudden forest fire spreads through the dry canyon.

The conflagration roars in the party’s direction, engulfing everything in its path.

To escape the fire unscathed, each character must succeed on one of the following ability checks:

[[/skill 15 athletics]]. The character scales the gorge to safety.

[[/skill 15 acrobatics]]. The character leaps across the branches, avoiding the flames below.

[[/skill 15 survival]]. The character cuts through a thicket of trees with fire-resistant sap.

On a failed check, a character takes [[/damage 2d6 fire]] damage on their way to safety.

Hobgoblin Patrol.name: Hobgoblin Patrol
Hobgoblin Patrol.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbHobgoblinPat]{Hobgoblin Patrol}

Creatures: 3 @UUID[Actor.mmHobgoblinWarri]{Hobgoblin Warriors}

Ahead of you, three humanoid warriors in battered armor argue in harsh tones as they march through the forest. They haven’t noticed you yet.

Three Hobgoblin Warriors were recently separated from their squadron after a bitter defeat. The Hostile hobgoblins are ornery and assault the characters on sight.

Activate the Scene for the players to see and place the Player Character Tokens near the Suggested Start Area.

Adjusting the Difficulty. To make this encounter easier, you can reduce the number of Hobgoblin Warriors. Conversely, add one more Hobgoblin Warrior to increase the difficulty.

Eavesdropping on the Hobgoblins. To listen in on the hobgoblins’ argument, a character must come within 30 feet of the patrol and make a [[skill 15 ste]] check. On a successful check, the character hears the hobgoblins debating whether they should ally with the bugbears in the Caves of Chaos or hire the ogre mercenary that dwells there (both are detailed in the @UUID[JournalEntry.hotbCavesOfChaos]{Caves of Chaos}). On a failed check, the hobgoblins spot the eavesdropping character and start combat.

Treasure. Each hobgoblin carries a leather pouch that contains [[/award 4GP]].

Giant Spiders’ Nest.name: Giant Spiders’ Nest
Giant Spiders’ Nest.text:
What You Need to Play

Scene: @UUID[Scene.hotbGiantSpiders]{Giant Spiders' Nest}
Creatures: 2 @UUID[Actor.mmGiantSpider000]{Giant Spiders}

You wander into a maze of thick webs camouflaged between tall trees. Two massive arachnids descend on you with fangs bared.

Two Giant Spiders start combat, eager to make the characters their next meal.

Activate the Scene for the players to see.

Some characters begin this encounter trapped in the spiders’ sticky web (see the “Giant Webs” section). Roll a [[/r 1d2]]{die} for each character. On an even number, place their Player Character Token in the Suggested Start Area. On an odd number, place it on the Web.

Giant Webs. The Web Token represents a 20-foot Cube filled with thick, sticky webs woven by giant spiders to snare prey. The webs are &Reference[Difficult Terrain], and the area within them is &Reference[Lightly Obscured].

The first time a creature enters the webs on a turn or starts its turn there, it must succeed on a [[/save 12 dex]] saving throw or have the &Reference[Restrained] condition until it breaks free or the webs are destroyed.

As an action, a creature Restrained by the webs can make a [[/skill 12 ath]] check. If it succeeds, it is no longer Restrained.

The webs are flammable and laden with dry pollen and old animal carcasses. If the webs take Fire damage, the entire 20-foot Cube of webs ignites, and each creature Restrained by the webs takes [[/damage 2d4 fire]] damage. The webs then burn away and are destroyed at the end of the turn.

Treasure. After the fight, the characters find one magic item suspended in the webs; draw a card from the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-heroes-borderlands.tables.RollTable.hotbMagicItems00]{Magic Item Table} to determine the item.

Pine Seeds.name: Pine Seeds
Pine Seeds.text:
Two types of trees grow in this area: one with russet bark and ruby-red pinecones, and another with gray bark and green pinecones. Squirrels and voles scamper about, collecting seeds from fallen cones. After so much travel, your stomachs growl with hunger.

The pine seeds from either tree are tasty, but the seeds from the ruby-red pinecones are poisonous.

A character can try to identify the edible pine seeds and make one of the following ability checks. Consider these examples:

[[/skill 13 nature]]. The character identifies both trees and which seeds are edible.

[[/skill 13 survival]]. The character observes that local woodland critters eat pine seeds only from the green pinecones.

On a failed check, a character accidently gathers the poisonous seeds.

Poisonous Pine Seeds. A creature that eats the seeds of a ruby-red pinecone must succeed on a [[/save 15 con]] saving throw or have the &Reference[Poisoned] condition until it finishes a Long Rest.

Foundry Conversion Credits.name: Foundry Conversion Credits
Foundry Conversion Credits.text:
The Heroes of the Borderlands Starter Set for Foundry Virtual Tabletop was produced by a group of Foundry VTT staff and contractors hand-selected from the Dungeons & Dragons Fifth Edition community. The below lists are sorted alphabetically.

Core Software Development

The system and this module would never be able to exist without the dedicated work of the Foundry VTT core development team:

  • Andrew Clayton

  • Ludovic Dey

  • Eber Höpfner

  • Kim Mantas

  • Richard Simões

System Development

The Dungeons & Dragons Fifth Edition game system on Foundry VTT owes its existence to an extensive list of volunteer developers to whom we will always be thankful. The vast majority of the development effort as part of the 5.1.0 Official release were contributed by:

  • Jeff Hitchcock

  • Kim Mantas

System Art

The custom artwork used throughout the character sheet were contributed by:

  • Mikiko (Contains Some NSFW Artwork)

The token ring used for every creature throughout the adventure and available for use in the system was contributed by:

  • Caeora

The Dynamic Token Engine

The dynamic token engine system and shaders were contributed by:

  • Ludovic Dey

Sourcebook Conversion

The conversion of the adventure text, images, tables, macros, scenes, stat blocks, and more into Foundry VTT were contributed by:

  • Matt Ryan

Token Creation

The creation of the portraits, tokens, and isolated subject artwork for use in the Dynamic Token Engine were contributed by:

  • Ian Hildebrandt

Partners at Wizards of the Coast

The creation of this sourcebook wouldn't have been possible without the help and support from our two primary contacts at Wizards of the Coast who helped us procure art, pushed for us to be able to make this the best conversion we could, handled the review process, and answered hundreds of questions. We would like to specially thank:

  • Head of Category Licensing & Business Development: Ann Earp

  • Associate Producer: Andy Smith
